1. The text discusses the use of ultra-hard X-ray observations to select a sample of active galactic nuclei (AGN) for a study of their far-infrared (FIR) properties. The selection of AGN using ultra-hard X-rays provides a direct view of the AGN, as these high-energy photons can easily pass through gas or dust in the line of sight. This is in contrast to optical or mid-infrared selection, which can be contaminated by the host galaxy.
2. The study uses data from the Herschel Space Observatory's Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver (SPIRE) to analyze the FIR emission from the AGN sample. The authors find that the FIR emission is not strongly contaminated by AGN-related emission, as evidenced by the small values of the correlation coefficients between the SPIRE wavebands and the bat luminosity. However, they do find a weak correlation between the 250 and 350 μm luminosity and ultra-hard X-ray luminosity for Sy 1 AGN only.
3. The authors also investigate the FIR colors (i.e. flux ratios) of the AGN sample and compare them to the colors of a sample of galaxies from the Herschel Reference Survey (HRS). They find that the FIR colors of the AGN sample are statistically similar to the colors of high stellar mass (M\* > 10^10.5 M\_sun) HRS galaxies, further emphasizing that the FIR emission of AGN host galaxies is likely produced by cold dust in the interstellar medium (ISM) heated by stellar radiation. However, they do find anomalous colors for 6 AGN, which have FIR seds dominated by synchrotron emission from a radio jet rather than thermally heated dust.

1. Myles Hollander, a statistics professor, is being interviewed about his career and experiences in the field.
2. He began his college career at Carnegie Mellon as an engineering major, but switched to math after being influenced by a charismatic math professor.
3. He went on to graduate school at Stanford, where he was part of a talented cohort of statistics students and was heavily influenced by professor Lincoln Ellsworth Moses.
4. Hollander's research has focused on nonparametric statistics, including developing inference procedures for the hyperparameter of the Dirichlet process.
5. He has also had a successful career as a co-author of three statistics books.
6. Hollander met his wife Glee at Stanford and they have been married for over 50 years.
7. He has had a long and productive career at Florida State University, where he has collaborated with many colleagues and mentored numerous students.
8. Hollander has served as the chair of the department and has been active in the American Statistical Association.
9. He has received numerous awards and accolades for his contributions to the field of statistics.
10. Hollander is looking forward to spending more time with his family and pursuing his interests in retirement.

1. The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is a topological invariant that can be used to distinguish between connected components of the moduli space of smooth projective surfaces and to compute the fundamental groups of complements of hypersurfaces in higher dimensions.
2. A Zariski pair is a pair of plane curves with the same combinatorics but non-homeomorphic complements. Finding new finite non-abelian groups that serve as fundamental groups of complements of plane curves and searching for more examples of Zariski pairs are important applications of fundamental group computations.
3. Fan proved some results concerning the projective fundamental group of complex line arrangements and conjectured that the inverse implication of his results is also correct. Recently, Eliyahu, Liberman, Schaps, and Teicher proved Fan's conjecture completely.
4. A conjugation-free geometric presentation of a line arrangement's fundamental group is a presentation with generators as meridians of lines at a far side of the arrangement and relations of a specific type. Fan's result implies that if the graph associated with the arrangement is acyclic, then the corresponding fundamental group has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
5. The paper aims to study which line arrangements have a fundamental group with a conjugation-free geometric presentation. The importance of this family of arrangements is that the incidence lattice determines the fundamental group of the complement without any computation.
6. The paper presents the computation of the fundamental group of the complement of real line arrangements using the Moishezon-Teicher method and the van Kampen theorem. It also discusses the relation between the families of nice, simple, and arrangements with conjugation-free geometric presentations.

1. The text discusses the use of flavor symmetry to generate the mass and mixing patterns of fermions in particle physics. It mentions the success of continuous symmetries like gauge symmetry and discrete symmetries like exchange symmetry in describing the mass and mixing pattern in the leptonic sector. A new symmetry called @xmath1 symmetry was introduced to avoid mass degeneracy under @xmath15 symmetry. This symmetry has been extensively studied and has been used to fit the tri-bi maximal mixing pattern in an extension of the standard model through the inclusion of @xmath1 discrete symmetry.
2. The text also discusses the possibility of generating non-zero and complex @xmath0 in the leptonic sector, which could lead to the exploration of CP violation in future short and long baseline experiments. This can be generated through radiative correction or the introduction of higher dimensional mass terms in the model.
3. The text also discusses the generation of non-zero complex @xmath0 and the possibility of non-zero CP violation in the proposed model of Altarelli-Feruglio with explicit soft breaking of @xmath1 symmetry. It also mentions that the tri-bi maximal mixing pattern can be generated naturally in the framework of see-saw mechanism with @xmath23 symmetry. However, the exact tri-bi maximal pattern forbids CP violation in the leptonic sector at low energy. The textures of mass matrices in the model could not generate lepton asymmetry. The authors investigate the generation of non-zero @xmath0 through see-saw mechanism by considering a small perturbation in @xmath2, the Dirac neutrino mass matrix, keeping the same texture of the right-handed Majorana neutrino mass matrix as proposed in ref.@xcite. They study the detailed phenomenology of neutrino mass and mixing including CP violation at low energy, neutrinoless double beta decay and leptogenesis.

1. Organic molecular crystals, which are composed of organic molecules held together by weak van der Waals forces, are emerging as excellent candidates for fabricating nanoscale devices. These crystals have potential applications in electronics and optoelectronics, including solar energy harvesting, surface photochemistry, organic electronics, and spintronics. A common feature of these devices is that they are composed of both an organic and inorganic component, with the organic component forming the active part of the device and the inorganic component providing the necessary electrical contact to external circuitry.
2. The electronic structure of the interface between the organic and inorganic components plays a crucial role in determining the final device performance. It is important to determine how charge transfers between the organic and inorganic component and the energies at which the transfer takes place. This is a challenging task, especially in the single-molecule limit.
3. Upon adsorption on a substrate, the electron addition and removal energies of a molecule change value from that of their gas phase counterparts. This is due to the formation of an image charge on the substrate in the vicinity of the molecule, which alters the addition or removal energy of charge carriers from the molecule.
4. A common way to calculate the addition and removal energies is to use a quasiparticle (qp) description. Within the qp picture, one ignores the effects of relaxation of molecular orbitals due to addition or removal of electrons and consequently takes the relative alignment of the metal Fermi level with either the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of a molecule as removal energy.
5. The adequacy of the qp description depends on the level of theory used to calculate the energy levels of the HOMO and LUMO. If the theory of choice is density functional theory (DFT), then it is important to note that except for the energy of the HOMO, which can be rigorously interpreted as the negative of the ionization potential, the Kohn-Sham orbitals cannot be associated with qp energies. This is commonly done in practice, but the Kohn-Sham qp levels may not provide a good approximation to the true removal energies, particularly for molecules.

1. The text discusses the interaction between many particles and how it can be described using pair potentials or forces between a single pair. This approach is accurate when the governing physical equations are linear, but if nonlinearities are present, nonadditivity gives rise to many-body effects.
2. Many-body effects can lead to changes in the total force acting on a particle, including strengthening or weakening of the force, a change in the direction of the force, or the appearance of stable or unstable configurations.
3. These effects are present in a variety of systems, including nuclear matter, superconductivity, colloidal suspensions, quantum-electrodynamic Casimir forces, polymers, nematic colloids, and noble gases.
4. Integrating out the degrees of freedom associated with small scales generates effective interactions among the large particles, which are not pairwise additive. These effective interactions can lead to collective behavior of the large particles, which can be described more easily if it is governed by pair potentials.
5. The text assesses the influence of many-body effects on critical Casimir forces (CCFs), which arise due to the confinement of the order parameter fluctuations in a critical fluid.
6. The authors study the normal and lateral CCFs acting on two colloidal particles immersed in a near-critical binary liquid mixture and close to a homogeneous, planar substrate.
7. They consider two three-dimensional spheres with different boundary conditions facing a homogeneous substrate at different sphere-surface-to-substrate distances.
8. The authors use field-theoretic mean field theory to calculate the forces between individual pairs and three-body forces on the same footing, and they find that these forces are characterized by universal scaling functions.

1. Molecular hydrogen (H2) is the most abundant molecule in the universe and plays a crucial role in the chemistry of the interstellar medium (ISM). Its formation is governed by the transformation of atomic diffuse clouds into molecular clouds.
2. Dust grains are the primary site for H2 formation in the ISM. The sticking of H atoms onto dust grains is an essential mechanism for H2 formation and cooling interstellar gas.
3. PAHs (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons) are significant dust grains in the ISM, and they have characteristics similar to graphite surfaces. The hydrogenation of PAHs is an important route to form H2 in the ISM.
4. The first hydrogenation of neutral coronene, a type of PAH, is associated with a barrier, but subsequent hydrogenation barriers vanish. Coronene films exposed to H/D atoms at high temperature confirmed the high H2 formation rate attributed to PAHs in photodissociation regions (PDRs).
5. PAH cations, which are usually present at lower extinction, also represent an important route to form H2. The addition of the first H atom is predicted to be barrierless, and a second H atom can react with the already adsorbed H to form H2 without a barrier.
6. In a pilot experiment, the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase was studied through exposure to hydrogen atoms. The results showed that odd hydrogenation states of coronene cations predominantly populate the mass spectrum.
7. The further hydrogenation of PAH cations is associated with a barrier if the number of already attached H atoms is odd and no barrier if this number is even. This alternating barrier-no barrier occurrence suggests that PAH cations can also enjoy highly hydrogenated states in the ISM and act as catalysts for H2 formation.
8. The experiments have been performed using a home-built tandem-mass spectrometer. The coronene ions are exposed to a constant flux of H atoms for different periods of time before their degree of hydrogenation is determined by means of mass spectrometry.
9. The data obtained from the experiment are a series of mass spectra of hydrogenated coronene cations as a function of H exposure time. The results show that the most

1. Atomic clocks, which measure time using the vibrations of atoms, have two main components: the atom or atoms used as the reference, and an active oscillator that is tuned using feedback based on measurements of the atom. The resonance frequency of the atom can vary based on factors such as the intensity of radiation from the oscillator, so a wave function is used to define the resonance frequency at absolute zero temperature. Computer-mediated feedback is used to adjust the oscillator based on measurements of the atom.
2. The use of atomic clocks and the concept of logical synchronization, which is the alignment of clock readings at the transmission and reception of signals, are important in digital communications and the study of spacetime curvature. The phase of a clock's cycle at which it receives a signal must be within a certain range for a logical symbol to be properly transmitted and written to memory.
3. The physics of signal propagation can impose constraints on channels, which are sets of pairs of clock readings at which a signal can be transmitted and received. These constraints can be used to steer the behavior of clocks in a network.
4. The behavior of open machines, which are systems that can receive and transmit signals, can be affected by clock adjustments and the relationship between the machine's clock and a proper clock. The echo count, which is the number of times a signal is transmitted and received between two machines, can be used to explain evidence in the form of an echo as being twice the radar distance between the machines.

1. The IEEE 802.15.4 standard is a low-power and low-data rate protocol designed for wireless personal area networks (WPANs) and wireless body area networks (WBANs). It operates in three different frequency ranges and uses carrier sense multiple access with collision avoidance (CSMA/CA) for channel access. The standard supports two types of topologies (star and peer-to-peer) and two modes of operation (beacon-enabled and non-beacon enabled).
2. The CSMA/CA mechanism used in IEEE 802.15.4 can result in packet loss due to collisions. The probability of a successful transmission by an end device is modeled as a function of the number of end devices, the backoff exponent, the probability of transmission success at a slot, and the probability of end device successfully allocated a wireless channel. The time delay caused by CSMA/CA backoff exponent is estimated as a probability of time delay event, which is obtained as the summation of the probabilities of time delay events for different backoff periods.

1. MOPPED is a patented algorithm for data compression and speeding up the evaluation of likelihood functions in astronomical data analysis. It is useful when the noise covariance matrix depends on the model's parameters, but it has limitations, particularly with multimodal and degenerate distributions.
2. The authors demonstrate MOPPED's application in galaxy spectra analysis and CMB power spectrum estimation. They also address the issue of "badly" behaved likelihoods in light transit analysis with a proposed solution.
3. The paper presents scenarios where MOPPED accurately and inaccurately represents the likelihood function. MOPPED's compression of data and faster likelihood evaluation provide significant runtime improvement when it accurately represents the likelihood function.
4. The authors discuss the criteria for MOPPED to accurately represent the likelihood function and provide an implementation of the solution for "badly" behaved likelihoods.
5. Limitations of the MOPPED algorithm are demonstrated through test cases from gravitational wave data analysis for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA). The short duration of a sine-gaussian burst signal allows for a static approximation, revealing issues with MOPPED in one-dimensional and multi-dimensional parameter estimation.

1. The cosmological constant problem (CCP) is a major puzzle in particle physics, and consists of several pieces. These pieces include the fact that the vacuum energy density can be the cosmological constant, and various sources of vacuum energy density exist, such as the zero point energy of each particle and potential energies accompanied with phase transitions. However, these vacuum energy densities can receive large radiative corrections including a cutoff scale. The experimental value of the cosmological constant is estimated to be much smaller than these theoretical values, which is known as the cosmological constant problem.
2. The pieces of the puzzle do not fit into the framework of Einstein gravity and the Standard Model of particle physics. In order to address this problem, the authors suggest an effective description of various experimental results concerning the vacuum energy. They propose that a dominant part of dark energy can originate from gravitational corrections of vacuum energy, under the assumption that the classical gravitational fields do not couple to a large portion of the vacuum energy effectively.
3. The vacuum energy density can have various sources, such as the zero point energy of each particle, the energy density from the Higgs potential, and the energy density accompanied with the chiral symmetry breaking due to quark condensations. The zero point energy density is calculated by using an effective potential at the one-loop level, and it contains quartic, quadratic, and logarithmic terms concerning an ultra-violet (UV) cutoff parameter. After the subtraction of logarithmic divergence, the zero point energy is given by the renormalization point. The zero point energy of the Higgs boson is estimated to be much larger than the experimental value of the cosmological constant, and its existence threatens the stability of our solar system. Therefore, it seems natural to suppose that the classical gravitational field does not feel a large portion of the vacuum energy.

1. Spectroscopic studies of hyperfine manifolds in alkali metals have been aided by the precision of experimental techniques and the straightforward interpretation of results due to their hydrogen-like structure.
2. Recent precise measurements in higher excited states accessible through two-step transitions have renewed interest in improving calculations in other states where theoretical methods such as many-body perturbation theory (MBPT) are yet to be tested.
3. Precise measurements in excited states beyond the first one have experimental complications, such as low signal-to-noise ratio and non-availability of detectors at desired frequencies.
4. The paper presents two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy as a tool for studies of atomic properties of higher excited states, which uses two lasers (pump and probe) counter-propagating through a thermal vapor.
5. The method monitors the absorption of the pump laser as a function of probe laser detuning, generating sub-Doppler peaks and sidebands that overcome the issues of low signal-to-noise ratio and non-availability of detectors.
6. The authors illustrate the technique using two ladder systems in rubidium, with different applications of amplitude and frequency modulation.
7. The theoretical model uses a density matrix formalism to describe a three-level atom in ladder configuration interacting with two lasers, modeled as Doppler-free and ignoring Zeeman sublevels for simplicity.
8. The system is solved using a Floquet basis expansion of the density matrix, resulting in a series of coupled equations that are solved recursively to extract the absorption of the first laser carrier and sidebands.
9. The three-level model reproduces the resonance features of absorption observed in experiments, and the method can be extended to other atomic levels.

1. The physics potential of forward proton tagging at the LHC has been a topic of interest, particularly for the central exclusive production (CEP) process where protons remain intact and are separated from the central system by a large rapidity gap. Observation of any particle in the CEP channel would provide a direct observation of its quantum numbers and allow for mass measurement regardless of decay products.
2. Proposals have been made to install forward proton detectors at the LHC, such as the FP420 collaboration's plan to install detectors 420 meters from the interaction points, allowing detection of central systems with masses in the approximate range of 70 to 170 GeV. Additional proposals aim to upgrade the capabilities of ATLAS and CMS to detect protons in the 220 m region.
3. The paper focuses on the CEP of the Standard Model (SM) and supersymmetric (MSSM) Higgs bosons with a mass of 120 GeV. The dominant decay channel for this mass region is H→b\bar{b}, which is difficult to observe in conventional Higgs searches due to the large QCD background. However, the CEP process suppresses the leading order background for this decay channel, making it observable in certain scenarios with appropriate proton tagging detectors.
4. The acceptance of the forward detectors is critical for this analysis, as it determines the smallest measurable energy loss of the outgoing protons and imposes an upper limit on the measurable momentum loss of the protons. The distance of the active edge of the detector from the beam and the aperture of the LHC beam elements between the interaction point and the forward detectors affect the acceptance.
5. The proposed forward detectors aim to associate particular protons with the Higgs candidate event by measuring the outgoing proton time-of-flight (TOF) from the interaction vertex to the detectors. The difference in arrival times of the protons on opposite sides of the central detector allows for a vertex measurement, which can then be matched with the vertex of a candidate Higgs event reconstructed using the central detector alone.

1. The text discusses the zero-field hall effect in chiral p-wave superconductors (SCs), which arises due to broken time-reversal symmetry, leading to a nonzero hall conductivity. This effect can be explained by the intrinsic angular momentum of Cooper pairs, spontaneous surface current, impurity effect, or multiband SC structure. The authors propose a new mechanism for this effect based on vortex dynamics near the Kosterlitz-Thouless (KT) transition in two-dimensional superfluid or SC films.
2. The authors describe the vortex-antivortex bound pair dynamics in a 2D p-wave pairing state with a vector order parameter, which gives rise to two types of integer vortices with different hall and vinen coefficients. This results in a convective term in the vortex pair polarization Fokker-Planck equation, leading to a nonzero vortex-dynamics-induced hall conductivity. The authors derive the response functions for bound pair dynamics and free vortex contribution, and investigate the frequency and temperature dependence of the conductivity tensor.
3. The authors also discuss the contribution of free vortex motion and the resulting total conductivity tensor. They present the paper organization and provide analytic expressions for certain quantities in the opposite limit of the convective ratio. The text assumes a neutral SF film system with film thickness of order the superconducting coherence length and linear dimension along the x and y directions. The vortex core motion relative to the local superfluid velocity leads to a Magnus force, and the SF film is driven by a vibrating substrate. The driving force on the vortex due to a transport current is a Lorentz force, which is balanced by the force from the environment. The polarization of a test vortex-antivortex pair is under the influence of an infinitesimal oscillating external field, and the langevin equation for their relative coordinate is obtained. The potential energy is given by the logarithmic interaction screened by the Kosterlitz dielectric constant, and the convective pair motion is one of the special features for a system with unequal opposite vortices.

1. The measurement of rotation curves (RCs) of disk galaxies is used to investigate the nature of dark matter (DM), including its content relative to baryonic components and their distributions. Dwarf galaxies are good candidates for this aim as their kinematics are generally dominated by the dark component, even at small galactocentric radii.
2. Recent studies of the RCs of dwarf galaxies have tested the NFW profile arising from pure N-body DM simulations and found that kinematic data are better fitted by a DM halo with a constant density core than by one that is centrally peaked.
3. The Orion dwarf galaxy is a nearby system with an extended disk, providing an important test of the DM paradigm. Its kinematics unambiguously point towards a cored profile, making it critically important for investigating the nature of the DM particle and the evolution of DM halos.
4. The Orion dwarf galaxy is an attractive candidate to determine the underlying gravitational potential of the galaxy. Its distance is estimated to be 5.4±1.0 Mpc, but the intrinsic uncertainty in this technique may allow for a larger distance ambiguity.
5. The Orion dwarf galaxy shows a large mass discrepancy at all radii, and the baryonic components are efficiently modeled. Spectral line imaging data show rich morphological and kinematic structure in the neutral gas disk.
6. The total gas mass is estimated to be (4.7±0.4)×10^7 M⊙, and the gas surface density profile is well fitted by an exponential thin disk with a scale length of 1.33 kpc.
7. The Orion dwarf galaxy is a decisive benchmark for the MOdified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) formalism and a promising target for further detailed studies, particularly a direct measurement of the distance.

1. The trihydrogen dication, consisting of three protons and one electron, has been studied extensively in the 1960s and 1970s. Its stability has been investigated through various theoretical and experimental methods.
2. Conroy, in a series of articles, studied the potential energy surfaces of the electronic ground state and the lowest excited states at linear and isosceles triangular configurations using a variational approach. The results suggest that the trihydrogen dication is not stable.
3. Schwartz and Schaad, as well as Somorjai and Yue, reported single-point calculations of the system at the supposed equilibrium equilateral triangular configuration, but did not address the stability problem.
4. Berkowitz and Stocker searched for the ion through charge stripping experiments and could not find evidence of a stable trihydrogen dication.
5. Later, the question of the existence of the trihydrogen dication was reconsidered theoretically by Shoucri and Darling, who examined equilateral configurations with the variational linear combination of atomic orbitals (LCAO) method, and by Hernndes and Carb, who studied two particular configurations with a more compact variational approach. No bound state was determined in these calculations.
6. Ackermann et al. revisited the question about the existence of the trihydrogen dication using the finite element method, which provided much higher accuracy than previously achieved. They treated the stability problem by keeping the nuclear charge as a continuous parameter and obtained critical values of the charges for the existence of stable or metastable equilateral triangular configurations.
7. The present study aims to address the question of the existence of the trihydrogen dication in an equilateral triangular configuration as a metastable state in a magnetic field. The study uses two methods, specialized variational with physically relevant trial functions and standard variational based on standard Gaussian trial functions, to explore the system and obtain highly accurate quantitative results for the total energy versus the size of the triangle.

1. Recent investigations of the large-scale distribution of galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) have revealed a complex relationship between the properties of galaxies (such as color, luminosity, surface brightness, and concentration) and their environments. Galaxy clustering is found to be a function of both star formation history and luminosity.
2. Color and luminosity measures of star formation history appear to have a more fundamental relationship with environment than do surface brightness and concentration measures. Some studies have explored the scale dependence of these relationships, but it is important to examine whether the density on large scales is related to galaxy properties independent of the relationships with density on small scales.
3. The SDSS is taking CCD imaging of the northern galactic sky and selecting targets for spectroscopy, most of them galaxies. Automated software performs all of the data processing, including astrometry, source identification, deblending and photometry, photometricity determination, calibration, spectroscopic target selection, spectroscopic fiber placement, and spectroscopic data reduction.
4. For the purposes of computing large-scale structure and galaxy property statistics, a subsample of SDSS galaxies known as the NYU Value Added Galaxy Catalog (NYU-VAGC) has been assembled. The low redshift catalog of this catalog, which corresponds to the SDSS Data Release 2 (DR2), has been used in this study. This catalog has important features for the study of low luminosity galaxies, including visual inspection of all of the images and spectra of low luminosity or low redshift galaxies, trimming of incorrectly deblended objects, and estimation of distances to low redshift objects using the local velocity field.
5. To evaluate the environments of galaxies in the sample, the number of other galaxies outside a projected radius of 10 kpc and within a certain outer radius and redshift direction is counted for each given galaxy. The mean expected number of galaxies in that volume is then calculated, and the density around galaxies in various classes is calculated as the density with respect to the mean. The sample is volume-limited for galaxies with a certain luminosity, and the total completeness-weighted effective area of the sample is 2220.9 square degrees. The catalog contains 28,089 galaxies.

1. Transverse spin fluctuations are important low-energy excitations in magnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry, and play a crucial role in various macroscopic properties such as long-range order, order parameter magnitude, Néel temperature, and spin correlations.
2. In the antiferromagnetic (AF) ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model, transverse spin fluctuations significantly reduce the zero-temperature AF order parameter in two dimensions and the Néel temperature in three dimensions.
3. Recent interest has focused on spin fluctuations due to defects, disorder, and vacancies in quantum antiferromagnets. In the random-t model, where the interaction is set to zero on a fraction of sites, the lattice-averaged AF order parameter is enhanced for small fractions due to suppressed quantum spin fluctuations. However, strong disorder in the Hubbard model with random on-site energies enhances spin fluctuations, leading to essentially empty and doubly-occupied sites acting as spin vacancies.
4. A new method has been developed to evaluate transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections about the Hartree-Fock (HF) level broken-symmetry state, in terms of magnon mode energies and spectral functions obtained in the random phase approximation (RPA). This method is applicable in the whole range of interaction strength and is demonstrated with three applications involving the AF ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model.
5. The RPA approach has been shown to properly interpolate between the weak and strong coupling limits for the spin-wave velocity and to yield identical results as the spin-wave theory approach in the strong coupling limit for the quantum Heisenberg antiferromagnet.
6. The quantum spin-fluctuation correction to sublattice magnetization is obtained solely in terms of transverse spin correlations, parallel to the spin-wave theory approach, and differs from the method involving self-energy corrections.
7. The method is based on a convenient way to perform the frequency integral in order to obtain spin correlations from spin propagators, and is illustrated for transverse spin correlations. The time-ordered, transverse spin propagator is written in frequency space as a sum of eigenvectors and eigenvalues of a matrix constructed from the zeroth-order, antiparallel-spin particle-hole propagator, evaluated in the self-consistent, broken-

1. The study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory, particularly in cosmology, has gained significant attention due to its role in explaining the large-scale homogeneity and isotropy of the universe, as well as the small-scale inhomogeneity and anisotropy. The dynamics of multi-field models of inflation, where the inflaton is coupled to another dynamical field during inflation, have been of particular interest. These models can lead to various features unavailable in single-field models, such as hybrid inflation models. The subsequent phase of energy transfer between the inflaton and other degrees of freedom has also been extensively studied, with the inflaton decaying through perturbative and non-perturbative processes.
2. The renormalization of time evolution equations in single-field models has been understood for several years, with methods such as the WKB expansion and adiabatic methods being used to extract divergences and renormalize the theory. However, multi-field models and the dynamics of reheating typically require the inclusion of quantum effects beyond the tree level, which brings in the issue of renormalization. The paper proposes a slightly different method to extract the divergences of the theory, allowing for dimensional regularization and the use of the closed time path formalism to follow the time-dependent evolution of the system.
3. The paper demonstrates the formalism with two examples: a simple reheating model and a hybrid inflation model motivated by supersymmetry. The authors investigate the narrow resonance regime and the broad resonance regime in the reheating model, emphasizing the importance of mixing effects between the fields, which were often neglected in previous models. In the supersymmetric hybrid model, the authors show that taking into account fluctuations and investigating the full mixed system can lead to the loss of some of the model's attractiveness compared to general hybrid models due to different effective mass corrections for the two fields.

1. The existence of dark matter (DM) has been established and its thermal relic abundance has been determined by the WMAP experiment. A promising candidate for DM is the weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP), which can be accommodated in models beyond the Standard Model by introducing an inert scalar field. The stability of the DM candidate is ensured by an imposed Z2 parity.
2. Neutrinos have nonzero but tiny masses, which may indicate that they are of Majorana type. Many models have been proposed to explain tiny neutrino masses, with the seesaw mechanism and the Higgs triplet model (HTM) being the simplest ways. However, these scenarios do not contain a DM candidate. In some models where tiny neutrino masses are generated by higher orders of perturbation, the DM candidate can be naturally contained.
3. In the HTM, Majorana masses for neutrinos are generated via the Yukawa interaction with a nonzero vacuum expectation value (VEV) of an SU(2) triplet scalar field with hypercharge 1. The vev of the triplet field is described by vt = √2 μvt/mT, where μvt is the VEV of the Higgs doublet field and mT is the typical mass scale of the triplet field. The direct information on the neutrino mass matrix would be extracted from the decay of the doubly charged component of the triplet field, which can be produced via vector boson fusion at hadron colliders. The searches for the doubly charged Higgs at the LHC put a lower bound on its mass of 870 GeV, assuming that the main decay mode is into a pair of same-sign W bosons.

1. Quantum communication technologies, such as quantum key distribution (QKD), promise to fundamentally change the way we communicate by allowing intrinsically secure communication. However, these new technologies require a new telecommunications infrastructure that can properly accommodate the quantum properties they rely on. This infrastructure will contain novel components, such as quantum memories, quantum repeaters, or quantum channels, which must all operate in a strictly quantum way.
2. Quantifying the quantum behavior of these devices is important for characterizing their suitability for quantum communication tasks. This can be done by measuring the quantum correlations in bipartite systems before and after they pass through a quantum channel. A strong quantum channel is one that preserves all or nearly all of the quantum correlations.

1. The study of dipole moments of elementary particles has provided valuable information on subatomic physics, including the discovery of spin, radiative corrections, and the renormalizable theory of QED.
2. A charged particle with spin has a magnetic moment, given by the gyromagnetic ratio and the anomaly. The Dirac equation predicts that for spin-1/2 point-like particles, the gyromagnetic ratio is 2 and the anomaly is zero.
3. Radiative corrections, such as those shown in Figure 1, give rise to the anomaly for point particles. The lowest-order correction is the Schwinger result, which was verified experimentally.
4. The magnetic and electric dipole moments can be represented as the real and imaginary parts of a generalized dipole operator, and the interaction Lagrangian is given by equation (ef{eq : lint}).
5. The electron anomaly is now measured to a precision of about four parts in a billion, and the measured value is used to give the best determination of the fine-structure constant. The muon anomaly is measured to 0.5 parts per million and has an increased sensitivity to higher mass scale radiative corrections.
6. The standard model value of the muon anomaly has measurable contributions from QED loops containing leptons and photons, hadronic loops containing hadrons in vacuum polarization loops, and weak loops involving the W and Z weak gauge bosons.
7. A significant difference between the experimental value and the standard model prediction would signify the presence of new physics, such as lepton substructure, anomalous couplings, or supersymmetry.
8. The hadronic light-by-light contribution to the muon anomaly is the ultimate limit to the precision of the standard model value and can only be calculated from a model.
9. The measurements of the muon anomaly have placed serious restrictions on physics beyond the standard model and have grown substantially in interest with the development of supersymmetric theories.

1. The paper presents a new design for an optomechanical system that consists of a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide, which enables the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling.
2. The reactive coupling originates from the dependence of the microdisk resonator's extrinsic losses on mechanical motion and further phase-dependent gradient forces.
3. The design is more effective in achieving cooling of the system to its ground state, but the paper explores other possibilities of investigating the effects of strong reactive coupling without cooling the system.
4. The authors examine the nonlinear response of the microdisk resonator to pump-probe fields, reporting reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting.
5. Normal mode splitting is observed in output fields in the presence of reactive coupling, while there is no normal mode splitting in output fields in the absence of reactive coupling.
6. The system consists of a microdisk cavity coupled to a freestanding waveguide, with a strong pump field and a weak stokes field entering the system through the waveguide.
7. The Hamiltonian of the system is given, describing the energy of the cavity field, the energy of the waveguide, interactions between the waveguide and incident fields, and coupling of the cavity field to the pump field and the stokes field.
8. The paper investigates the physical effects by scanning the stokes laser and studies the behavior of the system's output fields, finding that reactive coupling can lead to the appearance of normal mode splitting in the output stokes field.

1. Quantum many-body systems out of equilibrium have been a subject of increasing interest, with many studies revealing new findings but leaving several questions unresolved.
2. The emergence of a current in a physical quantity can cause a system to become non-equilibrium, and transport of that quantity is an important aspect of the dynamics.
3. Transport properties, especially magnetization transport in low-dimensional spin systems, have gained importance in the areas of spintronics and nano-device applications.
4. Theoretical studies have confirmed that the properties of transportation in closed quantum systems differ significantly from their classical counterparts.
5. Studies on introducing current in integrable Hamiltonians have shown that current-carrying states exhibit oscillatory nature and power-law decay of correlations in space.
6. Analytical and simulative studies have been conducted on nonequilibrium transport of magnetization in open quantum spin chains, shedding light on the behavior of physical quantities during equilibration.
7. Integrability has become a crucial perspective in the exploration of nonequilibrium phenomena, as integrable systems have restricted dynamics and their relaxation process depends on the initial state.
8. A quantum Ising chain model is described, and an initial configuration is constructed incorporating odd-occupation basis states in momentum space along with other states.
9. The dynamics of transverse magnetization in the quantum Ising chain model are studied, and it is observed that the system does not reach a homogeneous magnetization even after infinite time.
10. The phenomena of quantum phase transition are manifested in the dynamics in two ways, and the initial configuration contains several parameters, with all features of the dynamics being true for arbitrary values of those parameters.

1. Studying QCD at finite baryon density is important for understanding the structure of compact stars and the conditions near the core of collapsing stars.
2. Sufficiently cold and dense baryonic matter is in the color superconducting phase, which was proposed by Frautschi and Barrois by observing that one-gluon exchange between two quarks is attractive in the color antitriplet channel.
3. The color superconducting phase may exist in the central region of compact stars, but the charge neutrality condition and chemical equilibrium are required, which can lead to a mismatch between the Fermi surfaces of the pairing quarks.
4. The Cooper pairing will eventually be destroyed with the increase of mismatch, and the system may exhibit a first-order phase transition or a spatial non-uniform Loff (Larkin-Ovchinnikov-Fudde-Ferrell) state in a certain window of moderate mismatch.
5. The charge neutrality condition plays an essential role in determining the ground state of the neutral system. If the charge neutrality condition is satisfied globally and the surface tension is small, the mixed phase will be favored.
6. Homogeneous neutral cold-dense quark matter can be in the gapless 2SC (g2sc) phase or gapless CFL (gcfl) phase, depending on the flavor structure of the system. These gapless states resemble the unstable Sarma state but are thermal stable under a natural charge neutrality condition.
7. The existence of thermal stable gapless color superconducting phases was confirmed in refs. and generalized to finite temperatures. Recent results show that the g2sc and gcfl phases can exist at moderate baryon density in the color superconducting phase diagram.
8. In the g2sc phase, there is a chromomagnetic instability where the Meissner screening masses for five gluons corresponding to broken generators become imaginary. This instability is inherent to gapless phases and is still not fully understood.
9. Giannakis and Ren suggested that a Loff state might be the true ground state, and a charge neutral Loff state can cure the instability of off-diagonal 4-7th gluons, but not the diagonal 8-th gluon. A narrow unstable Loff window exists when the charge

1. The debate about the properties of the melting phase transition in two-dimensional systems has been ongoing for several decades, but recent developments in the fabrication of 2D materials may provide clarification.
2. The Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) theory is the most widely accepted theory for this transition, which involves two separate, continuous transitions as a solid transforms into a liquid in quasi-equilibrium steps. These transitions involve the unbinding of dislocation pairs and dislocations into point defects.
3. The KTHNY theory is compatible with the Mermin-Wagner theorem, which forbids the existence of exact long-range positional order in 2D for a wide range of pair potentials at finite temperatures. However, it assumes a dilute, unstructured distribution of lattice defects, which is not always observed in experiments.
4. The validity of the KTHNY theory has been examined for systems with different pair interactions, including hard-sphere (disk), Lennard-Jones, Coulomb, dipole-dipole, and Debye-Hückel (screened Coulomb or Yukawa) inter-particle interactions.
5. The timeline of research on this topic shows a trend towards identifying first or second order phase transitions in earlier particle simulations, but since approximately the year 2000, particle-based numerical studies have favored the KTHNY theory.
6. A possible resolution to the ongoing debate is that extensive Monte Carlo simulations of 2D Lennard-Jones systems have revealed the metastable nature of the hexatic phase, which may be linked to the observation of the hexatic phase in numerical simulations operating on a longer diffusive time scale.

1. The Kepler mission has discovered over 4100 planetary candidates, leading to a better understanding of planet occurrence rates around various types of stars. One significant finding is that small planets, particularly those with sizes between Earth and Neptune, are common. However, accurately determining planetary radii is crucial for understanding the distribution of planetary structures and the occurrence rates of "rocky" and "non-rocky" planets.

2. The presence of stellar companions can affect the observed transit depths and planetary radii in the Kepler candidate sample. Recent work suggests that a non-negligible fraction of Kepler host stars may be multiple stars, which can introduce a systematic uncertainty into planetary radii and occurrence rate distributions. Undetected stellar companions can lead to misclassifications of planet sizes, as seen with hot Jupiters, where 30% were classified as smaller planets due to unaccounted transit dilution from stellar companions.

3. The paper explores the effects of undetected stellar companions on the observed transit depths and derived planetary radii for the entire Kepler candidate sample. The study focuses on bound companions within a certain distance and shows that, without spectroscopic or high-resolution imaging observations to vet companions, observed planetary radii will be systematically too small. However, if a candidate host star is observed with high-resolution imaging or radial velocity spectroscopy to screen for companions, the underestimate of the true planet radius is significantly reduced. This vetting process will be even more effective for K2 and TESS candidates, which will be closer to Earth than Kepler candidates.

1. The range of hydrogen column densities in nearby galaxies' neutral gas disks is similar to that of damped Lyman-alpha systems (DLAs) in quasar spectra. Mapping the HI gas of DLA absorbing systems in 21-cm emission would provide a direct observational link between DLAs and local galaxies, but it is currently impossible with present technology due to the weak 21-cm line caused by the small transition probability.
2. The identification of DLAs as absorbers in background QSO spectra is not distance-dependent, and the lowest redshift Lyman-alpha absorbers cannot be observed from the ground because the Earth's atmosphere is opaque to UV wavelengths. The number density of DLAs decreases rapidly toward lower redshifts, making it difficult to find DLAs whose 21-cm emission would be within the reach of present-day radio telescopes.
3. There are now over 100 DLA galaxies known at various redshifts, spanning a wide range of galaxy properties. However, it is not just luminous, high surface brightness spiral galaxies that contribute to the HI cross-section above the DLA threshold. Blind 21-cm emission line surveys in the local universe with single-dish radio telescopes have resulted in an accurate measurement of the cosmological density of neutral hydrogen, which can be used as a reference point for higher redshift DLA studies.
4. High-resolution 21-cm maps of a large sample of local galaxies observed with the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope can be used to constrain the column density distribution function of HI. These maps show that most of the HI atoms are in column densities around 10^21 atoms cm^-2, both in the local universe and at higher redshifts.
5. The cross-section weighted probability distribution functions of various galaxy parameters can be calculated now that accurate cross-section measurements of all galaxies in the sample and their space density are known. For example, 87% of the DLA cross-section is in galaxies that are fainter than M\_B = -18, and the expected median impact parameter of DLA systems is 7.8 kpc.
6. The metallicity distribution for HI column densities peaks around [O/H] = -0.

1. Stars are thought to form in star clusters, with only a modest percentage of the gas in a giant molecular cloud being turned into stars during the collapse and fragmentation of the cloud.
2. After the onset of stellar winds and supernovae explosions, the gas within the embedded cluster is removed, causing a rapid change in the gravitational potential energy and resulting in a cluster that is far out of equilibrium.
3. Many studies have attempted to constrain the initial stellar mass function (IMF) in clusters by studying the internal dynamics of young clusters and comparing the ratio of dynamical mass to observed light to simple stellar population models. However, these studies have reported discrepant results, with some finding non-standard IMFs and others finding standard Kroupa or Salpeter type IMFs.
4. Bastian et al. (2006) noted an age-dependence in how well clusters fit standard IMFs, with all clusters older than 1100 Myr being well fit by Kroupa or Salpeter IMFs, while the youngest clusters showed a significant scatter. They suggest that this is due to the youngest (tens of Myr) clusters being out of equilibrium.
5. The paper provides evidence that the young massive clusters M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1, which have been reported to have non-standard stellar IMFs, are likely not in dynamical equilibrium due to rapid gas loss.
6. The authors also show that NGC 1569-A, which has been reported to have a standard IMF based on dynamical measurements, is likely also out of equilibrium.
7. The paper supports the hypothesis that rapid gas expulsion from young clusters, which leaves the cluster severely out of equilibrium, causes the effect of "infant mortality" in which many young clusters are destroyed.
8. The authors conclude that the excess light at large radii seen in many massive young star clusters is a signature of violent relaxation after gas expulsion, and that these clusters have effective star formation efficiencies of around 25-35%.
9. The observations presented in the paper also suggest that the escaping stars from a cluster can result in an artificially high velocity dispersion, leading to incorrect mass estimates based on the assumption of stellar virial equilibrium.

1. Quantum fluctuations can both suppress and enhance chaotic motion in wave packets in quantum physics, depending on the system and the specific phenomenon being considered.
2. The suppression of chaotic motion by quantum fluctuations is seen in the kicked rotor system, where quantum interference prevents the wave packet from delocalizing.
3. On the other hand, quantum fluctuations can enhance chaotic motion through the tunneling effect, as seen in the kicked double-well model.
4. The relationship between chaotic behavior and tunneling phenomena in classically chaotic systems is an important subject of study in quantum physics.
5. Semiclassical descriptions of tunneling phenomena in classically chaotic systems have been developed by several groups.
6. Lin and Ballentine studied the interplay between tunneling and classical chaos in a particle in a double-well potential with an oscillatory driving force.
7. They found that coherent tunneling takes place between small, isolated classical stable regions of phase space, which are much smaller than the volume of a single potential well.
8. Hnggi and coworkers studied chaos-suppressed tunneling in the driven double-well model using the Floquet formalism.
9. They found a one-dimensional manifold in the parameter space where tunneling is completely suppressed by the coherent driving.
10. The time scale for tunneling between the wells diverges due to the intersection of the ground state doublet of the quasienergies.

1. Understanding dissipative quantum dynamics of a system embedded in a complex environment is an important topic in physics and chemistry, with significant progress made in condensed phase dynamics through models such as the Caldeira-Leggett model and spin-boson model.
2. These models typically represent the environment as a bosonic bath, a set of non-interacting harmonic oscillators whose influences on the system are encoded in a spectral density.
3. While bosonic bath models have been successful, other bath models have been suggested to play essential roles in various physical and chemical studies.
4. Examples include using a bath of non-interacting Morse or quartic oscillators, mapping anharmonic environments onto effective harmonic modes with temperature-dependent spectral density, and fermionic bath models.
5. Both bosonic and fermionic environments are Gaussian baths, which can be exactly treated by the linear response in the path integral formalism. However, for non-Gaussian baths, attaining numerically exact open quantum dynamics requires higher-order response functions or explicit dynamical treatments of the bath degrees of freedom.
6. A stochastic formulation of quantum dissipation has been extended to incorporate all three fundamental bath models: non-interacting bosons, fermions, and spins.
7. The stochastic Liouville equation (SLE) prescribes a simple yet general form of quantum dissipative dynamics when bath effects are modeled as colored noises. Different bath models and properties are distinguished by assigning distinct noise variables and associated statistics.
8. Achieving stable convergences in stochastic simulations has proven challenging, even for well-studied bosonic bath models. Direct stochastic simulation of real-time dynamics remains formidable, especially for generic quantum environments with non-Gaussian characteristics or fermionic degrees of freedom.
9. The stochastic formalism provides straightforward prescriptions to compute dynamical quantities such as system-bath joint observables and can be used to derive numerical schemes for deterministic simulations of quantum dynamics for all three fundamental bath models.
10. The paper also discusses a dual-fermion mapping for handling non-Gaussian properties of spin baths and presents numerical examples to illustrate the methods.

1. The text discusses the glass transition, a phenomenon that occurs when a liquid cools and becomes an amorphous solid. This transition is associated with a sharp increase in relaxation times and a departure from equilibrium in laboratory measurements. Theoretically, it is believed that the transition is triggered by an underlying thermodynamic transition, known as the Kauzmann temperature, where only one minimum-energy basin of attraction is accessible to the system. However, this theory has been called into question by experimental data and simulations of polydisperse hard-core disks. The discrepancies between hard-disk and soft-sphere systems may be due to fundamental differences in the models or inappropriate sampling at low temperatures and high densities.
2. The text also discusses the Mode Coupling Theory (MCT), which predicts a transition from a high-temperature liquid state to a low-temperature arrested state at a critical temperature. The MCT has been used to study a molecular dynamics (MD) simulation model adapted to the glass-forming NiZr transition metal system. The MD simulations were used to calculate the partial structure factors and correlation functions of the system, which showed a structural relaxation in three successive steps as predicted by the idealized schematic MCT. The nonergodicity parameters, which describe the long-time behavior of the intermediate scattering function, were also calculated and found to decay to zero for longer times at all temperatures investigated, in agreement with the full MCT. The memory functions, which are used to evaluate the @xmath118, were also calculated and found to be in full agreement with the results in @xcite for the NiZr system. The @xmath118 has a maximum at an intermediate value of @xmath128 for all the investigated temperatures, and the values of @xmath130 move with decreasing temperature towards the limiting value 1 in the high temperature regime. A crossover temperature @xmath131 was estimated from the linear fit of the @xmath3-values for ni above 950 k and for zr above 1000 k. The diffusion coefficients of the Ni and Zr species were also calculated and found to have a fixed ratio in the temperature regime above approximately 1000 k.
