Chimera states, which are the coexistence of coherent and incoherent oscillations in a network of identical phase oscillators, have been observed in various models such as Kuramoto phase oscillators, periodic and chaotic maps, Stuart-Landau oscillators, and coupled chemical oscillators. These states have been shown to emerge naturally in a mechanical experiment involving two subpopulations of identical metronomes coupled in a hierarchical network. In the context of neuroscience, chimera states are believed to explain the phenomenon of unihemispheric sleep observed in many birds and dolphins. A new study has identified a variety of single and multi-chimera states in networks of non-locally coupled neurons represented by Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators.
2. The study also identifies a new "mixed oscillatory state" (MOS) in which desynchronized neurons are uniformly distributed among those attracted by a stable stationary state. Chimera-like patterns have also been discovered in the more natural setting where only the membrane potential variables are coupled. The more realistic 3d-HR model, which includes a third variable representing a slowly varying current, exhibits bursting modes and only states of complete synchronization and MOS have been observed. However, when coupling is allowed only among the first (membrane potential) variables, chimera states are discovered in cases where spiking occurs within sufficiently long bursting intervals. The study of the collective behavior of a system of nonlocally coupled Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators and the investigation of the existence of chimera states in relation to the values of all network parameters is also discussed.

1. Kauffman networks are disordered dynamical systems used to model genetic regulatory systems. They were studied using mean field theory and a dynamical phase transition was found. In this paper, the authors focus on the structural properties of the networks that determine their attractors. They introduce the notion of relevant elements and study their probability distribution. In the next paper, they describe how the relevant elements are subdivided into asymptotically non-communicating, independent modules. The modular organization of random Boolean networks was already suggested by Kauffman and used to study analytically the attractors in certain networks. The authors show that it is possible to describe the phase transition in random Boolean networks in terms of the scaling of the number of relevant elements with system size or in terms of a percolation transition in the set of the relevant elements.
2. The authors computed the properties of the attractors in the framework of the annealed approximation, but observed that the results of this approximation are reliable only when the system is chaotic enough. They propose a new approximation scheme that works better in the frozen phase and on the critical line. This region in parameter space is the most interesting one, since it reproduces some features of real cells and is also the less understood.
3. The authors define the Kauffman model, which consists of a set of elements, each with a binary variable representing its state of activation. Each element is under the control of other elements, and its state is determined by the states of its control genes and a response function. The control elements and response functions are chosen at random. The dynamics of the system obey a deterministic but disordered evolution law. The authors are interested in the probability distributions of the number, length, and size of the attraction basins of the different periodic orbits, as well as in the distribution of transient times. They observe that two dynamical regimes are present, and that the line separating them has properties reminiscent of those of real cells. In the chaotic phase, the average length of the cycles increases exponentially with system size, while in the frozen phase, the typical length of the cycles does not increase with system size. The authors also discuss the distribution of the weights of the attraction basins and the number of different cycles in a network.

1. The text discusses the phenomenon of turbulence in quantum fluids, specifically in superfluid helium and one-component atomic Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs). In these systems, many quantized vortices with quantized circulation are nucleated, forming tangles, which is different from classical turbulence (CT) in classical fluids where the circulation of the velocity field is not quantized. The element of quantum turbulence (QT) is believed to be useful for the understanding of CT.
2. The text also discusses a new trend in turbulence study in multi-component BECs, which have various characteristic features, including the realization of multicomponent BECs. In this system, there exists not only a velocity field but also a (quasi) spin field. Due to the spin degrees of freedom, various topological excitations such as monopole, skyrmion, knot, domain wall, and vortex can be generated, leading to novel turbulence where both the velocity and spin fields are much disturbed.
3. The text also discusses the possibility of a Kolmogorov spectrum in spin-superflow turbulence (SST) with hydrodynamic equations obtained from the Gross-Pitaevskii equation. The authors apply three approximations to these hydrodynamic equations and obtain the equations for spin motion and velocity motion. By applying a Kolmogorov-type dimensional scaling analysis, the authors obtain the -5/3 and 4/5 power laws for the velocity and spin fields, respectively. These power laws are confirmed by numerical results, indicating that the spectrum of the kinetic energy of SST can obey the Kolmogorov spectrum.

1. Low-luminosity Active Galactic Nuclei (LLAGNs) are thought to have low luminosities due to very low accretion rates onto supermassive black holes, and are predicted to have a "submillimetre bump" in their spectral energy distribution (SED) caused by an advection-dominated accretion flow (ADAF) rather than a standard disc.
2. The ADAF model predicts high brightness temperatures in radio bands, making future very-long-baseline-interferometry (VLBI) instruments promising for imaging accretion discs. However, there is a gap between observations and the ADAF spectrum at low-frequency radio bands, indicating the existence of additional unknown emission.
3. About half of low-luminosity Seyfert galaxies and LINERs, and at least 25% of transition objects, hold a compact radio core. Most of the cores show nearly flat spectra in 0.5-arcsec resolution, indicating jet domination.
4. An ADAF+jet model has been proposed to explain the radio excess in some LLAGNs, and high-frequency observations are promising for detecting the inverted spectrum of the ADAF due to less contamination from non-thermal jets and larger flux densities at higher frequencies.
5. The authors report millimetre survey and submillimetre data analyses for many LLAGNs, and find that at least half of the sources show inverted spectra between 15 and 96 GHz, indicating the presence of the ADAF.
6. The submillimetre fluxes measured with the SCUBA on the JCMT may be from the dust associated with host galaxies, and the inverted spectra are not caused by resolution effect but intrinsic properties of the cores.
7. The authors suggest that the relative radiative efficiencies between the jet and disc in LLAGNs are determined by some kind of physical parameter(s) in the central engine, and the central engines of LLAGNs probably can produce jets.

1. Dust grains in the interstellar medium affect the propagation of starlight through scattering, absorption, and reradiation. Studying these processes has provided insights into the physical and chemical properties of dust grains.
2. The degree of absorption and scattering by dust depends on the wavelength of the incident radiation, which can be quantified by the normalized dust extinction law (or reddening law). The ratio of total to selective extinction is a commonly used measure of the slope of the extinction/reddening law.
3. Galactic dust displays a wide range of behavior, with an average R0 value of around 3.1, but this is not universal. Significant deviations from this canonical R0 value and corresponding differences in the overall shape of the extinction/reddening law are known to exist for various interstellar dust clouds.
4. The variations in R0 appear to be generally correlated with environment, with higher R0 values found in dense molecular clouds and lower R0 values in more diffuse, high-latitude cirrus clouds.
5. Measurements of R0 along many sight lines through a broad range of cloud types are necessary to improve our understanding of the dependence of R0 on environment.
6. The traditional method of spectral typing individual cluster stars, in conjunction with photometric measurements, allows for a direct and precise measurement of extinction and reddening. However, this method requires high-quality, flux-calibrated spectra and a good understanding of the effects of metallicity on the energy output of stars.
7. The study proposes three methods for measuring the R0 of dust in the foreground of differentially-reddened globular clusters using broad-band photometry, which are based on the premise that the width of the blue horizontal branch (HB) is minimized when the appropriate R0 value is used to correct the photometry for extinction and reddening.
8. The methods are applied to NGC 4833, a low-latitude galactic globular cluster with variable extinction across its face, and realistic Monte Carlo simulations of the cluster data set are used to estimate the accuracy with which R0 can be recovered.

1. Heavy fermion systems are characterized by a hierarchy of energy scales, with the Kondo scale marking the screening of local magnetic moments through a many-body effect that entangles the spins of conduction electrons and local moments.
2. Below the coherence temperature, which tracks the Kondo scale, a paramagnetic heavy fermion liquid emerges, characterized by a large fermi surface with Luttinger volume including both magnetic moments and conduction electrons.
3. The competition between Kondo screening, which favors paramagnetic ground states, and the Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yosida (RKKY) interaction, which favors magnetically ordered states, is at the heart of quantum phase transitions in heavy fermion systems.
4. Two radically different scenarios have been put forward to describe this quantum phase transition: the standard Hertz-Millis picture, where the quasi-particles of the heavy-fermion liquid remain intact across the transition and undergo a spin-density wave transition, and alternative scenarios where the quantum critical point is linked to the breakdown of the quasi-particle state and a topological reorganization of the fermi surface across the transition is expected.
5. Recent experiments show that a change in fermi surface topology must not necessarily occur only at the magnetic order-disorder quantum critical point (QCP), but can be shifted to either side of the QCP via application of positive or negative chemical pressure.
6. The paper addresses these questions through an explicit calculation of the fermi surface topology in the framework of the Kondo lattice model (KLM), using dynamical cluster approximation (DCA) calculations aimed at investigating the KLM ground state. The results show that the KLM can describe the competition between RKKY-mediated spatial magnetic order and the time-displaced correlations responsible for Kondo screening, and that the DCA is a well-suited approximation for use with the KLM.

1. The discovery of a resonance at 125 GEV at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), compatible with expectations for the Higgs particle, is a major step towards understanding the origin of the mass of fundamental particles. This discovery may also affect the subfield of gravitation, particularly in models where the Higgs field has nonminimal coupling to the general relativity sector. Nonminimal coupling between the Higgs and spacetime curvature may be beneficial for having the Higgs responsible for inflation and as a suppression mechanism for the contribution to dark energy expected from quantum fields.
2. White dwarfs can be used to obtain limits on the coupling of the Higgs field to a specific curvature invariant by means of spectroscopic observations. This is demonstrated by the analysis of data taken from the HST archive on a second white dwarf, Procyon b, in addition to a carbon-rich white dwarf, BPM 27606, using the Southern African Large Telescope (SALT). The search for coupling between the Higgs (or any scalar field permeating the whole universe) and spacetime curvature arises naturally within the framework of field theory in curved spacetime. The lagrangian density for an interacting scalar field in a generic spacetime characterized by the metric tensor is written as L = (1/2)g^(1/2)g^(ij)∂\_iφ∂\_jφ - (1/2)m^2g^(1/2)φ^2 - (1/4!)g^(1/2)λφ^4 - (1/2)ξRg^(1/2)φ^2, where g is the determinant of the metric tensor, ∂\_i is the partial derivative with respect to the i-th coordinate, m is the mass parameter of the scalar field, λ is the self-coupling quartic coefficient of the scalar field, R is the Ricci scalar, and ξ is the coupling constant between the scalar field and the Ricci scalar. The coupling constant ξ is a free parameter in any model so far imagined to describe scenarios of scalar fields coupled to gravity, and it is therefore important to extract this coefficient, or upper bounds, from phenomenological analyses.
1. The discovery of pulsations in two new extremely low-mass white dwarfs (ELM WDs), J1614 and J222

1. The interstellar medium (ISM) of a typical disk galaxy is divided into distinct phases: hot ionized gas, warm neutral medium, and cold neutral medium. Star formation is restricted to cold dense gas and is strongly correlated with the molecular gas content. However, the presence of molecules may not be the cause of star formation but rather a marker of the cold and dense regions where gravitational collapse can occur.
2. The gas temperature sets the characteristic size and mass of prestellar cores in post-shock regions within magnetized, star-forming clouds. Tracking molecular chemistry is crucial for accurately representing small-scale fragmentation in numerical simulations of star-forming clouds. Molecular gas is predominantly found in dense, cold regions where dust shielding and self-shielding have attenuated the interstellar radiation field intensity.
3. The transition zones separating atomic and molecular gas, called photodissociation regions (PDRs), have been studied extensively. The outer layers of a PDR are typically composed of atomic hydrogen and singly ionized carbon, with the atomic-to-molecular transition beginning to occur as column density increases. The chemistry and thermodynamics of PDRs become dominated by deep penetrating cosmic rays and the freeze-out of molecules onto dust grains in the inner layers.
4. Simulating the ISM and star formation is a computational challenge due to the enormous range of spatial scales involved. Three-dimensional simulations have attempted to replicate a supernova-driven ISM, with varying degrees of success in reproducing a multiphase ISM or demonstrating the regulation of the star formation rate by stellar feedback. However, studies examining the atomic-to-molecular transition within large-scale, three-dimensional simulations have received less attention.

1. The discovery of an overdensity of stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) has been interpreted as an intervening population of stars that may represent a dwarf galaxy or tidal debris. This overdensity, labeled as the VRC (Vertical Extension of the Red Clump), has been analyzed and found to be a massive foreground population with about 5% of the angular surface density of the LMC itself. This conclusion, if true, would have profound consequences for the interpretation of galactic microlensing studies, as this stellar foreground population could be responsible for a sizable fraction of the microlensing signal toward the LMC. However, this explanation has been challenged on several grounds, including the lack of evidence for a foreground population in the MACHO team's extensive photometric database and the incompatibility of the feature's redder color with the hypothesis of a foreground clump population.
2. The origin of the VRC feature observed in the color-magnitude diagrams of the LMC has been debated, with some arguing for an intervening stellar population and others for a stellar evolutionary origin. Using BVR CCD photometry of several fields at different locations in the LMC, a team of researchers has confirmed the presence of substructure in LMC red clump morphology corresponding to the VRC. However, they argue that the origin is likely to be due to stellar evolution, not an intervening population. They demonstrate that the VRC corresponds precisely in magnitude and color to the so-called "blue loops" experienced by aging intermediate-mass core helium-burning stars.
3. The team also shows that similar red clump morphology is present in the cmd of Hipparcos, which probes stellar populations on scales of 100 pc from the sun, where intervening dwarf galaxies or tidal debris cannot be invoked. Finally, they analyze the argument used by Zaritsky & Lin to reject stellar evolution as the cause of the VRC and show that a more realistic model for the star formation history in the LMC is not only consistent with the VRC but also provides a better fit to the data.

1. The text discusses the relationship between star formation and cluster mass in galaxy clusters using data from WISE and SDSS DR7.
2. Cluster membership is determined using SDSS DR7 spectroscopic redshifts, and star formation rates are determined using 22  photometry from WISE.
3. A total of 109 star-forming demi-LIRGs are detected within 3  of 69 clusters, and both the fraction of demi-LIRGs and the mean specific star formation rate of cluster galaxies increase with projected distance from the cluster center.
4. However, the fraction of demi-LIRGs remains below the field value even at 3 times the cluster virial radius.
5. The paper finds no evidence of a correlation between the cluster specific star formation rate and cluster mass, indicating that transformation mechanisms which scale strongly with cluster mass may not play a dominant role in the evolution of star formation in clusters.
6. The results suggest that strangulation, a cluster mechanism that cuts off a galaxy's resource for future cold gas supplies, may be an important cluster mechanism for regulating star formation in dense environments.

1. The Bishop-Phelps theorem states that every bounded linear functional on a Banach space can be approximated by norm attaining functionals, but this result does not hold for bounded linear operators in general.
2. The Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás theorem is a numerical version of the Bishop-Phelps theorem, which provides a condition for the existence of a norm attaining operator.
3. The Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás property (BPBp) is a condition on a pair of Banach spaces that allows for a version of the Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás theorem to hold.
4. Uniformly convex Banach spaces and certain finite-dimensional Banach spaces satisfy the BPBp.
5. The Kim-Lee theorem is a characterization of uniformly convex Banach spaces in terms of the BPBp.
6. The strong Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás property (SBPBp) is a strengthening of the BPBp that requires the norm attaining operator to be close to the original operator.
7. The paper studies the SBPBp for bounded linear operators and provides a characterization of the SBPBp for a specific pair of Banach spaces.

1. The analysis of modern accelerator-based neutrino oscillation experiments requires a good understanding of the intermediate-energy neutrino-nucleus scattering cross section.
2. The importance of multi-nucleon events has been suggested in many calculations of charge-changing quasielastic cross sections. The contribution of two-particle-two-hole (2p-2h) excitations is now thought to be essential for a proper description of data.
3. A growing interest has arisen in including 2p-2h models into the Monte Carlo event generators used by neutrino collaborations. The only 2p-2h model implemented up to date in some of the Monte Carlo neutrino event generators corresponds to the so-called IFIC Valencia model, which has been incorporated in GENIE.
4. Implementing 2p-2h models in Monte Carlo codes is challenging due to the high computational time required for the large number of nested integrals involved in the evaluation of the inclusive hadronic tensor with sums over the final 2p-2h states.
5. Approximations can be made to speed up the calculations, such as choosing an average momentum for the nucleons in the local Fermi gas, neglecting the exchange matrix elements, or reducing the number of integrations to two nested integrals by performing a non-relativistic expansion of the current operators.
6. In this work, the authors present a fast and efficient method to calculate the inclusive 2p-2h responses in the relativistic Fermi gas model (RFG) using the frozen nucleon approximation.
7. The frozen nucleon approximation was found to work properly in computing the phase space function for two-particle emission in the range of momentum transfers of interest for neutrino experiments with accelerators.
8. The authors investigate the validity of the frozen approximation beyond the phase-space study by including the electroweak meson-exchange current (MEC) model and find that the presence of virtual delta excitations requires the introduction of a "frozen" propagator, designed by a convenient average over the Fermi sea.

1. The accretion of gas onto a supermassive black hole (SMBH) in the nucleus of galaxies is believed to be the source of activity in quasars and Seyfert galaxies, also known as active galactic nuclei (AGNs). Several studies have suggested a correlation between the mass of the SMBH and the luminosity, mass, and velocity dispersion of the stellar spheroid of the galaxies. These correlations may imply an evolutionary relation between the growth of the SMBH and the host galaxy.
2. In order to study the dependence of the various observed phenomena of AGNs on the black hole mass and the cosmic evolution of the black holes, independent and reliable estimates of the mass of the black holes are required. One independent method to estimate the mass of the black hole is using the reverberation mapping technique. This technique involves measuring the time lag between variations in the continuum emission and the broad emission lines, which can be interpreted as the light travel time across the broad line region (BLR).
3. The reverberation mapping technique has been used to make estimates of SMBH masses over a large range of redshift. However, the technique is observationally taxing and has only been applied to about three dozen AGNs to date. Using these estimates, a correlation was found between the BLR radius and the optical continuum luminosity at 5100 Å. This relation can be useful for estimating the SMBH masses from single-epoch spectra and calibrating other surrogate relations used for black hole mass estimates.
4. The text presents the optical spectroscopic and photometric observations of a new low luminosity AGN, the X-ray source and Seyfert 1.5 galaxy H 0507 + 164. Based on a reverberation mapping campaign that lasted for about a month, the authors have obtained the BLR radius and estimated the mass of the SMBH.
5. The authors also discuss the need for estimates of the BLR radius for a larger number of sources, as the extrapolation of the known BLR-luminosity relation to low luminosities suggests that the time lag between the variations of the broad line and that of the continuum will be of the order of hours to days. This would require monitoring programs of short durations, but fast sampling, to estimate the reverberation time lags for low

1. Broad emission iron lines are common features in the spectra of active galactic nuclei and black hole binaries, and are thought to originate near the black hole due to radiation being reflected off the accretion disc.
2. The spin of the black hole affects the shape of the iron line, with higher spin values resulting in the innermost stable orbit being closer to the black hole.
3. The Laor model is a widely used model for relativistic disc spectral lines, and assumes a maximally rotating Kerr black hole. However, other models have been developed that allow for the spin to be fitted.
4. The Laor model can still be used to estimate the spin if the inner edge of the disc is identified with the marginally stable orbit.
5. The other parameters of relativistic line models include the inclination angle, rest energy of the line, inner and outer radii of the disc, and emissivity parameters.
6. The emissivity of the line is given by different laws for different regions of the disc, and the angular dependence of the emissivity is characterized by a limb darkening profile in the Laor model.
7. The paper compares the Laor model to another relativistic model when applied to data from the XMM-Newton satellite and artificially generated data for a future X-ray mission. The two sources chosen exhibit a skewed iron line and marginally stable orbit.
8. The Laor model has a less accurate grid and is limited to the extreme Kerr metric, which can result in discrepancies in the spin determination and energy resolution when applied to higher quality data.

1. Axially symmetric solutions of Einstein's field equations are used to model galaxies or accretion disks, and can be static or stationary with or without radial pressure.
2. Solutions for static disks without radial pressure were first studied by Bonnor and Sackfield, and Morgan and Morgan. Solutions with radial pressure were also studied by Morgan and Morgan.
3. Disks with radial tension, electric fields, magnetic fields, and both magnetic and electric fields have been considered.
4. Solutions for self-similar static disks were analyzed by Lynden-Bell and Pineault, and Lemos.
5. The superposition of static disks with black holes and static disks as sources of known vacuum spacetimes have been considered.
6. A simple method to generate these solutions is the "displace, cut and reflect" method, but the matter content of the disk is usually anisotropic.
7. In this article, the authors apply the "displace, cut and reflect" method on spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein's field equations in isotropic coordinates to generate static disks made of a perfect fluid, i.e., with radial pressure equal to tangential pressure.
8. They also generate disks of perfect fluid surrounded by an halo made of perfect fluid matter.
9. The article discusses the results and presents the basic equations used to calculate the main physical variables of the disks.

1. The text discusses the creation of two interpenetrating superfluids, specifically focusing on the use of binary Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) with two species of atoms. Research has been conducted to condense two different hyperfine spin states of the same atom in the same trap using sympathetic cooling. The dynamics of the complex relative motion of the condensates and the measurement of the relative phase between the two condensates have been studied. However, the two condensates do not completely interpenetrate each other in the stationary state. Theoretical investigation of two-component Bose systems has been carried out, and hartree-fock theory has been successfully tested on the two-component ^87Rb system. Stability, ground-state properties, and collective excitations have been studied using the Gross-Pitaevskii equations.
2. The text also discusses the effects of symmetry and symmetry breaking in two-component BECs. The quantum state of the binary Bose system is characterized by two phases of the two condensates, leading to a richer physics than that of usual one-component systems. When the coupling drive is on, only one u(1) symmetry remains exact, while the other one is explicitly violated. This leads to the possibility of a nontrivial static configuration, a domain wall inside which the relative phase changes by π. The domain wall is a local minimum of the energy but is not topologically stable, and its spontaneous decay is exponentially suppressed due to an energy barrier. The paper is organized into sections that introduce the field-theoretical description of binary BECs, describe the domain wall configuration, discuss the boundary of finite domain walls and the related phenomenon of "vortex confinement," and contain concluding remarks.

1. Quantum field theory may exhibit anomalies, which are violations of classical symmetries in the quantized version of a theory. External symmetry breakage is harmless but internal symmetry (gauge symmetry) breakage leads to inconsistencies in the quantum theory.
2. Gravitation, regarded as a gauge theory, also suffers from anomalies, such as Einstein anomalies, Lorentz anomalies, and Weyl anomalies, which can be calculated using various methods, including perturbation theory, heat kernel method, Fujikawa's path integral approach, and differential geometry and cohomology techniques.
3. Schwinger terms, which are additional terms in the canonical algebra of equal-time commutators, are deeply related to anomalies and can be calculated using similar methods. They are frequently calculated within perturbation theory and are cohomologically described by the Faddeev-Mickelsson cocycle.
4. The text discusses the calculation of gravitational anomalies, specifically the Einstein anomaly and the Weyl anomaly, using dispersion relations, a less familiar but useful approach. The authors show that all anomalous features are easily obtained by this method.
5. The authors extend the method of dispersion relations to the case of pure gravitation, considering chiral fermion loops coupled to gravitation and showing that the gravitational anomalies and the Schwinger terms are completely determined by dispersion relations.
6. The paper is organized into several sections, discussing the general structure of the amplitude, Ward identities, dispersion relations, the anomalous Ward identities, and the gravitational Schwinger terms.
7. The text also discusses the equivalence between the dispersive approach and the dimensional regularization procedure for calculating anomalies.

1. The STE-Quest mission is a medium-sized candidate for launch in 2022/2024 by the European Space Agency (ESA) to test Einstein's Equivalence Principle (EEP) by measuring the gravitational red-shift and testing the universality of free fall.
2. The mission comprises a space segment and a ground segment, connected by highly stable bi-directional microwave and optical links for precise time- and frequency transfer.
3. The space segment includes a satellite, two instruments (an atomic clock and an atom interferometer), science link equipment, and precise orbit determination equipment.
4. The ground segment consists of three ground terminals connected to highly accurate ground-clocks.
5. The atomic clock is a rebuilt of the high-precision PHARAO clock used in the ACES mission, with an optically derived microwave signal for short-term stability.
6. The atom interferometer uses interference between matter waves to generate a signal that depends on external forces acting on the atoms, and performs differential measurements to reject unwanted external noise sources.
7. The science links comprise optical and microwave time & frequency links to compare the on-board clock with distributed ground clocks and to compare distant ground clocks to one another.
8. The precise orbit determination equipment is required to determine the spacecraft position and velocity, which allows calculating theoretical predictions of the expected gravitational red-shifts and the relativistic doppler, and compare them to the measured ones.
9. The mission's baseline orbit is highly elliptical, with a typical perigee altitude of 700 km and an apogee altitude of 50,000 km, maximizing gravity gradients between apogee and perigee to achieve mission objective 1 (earth gravitational red-shift).

1. Pulsed high-frequency (HF) electromagnetic (EM) waves are used to sound the density profile and drift velocity of the overhead ionosphere. In 1971, it was theorized that strong enough injected HF radio beams could excite weak-turbulence parametric instabilities in the ionospheric plasma.
2. Ionospheric modification experiments in Platteville, Colorado, and Arecibo, Puerto Rico, demonstrated the heating of electrons, deformation in ionosonde records, excitation of spread F, and the triggering of weak-turbulence parametric instabilities in the ionosphere.
3. Numerical simulations have become an important tool to understand the complex behavior of plasma turbulence. A full-scale simulation study of the propagation of an HF EM wave into the ionosphere was conducted, which is the first simulation involving realistic scale sizes of the ionosphere and the wavelength of the EM waves.
4. In the simulation, an EM pulse propagates through the neutral atmosphere and undergoes Faraday rotation when it reaches the ionospheric layer. The initially linearly polarized EM wave is transformed into two high-frequency EM modes, l-o mode and r-x mode, with different dispersion properties.
5. The l-o mode oscillations at a specific altitude radiate EM waves with perpendicular electric field components. Weakly damped oscillations of the electric field component are observed, which are interpreted as electrostatic waves produced by mode conversion of the l-o mode.
6. The nonlinear effects at the turning point of the l-o and r-x modes are investigated, and large-amplitude pump wave, relatively weak second harmonics of the pump wave, and low-frequency oscillations are visible in the frequency spectrum. Mode conversion of the l-o mode into electrostatic langmuir/upper hybrid waves and nonlinear harmonic generation of the high-frequency waves are observed.

1. The Mott-Hubbard model of interacting bosons on a lattice has been used to describe superfluid-Mott insulator transitions in various systems, including Josephson arrays and granular superconductors. Recently, the transition has been observed and studied in a system of cold bosonic atoms in an optical lattice. The possibility to manipulate and test the many-body behavior of a system of trapped bosonic atoms in an optical lattice has attracted significant theoretical and experimental interest, with potential applications in quantum computation.
2. The quantum phase transition in the system is driven by the interplay of the repulsive interaction of bosons on the same lattice site and the kinetic energy. The ratio of the on-site energy and the bandwidth forms the key parameter in the system, which can be easily controlled and varied in optical lattices. Experimentally, the system can be probed by taking absorption pictures to image the expansion patterns after a reasonable expansion time, which provides information about the momentum distribution of the state.
3. The essential physics of cold bosonic atoms in an optical lattice is captured by a bosonic Mott-Hubbard model describing the competition between hopping and on-site interaction. Various approximation schemes, including the Gutzwiller mean-field ansatz, density-matrix renormalization group, exact diagonalization, and quantum Monte Carlo, have been used to study this model analytically and numerically.
4. In this article, the authors study the short-range correlations, which are not included in the Gutzwiller ansatz, by using perturbation theory. The main purpose is to find corrections to the short-range behavior of the one-particle density matrix, which is directly relevant to experimentally observed expansion patterns. These patterns are important for determining the location of the insulator-superfluid transition.
5. The authors note that their perturbative approach is identical to the one used in previous studies, although the goal was different, viz., studying corrections to the phase diagram. They present numerical results for local observables and the density matrix and discuss the implications for expansion patterns both for bulk systems and a harmonic confining potential.

1. Scalar fields arise naturally in higher-dimensional theories such as string or m-theory, and can lead to accelerating cosmologies. In particular, compactification on a compact hyperbolic manifold with a time-dependent volume modulus can result in a flat expanding universe with a transient period of accelerating expansion. This behavior is typical of compactifications involving compact hyperbolic spaces or non-vanishing flux.
2. The transient acceleration in these models can be explained by the positive scalar field potential that both hyperbolic and flux compactifications produce in the effective, lower-dimensional action. The critical point in the target space, where the potential vanishes, separates steep exponential potentials (which arise in flux compactifications) from gentle exponential potentials (which arise from hyperbolic compactification).
3. The paper aims to generalize the analysis of these models to the multi-scalar case and to determine the model-independent behavior and the genericity of the phenomenon of transient acceleration. The authors also develop a new formalism for visualizing cosmological solutions that applies to any potential and illustrate it with an application to exponential potentials.

1. The authors discovered a wide, common proper motion companion to the star HIP 115147, which they identified as LSPM J2322+7847.
2. They obtained new photometry of HIP 115

1. The universe is observed to be flat and dominated by dark energy, which is believed to be connected to particle physics. A dynamical model called MAVANs proposes that relic neutrinos could form a negative pressure fluid and cause cosmic acceleration through an unknown scalar field called "acceleron."
2. The neutrino mass is given by the acceleron and depends on its number density, changing with the evolution of the universe. The equation of state parameter and dark energy density also evolve with the neutrino mass, depending on the scalar potential model and the relation between the acceleron and neutrino mass.
3. The origin of the scalar potential for the acceleron is not discussed in many literatures, but it is clear in the supersymmetric MAVANs scenario. A work presents a model including the supersymmetry breaking effect mediated by gravity.
4. The basic assumption of the MAVANs with supersymmetry is to introduce a chiral superfield in the dark sector, which is assumed to be a singlet under the gauge group of the standard model. It is difficult to build a viable MAVANs model without fine-tunings in some parameters when one assumes one chiral superfield in the dark sector.
5. Therefore, it is assumed that the superfield couples to both the left-handed lepton doublet superfield and the right-handed neutrino superfield. The scalar component of the superfield is assumed to be the acceleron, which causes the present cosmic acceleration, and the spinor component is a sterile neutrino.
6. The lepton number conservation in the dark sector is violated in this scenario, leading to a variable neutrino mass. The finite mixing between the left-handed and a sterile neutrino makes the mass of the left-handed neutrino variable.
7. In the MAVANs scenario, there are two constraints on the scalar potential: the magnitude of the present dark energy density and the stationary condition with respect to the variation of the neutrino mass. The time evolution of the neutrino mass can be obtained from the stationary condition.

1. The quark-gluon plasma (QGP) is a phase of quantum chromodynamics where quarks and gluons are mostly liberated from hadrons. The study of QGP has been ongoing for about thirty years, with experiments at the Super Proton Synchrotron and Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider providing evidence for its formation. The QGP can also be created in the initial stage of the "little big bang" through relativistic nucleus-nucleus collisions in heavy ion accelerators. The critical temperature and baryon density for the transition to QGP have been calculated for non-interacting, massless up and down quarks and gluons, but a similar calculation with non-zero interaction has not been performed.
2. In this work, the authors generalize previous calculations for the region with finite temperature and baryon density by considering weakly interacting quarks in the framework of the one gluon exchange scheme. They use the MIT bag model to take into account the bag pressure and the excluded volume hadron pressure. The authors calculate the thermodynamic properties of the QGP and compare the results with strange quark matter. They find that the QGP equation of state is harder than that of strange quark matter at the same baryon density and temperature. The interaction between quarks inside the bag is repulsive, making it easier for the system to transition to the QGP phase. The authors also find that the internal and free energies of the QGP are larger than those of strange quark matter.

1. A conformally symmetric model for strong interactions at low energies was proposed in ref. [xcite], based on the observation that the dynamical equations of gauge theories retain their flat-space-time form when subject to a conformally-flat metrical field.
2. The model describes confinement of quarks and gluons through the introduction of two scalar fields that spontaneously break the symmetry down to subgroups.
3. A symmetric second-order tensor field is defined that serves as the metric for flat space-time, coupling to electromagnetism.
4. Quarks and gluons are confined to an anti-de Sitter (AdS) universe with a finite radius in the flat space-time.
5. The model describes quarks and gluons that oscillate with a universal frequency inside a closed universe, as well as photons which freely travel through flat space-time.
6. The model comprises one real scalar field and one complex scalar field. Their dynamical equations were solved in ref. [xcite] for the case that the respective vacuum expectation values satisfy a certain relation.
7. A solution for the real scalar field leads to AdS confinement, via the associated conformally flat metric.
8. Under the condition of the relation between the vacuum expectation values, one obtains a light real scalar field associated with confinement and a very heavy complex scalar field associated with electromagnetism.
9. Weak interactions were not contemplated in ref. [xcite], but the model can be extended to include them by replacing electromagnetism with electroweak interactions.
10. The model has been further simplified to compare its properties with measured cross sections and branching ratios, by coupling the AdS spectrum to the channels of hadronic decay products via light-quark-pair creation.

1. The term "stochastic resonance" was introduced in the early 1980s in the study of periodic advance of glaciers on earth. It refers to the effect of nonmonotone dependence of the response of a system on the noise when this noise is added to a periodic input signal.
2. The phenomenon of stochastic resonance is characterized by the improvement of signal transmission in terms of statistical quantities through the addition of noise. This is because the perturbed signal may become observable, allowing for inference to be made on the signal.
3. The optimal level of noise, at which the signal transmission is maximized, is called stochastic resonance. This level can be determined using criteria such as the Shannon mutual information or the Kullback divergence.
4. The paper studies the problem of estimation and hypotheses testing for a model with a threshold and a subthreshold constant and non-negative signal. A noise that is a trajectory of a diffusion process is added and the perturbed signal is observed in continuous time.
5. Two schemes of observations are proposed: observing the proportion of time spent by the perturbed signal over the threshold and measuring the energy of the perturbed signal when it is above the threshold. The asymptotic properties of estimators for these two schemes are studied.
6. The paper notes the presence of stochastic resonance in the context of hypotheses testing, where the overall probability of error is nonmonotonic dependent on the noise level.
7. The paper also derives the asymptotic variance of the estimator and shows that it is asymptotically efficient in the sense of achieving the minimax asymptotic lower bound for the quadratic risk associated with the estimation of the signal.

1. High-temperature superconductors (HTS) have been found to have mainly d-wave pairing symmetry, with a predominant d-gap symmetry up to the superconducting critical temperature. This symmetry has been confirmed through try-crystal phase-sensitive measurements and thermal transport measurements. However, above a certain temperature (k), no direct evidence for this type of symmetry has been published.
2. The symmetry of the order parameter and the interaction between quasiparticles, supercurrents (vortices), and the thermal conductivity depend on the temperature and angle between the heat current and the magnetic field applied parallel to the CuO planes. At low temperatures, the nodal characteristics of the gap are directly observable by thermal conductivity, but as the temperature increases, thermal activation of quasiparticles reduces the sensitivity of the probe to measure gap characteristics.
3. A field-cooled procedure is used to rule out the influence of pinning of vortices, which is affected by the distribution of oxygen vacancies, defects, and impurity centers. The longitudinal thermal conductivity as a function of temperature in both crystals at zero magnetic field provides qualitative information about the quality of the sample.
4. The angular patterns of the longitudinal thermal conductivity at different temperatures for the twinned and untwinned crystals show a fourfold oscillation in the longitudinal thermal conductivity as the field is rotated from one direction to another. The phononic contribution to the total thermal conductivity is constant under variations of the magnetic field orientations, and the electronic contribution is entirely responsible for the magnetic field dependence. The variation of the thermal conductivity can be explained with a model involving a Doppler shift in the energy spectrum of the quasiparticles along with an accurate inclusion of the impurity scattering and/or assuming Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices.

1. The paper discusses the cosmetic surgery conjecture, which suggests that two surgeries on inequivalent slopes of a knot in a three-sphere are never purely cosmetic, meaning they result in the same oriented manifolds. The authors focus on purely cosmetic surgeries along knots in the three-sphere. They show that for most knots in the three-sphere, distinct slopes result in non-homeomorphic oriented manifolds. A knot invariant called @xmath30, which satisfies a crossing change formula, plays a crucial role in their study.
2. The authors prove that @xmath30 is equal to @xmath31, another knot invariant, and show that it is a finite type invariant of order @xmath5. They also derive an explicit closed formula for the canonically normalized finite type knot invariant of order 3 for two-bridge knots in Conway forms.
3. The paper includes results about purely cosmetic surgery from previous works, such as Proposition 5.1 and Theorem 1.2, which provide conditions for purely cosmetic surgery to occur. The authors introduce a new invariant, @xmath34, which is the degree @xmath83 part of the Kontsevich-Kuperberg-Thurston invariant of rational homology spheres. This invariant is universal among finite type invariants for homology spheres.
4. The authors prove the surgery formula for @xmath34, which plays a central role in their main result. They apply this formula to show that if a knot in the three-sphere with non-zero integers @xmath120 and @xmath121 satisfies @xmath122, then the knot admits purely cosmetic surgeries if and only if @xmath123.
5. The authors derive an explicit formula for @xmath87 and use it to study the cosmetic surgery problem for two-bridge knots. They show that if a two-bridge knot has the finite type invariant @xmath140 or @xmath141, then it does not admit purely cosmetic surgeries for any two distinct slopes. They also study the cosmetic surgery problem for the family of two-bridge knots @xmath196 and prove that it does not admit purely cosmetic surgeries.

1. Anomaly-Mediated Supersymmetry Breaking (AMSB) models have attracted attention due to their attractive properties, such as calculable soft supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking terms and real, flavor-invariant soft terms. However, AMSB models have the problem of negative slepton mass-squared parameters, which can be solved by adding a universal scalar mass to the AMSB soft SUSY breaking terms. The parameter space of the "minimal" AMSB model (mAMSB) is given by $m_0, m_{3/2},$ and sign($\mu$).
2. An alternative set-up for AMSB is Hypercharged Anomaly Mediation (HCAMSB), a string-motivated scenario that uses a similar setup as AMSB. In HCAMSB, SUSY breaking is localized at the bottom of a strongly warped hidden region, and the warping suppresses contributions due to tree-level gravity mediation. The anomaly mediation can become the dominant source of SUSY breaking in the visible sector.
3. In the mSSM, the bino gaugino mass can be the only soft SUSY breaking parameter not determined by anomaly mediation. The bino mass can lead to a small perturbation to the spectrum of anomaly mediation or it can be the largest soft SUSY breaking parameter in the visible sector. The effect of the bino mass on other soft SUSY breaking parameters can dominate the contribution from anomaly mediation.
4. The minimal AMSB model predicts a negative mass squared for the sleptons, while the pure hypercharge mediation suffers from negative squared masses for stops and sbottoms. The combination of hypercharge and anomaly mediation leads to phenomenologically viable spectra for a sizable range of relative contributions.
5. The hcamsb ssb contribution is parametrized using a dimensionless quantity $c_{m_0}$, which governs the size of the hypercharge contribution to soft terms relative to the AMSB contribution. The parameter space of hcamsb models is given by $m_{3/2}, c_{m_0},$ and sign($\mu$).

1. The text discusses the use of the Zero Range Potential (ZRP) approach in quantum mechanics, which allows for the exact solution of scattering problems. The ZRP can be represented as a boundary condition on the wavefunction or as a pseudopotential. Darboux transformations (DT) can be used to construct exactly solvable potentials and to modify the generalized ZRP (GZRP) boundary condition, creating a potential with arbitrarily disposed discrete spectrum levels for any angular momentum.
2. The DT technique can be used to correct the ZRP model by dressing the ZRP to improve its possibilities. This involves modifying the GZRP boundary condition and creating a potential with short-range core interactions that depend on the angular momentum. The dressed potential can be used to build a zero-range potential eigenfunction in the multi-center problem.
3. The text also discusses the use of ZRPs in the study of slow electron scattering by polyatomic molecules. The partial and integral cross sections can be expressed in terms of the phases of the scattered waves, which can be classified with respect to symmetry group representation. The phases can be found from the compatibility condition of a system of equations, which can be factorized to obtain the phases of regular structures such as a tetrahedron.
4. The ZRP model has limitations, such as the neglect of polarization effects at low impact energies. However, these effects can be accounted for by dressing the ZRPs, which can correct the computed phases and integral cross sections. The DT can also be used to improve the agreement between the calculated and experimental results at higher collision energies by taking into account higher partial waves.

1. The convection-diffusion equation is a type of partial differential equation that has remarkable applications in various branches of science and engineering. It has been solved numerically using various techniques, including finite element method, lattice boltzmann method, finite-difference scheme, and higher-order compact finite difference schemes.
2. Researchers have proposed different numerical schemes to solve the convection-diffusion equation, such as the nine-point high-order compact implicit scheme by Noye and Tan, which is third-order accurate in space and second-order accurate in time. Another scheme is the fourth-order compact finite difference unconditionally stable scheme by Dehghan and Mohebbi, which has the accuracy of order 4.
3. The text also discusses the differential quadrature method (DQM), which is an approximation to derivatives of a function as the weighted sum of the functional values at certain nodes. The weighting coefficients of the derivatives depend only on grids. The DQM has been used to solve the convection-diffusion equation with new sets of modified cubic b-splines as base functions.
4. The accuracy and adaptability of the method are illustrated by three test problems of two-dimensional convection-diffusion equations. The resulting system of ODEs can be solved by using various time integration algorithms, such as the SSP-RK54 scheme, which results in less accumulation errors.

1. Surveys using bolometer arrays at millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths have discovered dusty objects at extreme redshifts, which are not detected in surveys at shorter and longer wavelengths due to obscuration and unfavorable @xmath11 corrections. These "scuba galaxies" have significantly changed the understanding of galaxy formation and evolution.
2. Early efforts to study scuba galaxies at optical and infrared wavelengths were met with difficulty, as many of these galaxies had no plausible optical counterparts. This led to the development of various redshift engines and broadband photometric techniques. However, only a handful of detailed studies were attempted, often for extreme and possibly unrepresentative galaxies.
3. Recent progress has been made through radio imaging of submillimeter survey fields, which has allowed for the detection and identification of many submillimeter galaxies (SMGs). These bright SMGs have been found to be a diverse population, including quasar-like galaxies, morphologically complex galaxies, extremely red galaxies, and galaxies with obscured active nuclei and/or superwinds.
4. Spectroscopic redshifts for SMGs have been difficult to determine, but accurate redshifts reported by Chapman et al. (2003, 2005) have facilitated the first systematic measurements of molecular gas mass and constraints on gas reservoir size and dynamical mass for SMGs. These data suggest that SMGs are massive systems and provide some of the strongest tests of galaxy-formation models to date. However, a detailed understanding of SMGs remains a distant goal, and confusion and selection biases may have skewed our understanding of this population.

1. The text discusses the use of multi-object spectrographs on 4m-class telescopes to construct large samples of faint galaxies with measured redshifts, allowing for the computation of the luminosity function (LF) of galaxies as a function of redshift and the observation of the evolution of the galaxy population.
2. Several deep, faint galaxy redshift surveys have been conducted, and while there is broad agreement that the population of blue, star-forming galaxies has evolved strongly since z~1, the population of red galaxies shows at most modest signs of evolution. However, there are inconsistencies in the LFs derived by different groups, which may be due to small sample sizes, small survey areas, and systematic errors.
3. The local LF also has considerable uncertainties, with different surveys having similar shapes but substantial differences in overall normalization, characteristic luminosity, and faint-end slope. A steep faint-end slope is a natural prediction of galaxy formation theories based on hierarchical structure formation models, but there is only weak evidence for this in the local field galaxy LF.
4. The paper presents the results of a redshift survey of the Corona Borealis supercluster, which was originally planned to study the dynamics of the supercluster but also provides a sample suitable for studying the evolution of the LF. The survey finds that the LF of field galaxies and the two superclusters are different, and that the supercluster LFs do not continue the exponential decline for galaxies brighter than M* (the characteristic magnitude).
5. The paper also discusses the potential impact of environmental effects on the LF, with superclusters containing a population of very luminous galaxies that are not present in the field LF. These galaxies are found in the densest regions of the superclusters and are dominated by the light of an old, red stellar population.

1. Rapidity gaps, which are regions in pseudorapidity without hadronic activity, have been observed in hadronic collisions at HERA and the Tevatron. These gaps are attributed to the exchange of color singlet quanta between incident partons.
2. At the Tevatron, a fraction of dijet events with jet transverse energies above 100 Gev and jet separations of more than three units of pseudorapidity exhibit rapidity gaps between the jets. This observation suggests that color singlet exchange effects in QCD events are relevant at momentum transfers of order 1,000 Gev.
3. Bjorken predicted a gap fraction of order one percent, in terms of a fraction of dijet events due to color-singlet exchange and a survival probability of rapidity gaps of order 10%. The survival probability estimates the fraction of hard dijet events without an underlying event.
4. The two-gluon exchange model, which is a model for the calculation of the color singlet fraction, with the two gluon-exchange amplitude replaced by its imaginary part, is used to estimate the color-singlet fraction. In this model, the color singlet fraction grows with the color charge of the scattered partons.
5. Measurements by the CDF and D0 collaborations at the Tevatron show no significant decrease in the gap fraction as the contribution from gluon-induced dijet events is reduced. In fact, the D0 data are compatible with a slight increase of the gap fraction with increasing jet transverse momentum.
6. The two-gluon exchange model is found to be incompatible with unitarity, and phase shift unitarization leads to a more realistic description with color singlet exchange fractions that differ substantially from the expectations of the two-gluon exchange model.
7. The predicted color singlet fractions are found to strongly depend on the regularization of gluon exchange at small momentum transfer, and within the unitarized model, the non-perturbative effects can be summarized in terms of two parameters, the survival probability of gaps and a universal Coulomb phase shift.
8. The gap fraction between two hard jets varies with jet transverse energies and jet pseudorapidity separation, and the predicted fractions are compared with Tevatron data. The conclusions are given in section [

1. Forecasting electric energy consumption is important for managing power systems and maximizing consumer satisfaction. It has also been used for system security purposes to detect vulnerabilities in advance. Factors such as historical load, temperature, humidity, population, and GDP per capita can affect energy consumption. In the Gaza strip, energy demand has grown rapidly, with 75% of demands coming from service and household sectors.
2. Several algorithms have been proposed to tackle the electric energy consumption forecasting problem. These can be grouped into three approaches: time series, functional based, and soft computing based. Time series approach predicts future consumption based on past consumption patterns but can be inaccurate and not utilize weather information. Functional based approach models the relationship between weather and energy consumption, while soft computing based approach uses techniques such as fuzzy logic, genetic algorithm, and artificial neural networks (ANN) to predict energy consumption.
3. ANN is a system based on the working principles of biological neural networks and is useful in predicting future trends with reliance on past data. ANN systems have been designed for fields such as capacity planning, business intelligence, pattern recognition, and robotics. In computer science and engineering, ANN techniques have gained a lot of grounds and are vastly deployed in areas such as forecasting, data analytics, and even data mining.
4. In this study, historical monthly data from 1994 to 2013 was gathered from the Gaza region to develop a forecast model that predicts energy consumption for 2012 and 2013. ANN technique was used for training and learning procedures, which are fundamental in forecasting future events. The training of feed-forward networks is usually carried out in a supervised manner, and the learning process involves providing both input and output data, with the network processing the input and comparing the resulting output with the desired result.
5. The performance of the ANN model was evaluated using the mean squared error (MSE), root mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) criteria. The results obtained have good accuracy and show that the proposed ANN model can be used to predict future trends of electric energy consumption in Gaza.

1. Low mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs) are compact binaries where a compact object, such as a neutron star or black hole, is orbited by a low mass star. The secondary star transfers mass to the compact object via Roche-lobe overflow, forming an accretion disk that emits X-rays.
2. Most persistently bright LMXBs are neutron star systems, which can be divided into two groups: Z sources and atoll sources. Z sources are usually the brightest LMXBs in X-rays and have high accretion rates, while atoll sources have lower accretion rates and their X-ray color-color diagrams consist of fragmented island-like regions.
3. The main physical difference between Z sources and atoll sources is thought to be the strength of the neutron star magnetic field and their evolutionary history.
4. LMCX-2 is a persistent LMXB located in the Large Magellanic Cloud that shows the properties of a Z source, indicating that it is a neutron star system with an accretion rate around the Eddington limit.
5. Despite being X-ray luminous and having a known optical counterpart, little is known about the system parameters of LMCX-2. The estimates for the orbital period range from 6.4 hours to 12 days.
6. A new technique using phase-resolved spectroscopy has been developed to detect a signature of the donor star in persistent LMXBs. This technique has been used to detect narrow emission lines in several LMXBs, leading to constraints on their system parameters.
7. The authors of this paper applied the technique of Bowen fluorescence to LMCX-2 and detected a periodic signal in their spectroscopic dataset that they identify as the orbital period. They also detected narrow emission lines in the Bowen region, which they identify as coming from the irradiated side of the companion star.
8. The authors obtained a total of 77 spectra of LMCX-2 using the FORS2 spectrograph attached to the VLT unit 4 at Paranal Observatory. They de-biased, flat-fielded, and optimally extracted the spectra to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio.
9. The authors determined the pixel-to-wavelength

1. The axial anomaly, a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, has been analyzed using the renormalization procedure and the path integral formalism. An alternative approach by Dolgov and Zakharov interprets the anomaly as an infrared phenomenon, originating from a singularity in the chiral limit of the triangular diagram's absorbitive part. This infrared interpretation complements the more familiar ultraviolet interpretation from the renormalization procedure.
2. The Dolgov and Zakharov approach has been related to specific effects in physical reactions, such as polarized radiative decays of particles. The authors calculate decay rates for these processes, considering mass singularities and their cancellation, and discuss the kinoshita-lee-nauenberg theorem's implications. The work also highlights the importance of the axial anomaly in interpreting spin-dependent parton distribution.

1. The text discusses the problem of salient object detection in computer vision, which involves selecting and segmenting the most important object in a scene.
2. This problem has attracted a lot of interest in the computer vision community due to its potential applications in various areas such as recognition, image and video compression, video summarization, and human-robot interaction.
3. A large number of saliency detection methods have been proposed in the past 7 years, which typically involve two steps: selecting objects to process and segmenting the object area.
4. However, current models have mostly focused on scenes with single objects and performed well on biased datasets with low-clutter images and often a single object at the center.
5. The text aims to address the lack of suitable benchmark datasets and a widely-agreed objective definition of the most salient object for complex, cluttered scenes.
6. The text also discusses related topics to visual saliency modeling and salient object detection, including object importance, object proposal generation, memorability, scene clutter, image interestingness, video interestingness, surprise, image quality assessment, scene typicality, aesthetic, and attributes.
7. The text mentions some breakthrough efforts in saliency detection, such as using a conditional random field (CRF) framework, subtracting the average color from the low-pass filtered input, incorporating global context using a patch-based approach, and using a region contrast-based method.
8. The text also discusses the relationship between fixations and saliency judgments, and how human observers choose to annotate salient objects or regions in free-viewing tasks.
9. The text concludes by highlighting the need for more versatile datasets and remedying biases in salient object datasets, and situating the field of salient object detection among other similar fields such as general object detection and segmentation, objectness proposal generation models, and saliency models for fixation prediction.

1. Heegaard Floer theory is a decorated topological quantum field theory (TQFT) in 2 dimensions, constructed by Ozsváth and Szabó. It associates a vector space to a closed, connected, oriented 3-manifold and a map to a connected, oriented 4-dimensional cobordism decorated with a 2-structure.
2. The maps associated with cobordisms can be used to detect exotic smooth structures on 4-manifolds with boundary. For example, two homeomorphic but not diffeomorphic 4-manifolds can be obtained by performing a log transform with odd multiplicity on a regular fiber of the nucleus of an elliptic surface.
3. The original definitions of the vector spaces and maps in Heegaard Floer theory involved counting pseudoholomorphic disks and triangles in symmetric products of Riemann surfaces, with the Riemann surfaces related to the 3-manifolds and cobordisms involved via Heegaard diagrams.
4. Sarkar and the third author showed that every 3-manifold admits a Heegaard diagram that is nice in the sense that the curves split the diagram into elementary domains, all but one of which are bigons or rectangles. Using such a diagram, holomorphic disks in the symmetric product can be counted combinatorially, leading to a combinatorial description of the Heegaard Floer homology of any 3-manifold and null homologous knots and links in any 3-manifold.
5. The goal of the paper is to give a combinatorial procedure for calculating the ranks of the maps associated with cobordisms between 3-manifolds with the property that the induced maps on the Heegaard Floer groups are surjective. This includes all cobordisms for which the torsion is trivial and all those consisting of only 2-handle additions.
6. The computation of the ranks of the maps goes as follows: the cobordism is decomposed into a sequence of one-handle additions, two-handle additions, and three-handle additions. Using the homological hypotheses on the cobordism and the τ-action on the Heegaard Floer groups, the problem is reduced to the case of a cobordism map corresponding to two-handle additions only. Then

1. The paper extends the results of Yetter, Gerstenhaber, and Gerstenhaber and Schack on the infinitesimal deformation theory of associative algebras and poset-indexed diagrams of associative algebras to a deformation theory for arbitrary pasting diagrams of $\mathcal{C}$-linear categories, functors, and natural transformations. It establishes that obstructions are cocycles for deformation complexes of pasting diagrams in general, and considers deformations of pasting diagrams in which specified functors or natural transformations are required to be deformed trivially. The paper also addresses a point overlooked in previous theorems regarding the dependence of cochain maps on choices of association for 2-dimensional compositions.
2. The paper describes chain maps induced by pasting compositions on the full deformation complexes, when $\mathcal{D}$ is a composable pasting diagram. It constructs two chain maps for functors, and two more for natural transformations. It also gives a cochain map that ties together all of the deformations when a natural transformation, its source and target, and their common source and target are deformed simultaneously.
3. The paper uses the cochain maps of the previous section to give explicit examples of deformation complexes associated to various shapes of commutative pasting diagrams. It shows that cochain maps induced by two different associations of the 2-dimensional composition are not actually equal, but only chain homotopic. It also discusses the effect of compositions of 2-arrows and the iterative cone construction in the deformation complex of the pasting diagram. The paper leaves zero entries in matrices of maps giving coboundaries blank for improved readability.

1. The text discusses the importance of understanding the physical picture behind observable phenomena in physics, rather than just calculating numbers. It highlights the need to select essential degrees of freedom in a theory, using the example of electric conductivity and heat capacity in crystals, which are explained by "heavy electrons" with dynamical mass, phonons, and their interactions.
2. The author then connects this concept to QCD, explaining that the full nonquenched QCD on a lattice is hoped to solve the problem of obtaining correct nucleon and pion masses in terms of underlying degrees of freedom. However, QCD at the scale of 1 GeV becomes too complicated, making it difficult to determine the relevant physics for the nucleon mass and its low-energy properties.
3. The author argues that spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry is the most important QCD phenomenon for understanding the nucleon mass and its low-energy properties. Beyond the scale of spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry, light and strange baryons can be viewed as systems of three constituent quarks that interact through the exchange of Goldstone bosons (pseudoscalar mesons), vector and scalar mesons, and are subject to confinement.
4. At low temperatures and densities, the chiral symmetry of the QCD Lagrangian is spontaneously broken down to a subgroup by the QCD vacuum. A nonzero value of quark condensates for light flavors represents the order parameter for spontaneously broken chiral symmetry.
5. Spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry has two important generic consequences: the appearance of an octet of pseudoscalar mesons of low mass, which represent the associated approximate Goldstone bosons, and the acquisition of a dynamical mass by valence (practically massless) quarks, known as constituent quarks.
6. Constituent quarks should be considered as quasiparticles with a dynamical mass generated by nonperturbative gluon and quark-antiquark dressing. The flavor-octet axial current conservation in the chiral limit implies that the constituent quarks and Goldstone bosons should be coupled with a strength that satisfies the constituent quark analog of the famous Goldberger-Treiman relation.
7. The author acknowledges that the microscopic mechanism for spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry in QCD

1. The text describes a calcium phosphate-coated implantable medical device that minimizes immune response and stores and releases one or more medicinally active agents. The calcium phosphate coating is made through a unique process that involves the application of a thin polymer film coating impregnated with medically active agents such as antibiotics, anti-inflammatory agents, and other drugs. The coating is flexible and non-thrombogenic, and the release of the drugs from the coating is aided by the dissolution of the carrier film.
2. The text also discusses the use of calcium phosphate materials, such as hydroxyapatite (HA), as a coating for implantable medical devices. These materials are fully bio-compatible and bio-resorbable, and they offer new perspectives for coating-based drug encapsulation and delivery systems. The use of HA coatings has been limited due to their brittle behavior, but the text describes a method of biomimetic deposition of HA films at room temperature (BM-HA) that can be used for drug delivery. This method proceeds at or near room temperature and allows for the incorporation of biologically active species, such as antibiotics and anti-cancer drugs, into the apatitic crystals that form through nucleation and growth. The deposition rates for BM-HA are in the range of 0.05-0.5 μm/h.

1. The present invention is related to nerve regeneration, specifically to nerve conduits for the regeneration of peripheral nerves.
2. Current treatments for peripheral nerve injuries include end-to-end suturing and autograft or allograft biological tissue, but both have limitations.
3. Tissue engineering and biomaterials suggest that biomaterials can be used to produce natural or synthetic nerve guidance conduits (NGCs) that can overcome the limitations of natural tissue methods.
4. FDA-approved tissue engineered nerve devices have been available for several years, but they do not possess the proper physical topography or chemical cues for nerve repair and regeneration and are currently limited to a critical nerve gap of approximately 4 cm.
5. The invention provides a fabricated implantable NGC with an inner spiral structured porous sheet, which can serve as a medical device to treat PNI and restore function to the site of the injury.
6. The spiral structure facilitates regeneration of nerve tissues, and the chambers at the proximal and distal ends of the conduit allow for nerve stumps to be sutured without tension.
7. The spiral conduit is tunable such that its length and diameter can be varied controllably depending on how it is to be used.
8. The invention also provides a process for fabricating an implantable NGC, which can be used as a medical device for facilitating the repair and regeneration of nerve tissues.
9. The NGC of the present invention comprises a three-dimensional (3-D) spiral structured porous sheet having two chambers at the ends thereof, a highly porous PCL sheet, a thin layer of aligned electrospun fibers on the surface channels, and a dense randomly-oriented fibrous tube on the outside of the NGC.
10. The NGC provides superior mechanical strength compared to NGCs in the prior art, along with integrated multiple channels, stable aligned fibrous layers, good inter-cell communication, and high surface/volume ratios within the NGCs.

1. The invention relates to seat base support assemblies, particularly those using sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, or flexible steel bands.
2. The background of the invention describes the shift in the furniture industry towards thicker cushions and lower seat frame heights, requiring more upward resilience in the spring base.
3. The invention aims to provide a new and improved rail connector for various types of seat base support assemblies.
4. The first form of the rail connector uses a pre-stressed, close-wound coil spring with attachment arms, which can be wound on a transverse or longitudinal axis and have a leverage-amplified torsioning capability.
5. The second form of the rail connector uses a pre-stressed, cantilever spring configuration, which can be used with a sinuous spring band having leverage-amplified torsioning incorporated.
6. The invention combines four essential seat-force-generators, producing the four most desired seat-performance characteristics.
7. The text describes various modifications and configurations of the first and second forms of the rail connector.
8. FIGS. 1-5 illustrate the first form of the rail connector, while FIGS. 6-9 illustrate the second form of the rail connector.
9. The connectors can also be used to connect other forms of seat base support means to the frame rails, providing dynamic uplift.
10. The invention can be modified and improved while still falling within the true spirit and scope of the invention.

1. The text describes an anvil assembly for use with a surgical stapling device, specifically a circular surgical stapling device. The anvil assembly includes a stabilizing collet positioned to prevent damage to the anvil assembly during attachment to the stapling device.
2. The anvil assembly includes an anvil shaft with a proximal portion having a plurality of flexible legs that define a first longitudinal bore, and a distal portion with an anvil head assembly that supports an anvil plate with staple deforming pockets. The stabilizing collet defines a second longitudinal bore and is supported within the first longitudinal bore to prevent damage to the flexible legs.
3. The collet is cylindrical and substantially rigid, with a distal end having a plurality of cantilevered fingers, each with a protrusion that secures the collet within the first longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft. Each flexible leg defines a longitudinal channel with an adjacent leg, and the anvil shaft defines a hole adjacent the distal end of each longitudinal channel to receive the protrusions. The anvil head assembly is pivotally secured to the anvil shaft, and the anvil plate is annular.

1. The invention is related to a container of a blender with a set of high-speed blades inside the lower portion.
2. Early blender containers were made of glass, but reinforced plastic was later used due to its light weight, cost efficiency, durability, and rigidity.
3. However, reinforced plastic containers can develop nicks over time, leading to debris mixing into the liquid and causing poor hygiene.
