2. The electrical cord support keeps the cord above the ironing surface and includes a flexible cord support and a clamp to secure it to the ironing board.
3. The flexible cord support has a first rod with a cord receiving end, a resilient spring section, and a second rod with an upper end to detachably receive the spring section.
4. The clamp has a "C" shape with a pair of leg portions, one for engaging the ironing surface and the other for securing the apparatus to the ironing board.
5. The article holder is mounted to the clamp and has a pair of tangs detachably received by openings in a mounting brace.
6. The electrical cord support can be moved between a raised position and a retracted position for storage.
7. The article holder can be removed from the ironing board when not in use.
8. The invention also includes an electrical receptacle for receiving the plug of the electrical cord.

1. The invention is a buttonhole controlling device for a sewing machine that forms buttonholes of a selected length without overlap, regardless of the type of material being sewn.
2. The device includes a foot pad attached to a presser bar, and a travelling assembly with a slidable member that can be positioned by a button for which a buttonhole is to be sewn.
3. The slidable member has a tab that actuates a tripping lever on the machine during movement of the assembly, limiting the length of the buttonhole.
4. An adjustable stop on the travelling assembly engages the tripping lever to terminate the formation of the buttonhole, preventing open or overlapping buttonholes.
5. The device controls the operation of the tripping lever, which in turn controls the sewing machine to form buttonholes with top and bottom bar stitches and left and right leg zig-zag stitches.
6. The length of the buttonhole can be adjusted by positioning the button between the "V" notches in the anchor element and gaging element of the shoe.
7. The device can be fine-tuned by adjusting the screw of the adjustable stop to compensate for possible slippage in different materials.

1. The text describes an apparatus for treating a dyed or printed textile web with a liquid, such as a washing or rinsing solution.
2. The apparatus includes a conveyor (endless sieve belt) for transporting the textile web along a predetermined horizontal path, a liquid applicator (spray pipe) for applying the liquid to the web during motion, a suction device for removing the liquid from the web, and a dwell stretch for conducting the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop.
3. The dwell stretch lengthens the action time of the applied liquid on the substances to be removed from the fabric or textile web, allowing for a more thorough washing or rinsing effect.
4. The apparatus is especially advantageous for printed material, as it allows for effective washing without soiling a white background.
5. The dwell stretch device can be formed by an air pass, wherein the textile web is completely free of support or guiding elements at least along major portions of the dwell stretch or loop and is accessible to the atmosphere at all sides.
6. An alternative embodiment of the dwell stretch includes at least one freely rotatable drum disposed above the upper section of the sieve belt, with the dwell loop extending around the drum and at least two rollers disposed laterally adjacent to one another below the drum for guiding the web to and from the drum.
7. The apparatus can have a compact construction and can cause the textile web to adhere to the belt and be entrained thereby, allowing for guidance over several rollers or drums without appreciable longitudinal tensile stresses.

1. The dry cleaning machine of the present invention includes a separate intake fan and duct to bring ambient air into the access opening whenever the door is opened, reducing the exhaust of residual solvent vapors from the tubs.
2. The system includes a normally closed valve that isolates the intake system from the solvent vapors during normal operation, and opens to draw air into the interposed duct when the door is opened.
3. The machine includes a pair of nested tubs, a drive motor, a pump for pumping solvent into the tubs, a blower for circulating heated air through the tubs, and a refrigeration system for solvent vapor recovery.
4. The solvent flow system includes a recirculation path that filters the solvent from the storage tank through the filters, into the tubs, through the button trap, and back to the tank.
5. The air flow system includes a header chamber attached to the outer tub, and a pair of airflow hoses attached to the header chamber. Electrically energized one-way valves control the flow through these hoses.
6. During the spin cycle, valves 90 and 94 are closed to prevent air circulation through the air distributing system, reducing the undesirable phenomena of "streaks and swales" in the clothes.
7. During the drying portion of the cycle, valves 90 and 94 are opened to allow the air and vapor mixture to exit the tubs and flow through the condenser housing, where the solvent vapor is condensed and returned to the storage tank.

1. The text describes a method and apparatus for forming a melt spun nonwoven web using a two-dimensional slot across the entire machine width, which produces a linear plane of filaments with substantially constant filament distribution. This design provides good control of cross-machine uniformity and is simpler than both eductive and non-eductive systems.
2. The system uses the same air for quenching and drawing the filaments, and the drawing chamber is relatively small with no nozzle length parallel to the fiber/air stream, allowing for higher quench pressures without structural deflection problems. The small amount of machined surface area exposed to the fiber stream collects less dirt and is easier to clean than other systems.
3. The necessary drawing tension is obtained by selecting a suitable slot gap opening, and filament cooling is controlled by regulating the temperature of the quench fluid and controlling the rate of flow of air past the filaments to exhaust ports near the top of the quench chamber.
4. The invention has advantages over prior art systems, including more efficient energy consumption, improved machine element cleanliness, better web uniformity, lower capital costs, and easier process control. The system can also accommodate a wide variety of materials and operating conditions.

1. The text describes embodiments of a sewing machine, an embroidery unit, and a non-transitory computer-readable medium storing a sewing machine control program that allow for easily setting a position on a work cloth for sewing.
2. The sewing machine includes at least one detecting portion, a processor, and a memory. The detecting portion detects an ultrasonic wave transmitted from a transmission source, the processor identifies the position of the transmission source based on the detected ultrasonic wave, and the memory stores computer-readable instructions for executing these steps.
3. The embroidery unit can be attached to and detached from a bed of a sewing machine and includes at least one detecting portion and a notifying portion. The detecting portion detects an ultrasonic wave transmitted from a transmission source, and the notifying portion notifies the sewing machine of the detection timing. The embroidery unit moves the work cloth based on the position of the transmission source identified by the sewing machine.
4. The non-transitory computer-readable medium stores a control program that causes a sewing machine to identify the position of a transmission source of an ultrasonic wave based on information pertaining to the ultrasonic wave detected by at least one detecting portion of the sewing machine, and to control sewing based on the identified position.
5. The sewing machine can receive (detect) an ultrasonic wave transmitted from an ultrasonic pen using receivers and identify a specified position on the work cloth based on the detected ultrasonic wave.
6. The sewing machine can calculate the specified coordinates E (Xe, Ye, Ze) of the specified position on the work cloth using the distances EB and EC, which are calculated based on the propagation times Tb and Tc of the ultrasonic wave.
7. The receivers should be positioned to satisfy certain conditions to accurately identify the specified position, such as being unlikely to be obstructed, being separated from each other, having a large distance from the needle hole, not having an extremely large distance from the needle hole, and being provided above the top surface of the bed.

1. The invention relates to preparations for application onto cellulosic fabric or textile materials, such as cotton or linen, to enhance their utility. The preparations comprise a blended mixture of wool particles or wool powder and a binding agent, with the functional additive carried by the wool particles.
2. The use of ultrafine wool fibers as carriers for functional additives has shown exceptional additive-carrying and retention ability, enhancing the durability of functional enhancements of a cellulosic fabric material.
3. Another aspect of the invention involves a preparation for application onto a cellulosic fabric material comprising a mixture of powdered bamboo fibre, carrier agents, and binding agents. The non-charcoal fibrous bamboo powder is preferably nano-sized, with a particle size of 1 μm or below.
4. A method of preparing a preparation for application onto a cellulosic fabric material comprising wool as a functional additive carrier is also provided, involving pulverizing wool to obtain ultrafine wool powder of macrofibril size and forming an ultrafine wool suspension.
5. The functional additive may include additives for ultraviolet protection, anti-bacteria, or other clothing functions. The wool particles or wool powder may have a size of 200 nm or below and a helix or helical structure capable of carrying the functional additives.
6. The functional additive may comprise an anti-UV (ultraviolet light) agent, such as zinc oxide or titanium oxide, or anti-bacterial agents such as nano-silver, zinc oxide, titanium oxide, or non-charcoal bamboo powder.
7. The cellulosic fabric material, such as a fabric material made of cotton or linen, may be applied, bonded, or deposited with a preparation of any of the preparations.
8. The preparation may be bonded to or deposited onto the cellulosic fabric by printing, padding, or foam application.
9. The method of preparing a preparation comprising bamboo fibre as a functional additive involves pulverizing bamboo fibre to obtain coarse bamboo powder, adding a wetting agent and bamboo powder into water to form a suspension, and pulverizing the coarse bamboo

1. The present invention is a frame quilting machine that includes a large metal frame, a sewing machine head, and a computer-controlled system for moving the frame in the X and Y directions while the sewing machine head stitches a pattern into a fabric stretched on the frame. The system includes a separate computer or process controller for controlling the sewing machine and a separate computer or process controller for controlling the frame movement. This allows for independent programming and reprogramming of the sewing and movement functions, reducing the amount of work required to make adjustments or changes.
2. The frame quilting machine includes a reprogrammable function that allows the operator to manually draw a pattern on a monitor using a computer aided design program. The program then converts the drawn pattern into computer language and stores it in the memory of the computer. The pattern can then be duplicated as often as desired and the computer will cause the machine to stitch the pattern into the marked locations on the fabric.
3. The sewing machine function is controlled by one computer and the quilting table motion is controlled by a separate computer. This allows for easier reprogramming of the sewing machine function or the pattern without having to also reprogram the other function. The machine is designed to satisfy increased production needs of manufacturers who supply custom, hand-guided, or outline quilted patterns.

1. The invention describes a method of manufacturing a two-sided nonwoven fabric with a three-dimensional image that is durable to converting and end-use application. The method involves forming a fabric from a first precursor web and a second precursor web, with a fluid-pervious support layer or scrim interposed between them. The precursor webs are subjected to hydroentanglement on a moveable imaging surface having a three-dimensional image transfer device.
2. The first and second precursor webs, with an interposed fiber distribution control layer, are advanced onto the imaging surface of the image transfer device. Hydroentanglement of the precursor web is affected to form a three-dimensionally imaged fabric. The incorporation of a fiber distribution control layer acts to limit the ability of the fibrous constituent of the first precursor web and the second precursor web from becoming extensively intermixed.
3. The precursor webs can be hydroentangled prior to juxtaposition of a support layer or scrim and subsequent three-dimensional imaging. Alternatively, one or more layers of fibrous matrix can be juxtaposed with one or more support layers or scrims, then the layered construct can be pre-entangled to form a precursor web which is imaged directly.
4. The fabric can have a first side or surface comprised of a first fibrous matrix and a second side or surface comprised of a second fibrous matrix, wherein the first and second fibrous matrix are dissimilar. The first and second sides are separated by an intermediate water pervious, fiber distribution control layer, which acts to deter the excessive intermingling of the first fibrous matrix and second fibrous matrix.
5. The fibrous constituent of the first fibrous matrix and the second fibrous matrix can exhibit a by fiber modulus difference of at least 10%, wherein the fibrous matrix with the lower fiber modulus comes in contact with the three-dimensional imaging transfer device.
6. Subsequent to hydroentanglement, the three-dimensionally imaged fabric may be subjected to one or more variety of post-entanglement treatments, such as application of a polymeric binder composition, mechanical compacting, application of surfactant or electrostatic compositions, and like processes.

1. The invention describes a sewing machine device that includes a guide chute for feeding a strip of add-on material over the bed plate, where the strip can be stopped by a displaceable stop controlled by the sewing machine's control means. The control means can control the operation of the sewing machine based on the position of the stop and the strip material.
2. The device includes a two-armed lever with a stop for contacting the feed path of the strip and preventing feed when the strip is not fed in correct association with the fabric. The lever is part of a control means including a control switch and a setting means for adjusting the position of the stop. The stop is mounted for being displaced by a setting means in the form of an air cylinder and substantially perpendicularly to the feed motion of the workpiece. The limits of the setting motion of the stop can be adjusted by displaceable stops.

1. The invention describes a connective knitting method of two tape-shaped knit pieces using a flat knitting machine with needle beds arranged in a V-form. The method involves knitting two pieces of tape-shaped knit fabric and joining their end portions by transferring loops from one needle bed to another and forming new loops through binding off. This method eliminates the need for sewing means, increasing productivity and lowering manufacturing costs.
2. The knitting process can be controlled by a computer following a designed knitting pattern. This invention can be applied to various parts of garments, such as the collar part of a sweater, the neck rope part of a tanktop, the lower end portion of baseball stockings, and the neck rope part of an apron, with different matrix textures like plain knitting, rib knitting, or tubular knitting.

1. The invention describes a traction element, production line, and method for producing a traction element with increased flexibility and improved adhesion between the stranded cables and the plastics material jacket.
2. The traction element has a core strand sheathed by a flexible thermoplastic plastics material layer, and is produced by winding at least six peripheral strand cords around the core strand. The strand cords themselves consist of individual fibers or wires of a material guaranteeing tensile strength.
3. The production line includes an extruder with a thread guide for the stranded cables and at least one matrix, which can be adjusted with and in relation to one another. The stranded cables run through the extruder and the outlet opening of the matrix, lying on one plane, and are embedded in a flexible thermoplastic plastics material jacket.
4. The method for embedding at least one stranded cable with a plastics material-coated core strand involves degreasing and/or pretreating the unwound stranded cables, preheating them to a temperature of about ±20° C. of the melting temperature of the flexible thermoplastic plastics material sheathing the core strands, and sheathing them in the extruder with the liquefied plastics material.
5. The traction elements are suitable for lifting and pulling loads, and are particularly suitable for lift bands or cables, which have to meet high safety requirements.
6. The production line, traction element, and method can increase the economy of the process, achieve a sharp improvement in the adhesion between the stranded cables and the plastics material jacket, and improve the adhesion over long-term and intensive use.

1. The invention describes a lockstitch sewing machine with a rotary hook arrangement that includes a spring rod, a front cam, and a rear cam, all of which control the rotation of the bobbin housing. The spring rod is located between the cams and cooperates with a projection of the housing. The rotary hook revolves in a horizontal plane, and the bobbin housing is supported in the hook body. The bobbin housing comprises a bobbin capsule carrier and a removable bobbin capsule.
2. The lockstitch sewing machine includes a base plate, a standard, an arm with a head, an arm shaft, a needle bar with a threaded needle, a thread take-up lever, a thread tensioning device, a belt pulley, a belt, and a rotary hook drive shaft. The arm shaft is in drive connection with the needle bar and the thread take-up lever, and the head carries the thread tensioning device. The belt pulley, via a belt and a belt pulley, transmits the drive movement of the arm shaft to the rotary hook drive shaft mounted in the base plate.
3. The rotary hook includes a hook body and a hook tip formed thereon. A bobbin housing is supported in the hook body and comprises a bobbin capsule carrier and a removable bobbin capsule. Two projections laterally project from the outer surface of the bobbin housing, which together form a triangular shoulder. The outer side face of one projection forms the front side face of the shoulder, and the outer side face of the other projection forms the rear side face of the shoulder.
4. The front and rear side faces of the two projections are tangential to the generated surface of the bobbin housing. In the bobbin housing, a rotary hook thread is arranged in a known manner. It runs through a thread opening in one projection and thence to the stitch hole of the stitch plate recessed in the top of the base plate. The shoulder lies in the central region of the loop castoff side of the bobbin housing. The loop castoff side lies in the region of that half of the outer surface which, according to FIG. 2, lies outside a line conceived to extend through the stitch hole and the axis of rotation of the rotary hook.

1. The text describes a method for producing silicon-based nanowires and films using liquid silanes as precursors, specifically cyclohexasilane (Si6H12), which can be transformed into solid polydihydrosilane (SiH2)n by thermal treatment or light activation via radical polymerization. Additional thermolysis causes evolution of H2(g) giving a-Si:H at approximately 350°C and crystalline silicon at approximately 750°C.
2. The text also discusses the use of four-component and five-component inks for electrospinning procedures to produce micro and nanofibers. The inks include a liquid silane, a polymer, an accelerant, and a solvent for the four-component ink, and a solid phase is added for the five-component ink. The solid phase components can be metallic particles, photoactive or reactive compounds, or polydihydrosilane.
3. The electrospinning methods can manage stress by reducing the dimensionality from 2D films to 1D wires, and the lateral cohesive stresses that promote cracking in 2D thin films are well managed in 1D wires where radial shrinkage does not lead to the observed deleterious microstructural changes of larger silicon structures.
4. The text also mentions the potential use of the silicon-based materials and nanofibers produced by the methods in a variety of applications including as an active component in other composite materials, such as electrically-conducting silicon composite electrodes for lithium-ion batteries.
5. The text includes figures and examples that illustrate the methods and characterization of the resulting materials.

1. The text describes an arrangement for controlling thread tension in a spool creel with multiple spool holders. Each spool holder has a controller with a brake rotor and an adjustable, tension-responsive braking element. A tensioning lever, coupled to the braking element, is biased by threads and operates at an angular position dependent on thread tension and weight. A biasing arrangement, activated by fluid pressure, is connected to the tensioning lever and can be simultaneously set for all biasing arrangements.
2. The force generated by the biasing arrangement operates in addition to the weight force on the tensioning lever, altering the thread tension. This change can be centrally set so that the thread tension can be determined for the entire creel. When the warping machine served by the creel is shut off, the braking force throughout the entire creel can be increased for quick braking action.
3. The tensioning lever subtends a large angle to the horizontal plane, and the working elevation angle of the biasing arrangement attached to the tensioning lever should preferably subtend a smaller angle. In a preferred modification, the biasing arrangement operates on a brake shoe, which is applied to a further rotating braking surface under higher fluid pressures for rapid braking at shutdown.
4. An alternate embodiment replaces the friction brake with an electromagnetic brake. The tensioning lever is rigidly connected with a transverse lever arm carrying a magnetic system. The magnetic system surrounds a braking disc attached to the brake drum. The magnetic system brakes by generating eddy currents in the braking disc, with a greater braking effect when the disc is more covered by the system.

1. The present invention describes a sewing machine detector with a durable and compact design that minimizes stress on optical fibers and eliminates electrical interference with the power indicating light. The detector includes flat, sheet-shaped light shielding discs that rotate with the sewing machine shaft and are coated with light-transmitting synthetic resin. These discs have printed light shielding areas that detect the sewing machine speed, needle UP and DOWN positions, and thread trimmer timing position. An optical fiber supporter holds the ends of the light sending and receiving optical fibers in linear fixing holes, which eliminates stress caused by flexing the fibers. The optical fiber supporter is fastened to the enclosure of the detecting section, and the first and second reflecting portions are positioned in opposition to direct light through the light shielding areas of the discs.
2. The detector also includes a power indicating window that receives one end of the power indicating optical fiber, and a fixing block within the module section for securing the optical fibers. The light emitting devices and light receiving devices are fixedly secured to a circuit board within the module section. The detector is capable of stably detecting sewing machine control signals despite shaft vibration, and is less expensive to manufacture due to the elimination of curved reflecting portions on the reflective discs. The detector also reduces stress on the optical fibers by supporting them linearly, and provides for the easy generation and maintenance of accurate optical axes. Additionally, the detector includes an optical fiber power indicating cable that does not interfere with sewing machine control circuitry and can be run simultaneously with the optical fibers for detection.

1. The invention describes a process for the continuous production of viscose rayon yarns with a high degree of whiteness. The process includes completing coagulation, washing with water having a non-alkaline pH, drying, and possibly finishing. The coagulation index and the amount of certain elements on the yarn are reduced during washing. The coagulation can be completed through various methods, such as the passing of time or an acid treatment. The process is carried out with spinning speeds not lower than 90 m/min, and the washing is preferably carried out at temperatures between 20° and 30° C for a period of 25 to 40 seconds.
2. The invention also includes the chemical composition of the wash water, which should have a pH between 4.0 and 5.5 and be free from cations such as Ca2+ and Mg2+ in certain amounts. The wash water can be obtained by treating water from the industrial distribution network with weakly acid ion exchange resins. The process results in a finished yarn with a high degree of white, and other auxiliary treatments may be added to the process. The process is an improvement over traditional processes as it requires handling and recovering a lower number of treatment liquors, resulting in a lower economic burden.

1. The text describes a problem encountered when bleaching pulp with oxygen: oxygen entrained in the pulp mat reduces the vacuum on the vacuum washer and mixes with the wash water to form foam, reducing the vacuum in the washer and preventing chemicals and water from passing through the mat.
2. Several proposals for deaerating the pulp before the washer are mentioned, including the Deculator process, which involves rapid acceleration and spraying of stock into a long 6-foot diameter stainless steel receiver where it is boiled under vacuum while being impinged against a suitable target surface. This system requires expensive equipment, including vacuum systems and vacuum vessels.
3. Another system is described in U.S. Pat. No. 4,209,359, which involves agitating the slurry with a radial flow impeller to impart a substantially radial flow to the slurry.
4. Other large degassing chambers are shown in U.S. Pat. No. 3,832,276 and U.S. Pat. No. 3,963,561, which utilize large tanks that must be built to withstand pressure.
5. The inventors devised a system for a small deaeration tank that may be at either atmospheric pressure, under low pressure, or vacuum and can be placed on top of an oxygen reactor. The tank has no moving parts and allows steam or oxygen to be recovered. The system involves using the filtrate from the washer after the oxygen bleach as the swirling fluid in the deaeration tank.
6. The deaeration tank is shown diagrammatically in FIG. 2-4 and is described as a cylindrical tank having an open top and a flat bottom. The tank has an exterior diameter and height, and the inlet pipe and outlet are located at specific positions to provide optimum deaeration. The tank may be closed and built to withstand pressures of ±1 atmosphere if the oxygen or steam is being recovered.

1. The text describes a new type of composite material called biomimetic tendon-reinforced (BTR) composite materials, which have improved properties including high out-plane stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio.
2. The BTR composite material is designed using a function-oriented material design (FOMD) process, which involves defining the functions of a particular structure and quantifying them to define the objectives for the optimization process.
3. The FOMD process uses topology optimization to maximize the out-plane stiffness of the composite material, resulting in a new composite concept where fibers are evenly distributed in the matrix material and can be treated differently in tension and compression.
4. The BTR composite structure includes six fundamental components: tendons/muscles, ribs/bones, joints, flesh, skins, and shell.
5. The BTR concept can be extended to a three-dimensional lattice structure made of various raw materials, such as steel frame, steel columns, carbon-fiber ropes, and carbon fiber/epoxy cover panels.
6. The BTR composite can be used to develop a composite armor, which would benefit the future combat system in total weight reduction and energy absorption.
7. The carbon ropes in the BTR composite can act as safety members to preserve the integrity of the whole structure when a load carrying tendon is broken.

1. The text describes a load-limiting device for use in braced frames in structures, particularly for buildings prone to dynamic and/or seismic activity. The device is designed to undergo plastic deformation during a dynamic event to dissipate energy and limit loads on the structure.
2. The load-limiting device can be connected to the brace of the structure using a connection means, which can be a high-strength bolt, weld, adhesive bonding, clevis, shackle, or any other means for connecting the load-limiting device to the brace.
3. The device can be used in conjunction with the prior art braced frame system, which consists of attaching a brace to the building frame beams with little or no joint eccentricity. The device can be placed at a point on the brace that is connected to the beams and/or columns of the structure.
4. The device undergoes plastic deformation during dynamic loading to dissipate and/or absorb dynamic energy. After a dynamic load, the device can be removed and replaced with a new one that has not undergone plastic deformation. The deformation process of the modified braced frame system shows the brace forces acting on the load-limiting device, and the inertia force placed on the structure during a dynamic event. Plastic hinges form at the corners of the load-limiting device in the plastically deformed configuration, limiting the magnitude of the loads acting on other parts of the frame and avoiding the possibility of fracture of less ductile components in the braced frame system.

1. The present invention is a bedroom cabinet designed for use in a flophouse facility with individual rooms on an existing building's floor.
2. The bedroom cabinet is box-shaped, made of an outer casing and an inner casing, and has a flat external surface.
3. The outer casing is made of upper and lower outer casings, each with front, back, left, and right side portions and an upper or lower surface portion.
4. The front side portions of the upper and lower outer casings have notch portions for the upper and lower halves of the exit.
5. The inner casing is positioned within the outer casing and has a front surface panel, a back panel, left and right side panels, a ceiling panel, and a bottom panel.
6. The front surface panel of the inner casing has an opening in communication with the notches of the upper and lower outer casings.
7. A clearance is formed between the outer casing and the inner casing, which can be used to house boxes for electric devices or shelves for users' belongings.
8. The clearance can also house wirings or other components for interior electric devices.
9. A further embodiment of the invention includes spacer members with venting grooves in the clearance between the outer and inner casings, which improves natural ventilation and sound-proofing.
10. The bedroom cabinet can be easily assembled and disassembled, making it ideal for use in construction sites or other temporary facilities.

1. The present invention is a portable, temporary guard rail support designed for use in the construction industry to provide a safe work area for workmen working at dangerous heights.
2. The guard rail support includes a base plate, an upright column, L-shaped rail supporting brackets, a retaining flange, an angle brace, and a fall protection tie-off ring. The brackets and flange can accommodate wooden rails and a kick board to form a guard rail assembly.
3. The fall protection tie-off ring can serve as retaining and attachment means for a safety cable or for fastening weatherproof tarpaulins.
4. The guard rail support can be secured to the floor via suitable fasteners, and lengths of stock lumber can be positioned and secured within the corresponding rail supporting brackets and retaining flanges to form a guard rail assembly.
5. The guard rail support can also be used with a concrete-filled steel base for greater stability and support in cases where it is not possible to secure the base plate to a floor surface via fasteners.
6. The guard rail support can be used in conjunction with a mesh-like fence structure to form a mesh-like safety barrier at any desired site under construction.

1. The text describes a pulsed power device and method for Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR) using pulsed power electrohydraulic (EH) and electromagnetic (EM) discharge devices to stimulate oil production.
2. The EH mode uses a plasma channel to create high pressures and temperatures, while the EM mode uses controlled flux compression to generate various physical effects without the coupled effect of the EH strong acoustic wave.
3. The pulsed power method can generate high-frequency acoustic stimulation of the reservoir separately from the direct acoustic response of the EH shock wave, inducing a coupled acoustic vibration at very high frequencies in geologic materials like quartz.
4. Effective acoustic stimulation requires higher frequencies than direct acoustic methods can generate, and can be optimized by targeting specific scales of inclusions in the formation.
5. The invention uses a coupled process of direct EH acoustic vibrations and electromagnetically-induced high-frequency acoustic vibrations, recognizing that these two effects must occur together to effectively mobilize the oil and increase production.
6. The technique can be applied using a multi-level discharge device or multiple pulse sources in multiple wells to extend the effective range of stimulation and achieve better stimulation of a specific volume of the reservoir.
7. The discharge characteristics of the pulse sources can be customized to produce specific frequencies that will achieve optimal stimulation by activating specific scales of inclusions in the reservoir.
8. The invention also includes the use of EM pulse sources that do not generate a direct acoustic shock pulse, allowing for operation in more sensitive wells and a wider range of discharge pulse durations.
9. The pulse source can be directed using a range of directional focusing and shaping devices, placed in an injector well, and customized to produce specific frequencies for optimal stimulation.

1. The text describes a splice for a soil reinforcing element used in Mechanically Stabilized Earth (MSE) structures, which can be used for various applications including retaining walls, bridge abutments, dams, seawalls, and dikes. The splice is used to extend the length of a soil reinforcing element by coupling one or more grid-strips to the soil reinforcing element. The grid-strip generally extends the length of the soil reinforcing element to the length required for the particular MSE application. The splice includes wave plates with transverse protrusions that receive and seat the transverse wires from the soil reinforcing element and the grid-strip. The splice is secured by a connective device such as a threaded bolt that extends through perforations in the wave plates and clamps down on the longitudinal wires of the soil reinforcing element and the grid-strip.
2. The text also describes a composite soil reinforcing element that includes a soil reinforcing element having a first plurality of transverse wires coupled to at least two longitudinal wires, a grid-strip having a second plurality of transverse wires coupled to at least two longitudinal wires, and a splice that couples the reinforcing end of the soil reinforcing element to the splicing end of the grid-strip. The splice includes a first wave plate defining one or more first transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number of the first plurality of transverse wires of the soil reinforcing element, and a second wave plate defining one or more second transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number of the second plurality of transverse wires of the grid-strip. The splice further includes a first perforation defined on the first wave plate and a second perforation defined on the second wave plate, and a first connective device extensible through the first perforation and the second perforation to couple the first wave plate to the second wave plate and clamp down on the at least two longitudinal wires of the soil reinforcing element and the at least two longitudinal wires of the grid-strip.

1. The text describes a plow blade with a fluid passage and points of fluid ejection, designed for efficient production using basic manufacturing processes. The blade can be rebuilt by replacing worn portions, and ejecting fluid at specific points reduces drag and minimizes the volume of ejected fluid.
2. The plow consists of a blade, leading edge sections, point, and a fluid tube. The blade has a front edge, top end with apertures for attachment to a power unit, and a bottom end that supports various points.
3. The fluid tube is adapted to transfer pressurized fluid from the top of the plow into a void in the leading edge section, and stitch welds define flow paths for the fluid to exit the blade at controlled locations and with a controlled flow rate.
4. The length and location of the stitch welds define the location and volume at which the fluid exits the blade, and the fluid pressure varies along the blade's length, with higher pressure near the bottom where resistance from soils is greater.
5. The number of leading edge sections and the location and size of the stitch welds can be adjusted to tailor the plow for specific applications, and a manifold can be installed between the blade and leading edge sections to control the flow rates and location of fluid injection.
6. The fluid tube can be located on the opposite side of the blade and protected by plates, with the tube terminating at a bottom end section that includes a void. The tube is then sealed by welding it to the bottom end section and the blade, forcing the fluid into the void.

1. The present invention is a building system that allows for the creation of larger exterior panels without the need for movement control joints, and a cavity wall plaster system that can provide walls of considerable size and non-square or non-rectangular perimeters.
2. The system involves the use of a reinforced plaster panel with a minimum thickness of 21mm, and a frame or substructure with studs, battens, and meshes. The battens are fixed both on and between studs, and a first mesh is attached to the battens while a second mesh is supported at least in part by a plaster matrix. The plaster matrix penetrates the first mesh, interposing both meshes, attaching to the second mesh and covering the second mesh.
3. The system also includes reinforcement at corners and around openings, with the option for additional regional reinforcement. The edges of the plaster are formed and supported by uPVC mouldings, and movement is accommodated by providing physical breaks in the plaster.
4. The system is intended to be fixed to timber walls with studs at 600 mm centers, and is able to resist wind face loading up to and including those associated with VH wind speed zones. The location of Movement Control Joints (VMCJs) shall be shown on the consented building elevations in compliance with the Rules.

1. The invention describes a new and improved safe and door structure, which is a readily assembled, low cost door and safe structure. The safe has a valuables receiving chamber with a generally rectangular opening and a first set of inwardly extending ledges on opposing walls for placement of a plate-shaped separate steel door thereon. A set of grooves formed on the opposite walls transverse to the first set of opposing walls provide stops for retaining the door therein. The door is engaged by inserting one edge into a deeper groove at a slight angle while pivoting the other edge toward the ledge, and then laterally displacing the door until the latter edge is in abutment with the seat of the shallower groove. A lock assembly on the reverse side of the door has the latch bolt engaging a detent in one bar for prevention of lateral movement with reinforcing bolts on both sides of the lock bolt preventing transmission of force to the lock mechanism in the event of forceful intrusion attempts.
2. The safe construction can be formed utilizing the construction described in applicant's U.S. Pat. No. 4,176,440, which is an in-place construction wherein a liner, preferably formed of an appropriate plastic material, is employed as a combination liner and form for the pouring of concrete thereabout to provide the majority of the body of the floor safe. The liner may be made of plastic, sheet metal, sheet steel, or a thermosetting resin or other fire-resistant and heat insulating substance. The invention is not limited to a cast-in-place concrete construction and can be equally applicable to a safe which is formed of all metal, such as by steel fabrication or steel casting methods.

1. The text describes various embodiments of geological formation pressure sensing systems that more accurately measure the formation pressures at desired depths. The inlet to the pressure sensing apparatus is located at a desired depth in the formation and isolated to pressures produced by the formation at such depth.
2. The systems described involve the use of a borehole, grout pipe, pressure sensor arrangement, connector block, filter, check valve, and fluid injection pipe. The pressure sensor arrangement is fixed in the borehole at the desired location by placing a cement grout around it. Before the cement grout is fully cured, a liquid is pumped down hole through a check valve to clear the filter of the cement grout material. Subsequently, a fluid is again pumped down the borehole through the check valve to form a void or communication path between the formation and the pressure transducer.
3. The cement grout material around the void isolates the pressure transducer in the borehole, except the laterally adjacent portion of the geological formation where it is desired to obtain fluid pressure measurements. The systems also involve the use of a packer that carries a pressure transducer at its bottom end and is inserted into the large tube and sealed therein. The packer effectively plugs the large tube so that the pressure in the formation can pressurise the lower injection tube.
4. The text also describes the process of pumping a pressurised fluid into the surface input tube to displace fluid from the injection tubing, through the check valve and out of the filter through the opened cement grout. This process fractures the formation at a specific location via the void area around the filter. The hardened cement grout in the borehole above and below the void area functions to concentrate the pressurised fluid in the annular area of the formation surrounding the filter component of the pressure sensor arrangement.
5. The natural pressures of the geological formation cause the formation fluid to enter the fracture zone and from the filter to the pressure transducer. Changes in the formation pressure are sensed by the pressure transducer and coupled by corresponding electrical signals to the surface monitoring equipment.

1. The invention relates to a jointing structure in vehicle traveling path joints, such as those found in new transit systems, monorails, road bridges, and footbridges, which have an expansion function to accommodate temperature-related changes in the size of the joints.
2. The jointing structure includes steps at the ends of the traveling paths, elastic members (such as laminated rubber) mounted inside the steps, and a joint block mounted on the elastic members across the expansion gap. The elastic members are designed to permit no deformation at a median bridge girder length, allowing the joint block to always be in the center of the expansion gap and ensuring smooth vehicle traveling.
3. The joint block is placed across the expansion gap, preventing differences in level from occurring and ensuring adequate management of each member. A joint block made of the same concrete as the traveling path provides increased slip resistance to tires.
4. The elastic members are made of a material that is hard to be deformed vertically and easy to be deformed horizontally, and are fitted to the joint block detachably by bolting or the like. Supporting blocks may be mounted inside the steps to protect the traveling path ends from damage.
5. The expansion gap may be decentralized into multiple smaller gaps to prevent tire fall-in and/or stuck-in situations, and the use of blocks of the same quality as the traveling path or high-strength fiber-reinforced concrete facilitates difference-in-level management.
6. The structure eliminates problems such as rust and degradation of exposed members, and prevents scattering of these members for increased in-traveling safety. The expansion gap may also be provided at an oblique angle to the axial direction of the traveling path to prevent tire fall-in and/or stuck-in situations in small-sized vehicles.

1. The text describes an enclosed floor track system for use in a fluid treatment chamber, specifically for chilling meat products. The system prevents contamination of the sanitary environment and the treatment fluid by the wheels of wheeled trucks or other transport vehicles.
2. The first embodiment of the system includes a wheel channel with opposed sidewalls and a cover plate, which together prevent showered fluid or fluid on the floor from entering the wheel channel area and becoming contaminated. The cover plate can be hinged to facilitate cleaning.
3. The second embodiment of the system is designed for trucks with downwardly depending struts supporting the wheel structure. The sidewalls of the wheel channel extend upwardly beyond the top of the wheel structure and include inflatable elastomer seals that enclose around the hand truck wheel struts and prevent entry of the brine solution into the guide track.
4. The fluid treatment chamber includes a brine distribution piping system, a return piping system, a brine receptor, and a brine recirculation pump. A control panel is used to start and stop the brine circulation system and control the rate of flow.
5. The brine solution is pumped under pressure through the distribution piping system where it is showered onto meat-laden hand trucks. The floor of the fluid treatment chamber is inclined to collect the warm brine solution in a sump where it is cooled and returned to be cycled again.
6. The present invention relates to an enclosed floor track system for transporting the hand trucks into and out of the fluid treatment chamber. Chamber doors keep the showered brine solution contained within the chamber when closed, and when open permit the transportation of meat-laden hand carts into and out of such chamber via the floor tracks.
7. The enclosed floor tracks are supported above the chamber floor by support legs and are slightly pitched to drain any liquid within the tracks into a waste sewer. The overall structure of the hand truck, except the wheels, and the chamber interior including the floor are sanitary, thus any brine solution coming into contact with the hand truck structure or chamber floor is also maintained sanitary and can be reclaimed and recirculated.
8. The enclosed floor track system prevents showered or dripping brine from entering into the track system, and what little solution which may enter the tracks and become contaminated is drained

1. The lock device is designed to prevent a work machine, such as a boom in a backhoe work machine, from being tilted or rotated downward by its own weight. It comprises an engaging member and an engaged member that can be manually locked and unlocked. The engaging member is supported by a guide member and a support pin, and has a hook part and a slot for the support pin. The engaged member can engage with the hook part to lock the work machine in place. The guide member ensures that the engaging member maintains the lock position at any rotation position of the boom between its highest and lowest positions.
2. The lock device is easy to operate, reduces the risk of damage to the engaging member and engaged member, and simplifies the lock mechanism by eliminating the need for a holding mechanism and separate slip-prevention member. It also guides the engaging member at its upper and lower sides to stabilize its movement and prolong the life of the lock mechanism. The lock device is suitable for use in various work machines, including excavating devices, loaders, and cranes.

1. The text describes an adjustable swimming pool vacuum head that can easily regulate the suction being exerted by the suction head during the pool cleaning operation. The adjustment mechanisms are conveniently located on the top of the vacuum head and can be quickly operated by hand without the need for hand tools.
2. The vacuum head comprises a generally rectangular, horizontally extending platform with a central portion, longitudinally extending edges, longitudinally spaced end portions, and a plurality of longitudinally spaced, transverse stiffening ribs. The central portion of the platform is provided with an opening and an upwardly extending cylindrical member in communication with the opening.
3. The invention also includes a first, or outboard roller assembly connected to the platform proximate each end portion, and a second, or inboard roller assemblies interconnected with the platform on either side of the central opening. The inboard roller assemblies have a specially configured frame member that is connected to and spans the platform.
4. The central portion of the platform is provided with an adjustability feature that can increase the spacing between the central, suction portion of the platform and the pool bottom, thereby precisely regulating the effective suction of the device without having to adjust the suction at the suction source. The invention also includes a roller height adjustment device that can be provided in kit form for use in combination with certain types of prior art suction head assemblies.

1. The text describes a wear bushing retriever apparatus for the oil and gas industry, which is used to protect against excessive wear in well heads and casings during drilling operations. The apparatus includes a sub-unit with a mandrel and a removable lower collar section that can be threaded onto a section of drill pipe. A retriever section is inserted onto the mandrel and can be moved vertically but not rotationally, allowing it to engage with an extended J-slot of a wear bushing for retrieval.
2. The apparatus is designed to solve problems with existing wear bushing retrieval methods, such as the need for a drill bit to be removed from the hole before retrieval. The apparatus can be threaded onto any two sections of drill pipe without retrieving the drill bit, and it includes a retriever unit that can be quickly installed and removed for easy bushing replacement.
3. The retriever unit includes protruding members that engage with the wear bushing's J-slot, and it is prevented from rotating around the mandrel by insertion members that engage with grooves on the mandrel. This allows the retriever unit to move vertically but not rotationally, preventing damage to the unit or the wear bushing during retrieval. The apparatus is also designed to allow for some vertical play in the retriever unit, preventing the weight of the drill string from damaging the wear bushing during retrieval attempts.

1. The invention describes a vibratory tool used in downhole operations to dislodge stuck objects or fish.
2. The tool has a modular design, allowing for different numbers of pistons to be stacked, increasing the delivered power of the tool.
3. The tool has a passage that can be closed off by dropping a plug onto a seat, allowing a wireline or other tools to pass through the tool.
4. The dump valve is disposed annularly about the central passage, preventing it from being slammed against a seat during operation.
5. The mandrel is powered by stacked pistons in the tool body, magnifying the delivered power from the vibratory tool.
6. The tool can be configured to apply high amplitude low-frequency oscillating forces to the stuck fish without impacts.
7. The tool has a rotational lock between the mandrel and the housing for torque transmission.
8. The tool can be operated to have impacts on each cycle, which can be induced during operation by varying the overpull amount.
9. The tool can operate without impact of the pistons and can still be effective in releasing a fish.
10. The tool may also be used in stimulation or fishing operations, providing large amplitude vibrations in a tubing string and relying on a single valve for operation.

1. The invention describes a precast concrete retaining wall system with a face panel and a base, both connected by a counterfort piece extending from the rear side of the face panel. The counterfort provides additional support and stability to the wall.
2. The face panel and counterfort are precast with openings for drainage to limit pressure on the wall and improve stability. Rebars are cast within the counterfort for added strength and tension.
3. The base is also precast and can be connected to the face panel or counterforts using a shear key filled with grout. The base can also have openings to accept downward-extending rebar ends from the counterfort.
4. The connection between the face panel and base is made by inserting the rebar ends of the face panel into the openings in the base and sealing the connection with grout.
5. Multiple retaining walls can be placed adjacent to one another to form a continuous wall, with shims or shear keys between adjacent walls for flexibility.

1. The present invention is a down hole heating system designed to improve the flow of oil and gas in wells that are experiencing issues due to high oil viscosity and/or blockage by paraffin or similar meltable petroleum byproducts.
2. The system includes a heating unit with electrical resistance type heater rods, the electrical current for which is supplied by cables running down the exterior of production tubing and connect to leads at the upper end of the heating unit. A heat insulating packer and stainless steel collars are also included to contain the heat from the heating unit within the desired zone.
3. The design of the system focuses the heat on the production formation itself, heating the oil and paraffin in situ and allowing it to flow to the well bore for pumping. This is achieved by largely containing the heat below the level of the junction between the production tubing and the perforated tubing.
4. The system also addresses the problem of physical and chemical attack of the electrical connections between the power leads and the heater rods, as well as shorting of electrical circuits because of invasion of heater units by conductive fluids, by shielding the internal connection for the down hole heating unit from the pressures and hostile chemical agents which surround the unit in the well bore.

1. The invention relates to a mechanism for installing and retrieving down hole objects in wells, specifically for removing objects stuck or lost within a well bore.
2. The mechanism includes an expandable collet type device for establishing internal connection with an object to be pulled from the well bore, or an external grapple device with external teeth for internally gripping an object such as drill pipe or tubing.

1. The present application claims priority to previously filed Mexican and PCT patent applications, the contents of which are incorporated by reference.
2. The invention relates to a method for manufacturing composed stave floors with improved physical, aesthetic, and functional properties.
3. Conventional composed stave floors have a sight substrate thickness of 2-3 mm, which tends to deform or detach upon sanding or rushing.
4. The base substrate in conventional floors is composed of slung wood or plywood joined by glue, which can lead to deformation, displacement, or dimensional changes.
5. The example embodiment provides a method with a sight substrate of at least 4 mm thickness and a base substrate of at least 12 mm thickness, assembled together with glue and multidirectional holding means.
6. The multidirectional holding means include dendrites, adhesion means, and horizontal and vertical reinforcement means in the union plane and normal to the union plane.
7. This method prevents displacement or change of dimensions, extends floor lifespan, and allows for corrective maintenance.
8. The invention also aims to provide pre-varnished floors with higher hardness glazes, such as aluminum oxide, from the supplier.
9. The summary includes modifications and variations that do not deviate from the spirit and scope of the example embodiments.

1. The text describes a ladder attachment for improving lateral stability, preventing damage to the work surface, and allowing the ladder to straddle corners. The attachment includes a brace assembly with a U-bolt that encircles a ladder rung and a clamp that secures the assembly to the ladder siderail. A resilient pad assembly is pivotally connected to an extension arm and provides a non-slip gripping portion that contacts the work surface.
2. The large contact area brace assemblies increase the contact area between the ladder and the work surface, preventing damage to the surface. The ability to pivot the resilient pad assembly horizontally allows the ladder to straddle corners, providing stability and access to inside and outside corners.
3. The attachment can be constructed of heavier gauge material or with additional bolts for added strength and stability, particularly in less substantial ladders where there is a limit on the amount the U-bolt can be torqued. The invention can be modified and adapted to various situations and materials while still maintaining its essential teachings.

1. The present invention pertains to a collated nail strip formed with a debris-free plastic material for use in a fastener driving tool.
2. Presently known collated nails are assembled using tape strips or an extruded plastic material, but they tend to generate debris as the nails are driven into the workpiece.
3. The invention aims to reduce the tendency for the plastic to generate debris and to minimize the amount that the strip can flex, while maximizing the adhesion of the plastic to the nail shanks.
4. The collation system is configured to permit the collation to be coiled for use in driving tools that accept collations in this manner.
5. The fastener assembly includes a row of fasteners arranged parallel to one another, and a collation system formed from a plastic material that is molded onto and adhered to the fasteners.
6. The plastic material defines a collar portion that captures or at least substantially encircles the fastener shank and a connecting portion extending between and connecting adjacent collar portions.
7. The plastic material is formulated from an adhesive polymer such as a polyolefin, a polyolefin blend, an epoxy or the like.

1. The invention is a nozzle for applying sealants such as silicones, useful in various industries including aviation, automotive, naval, railway, and robotics.
2. The nozzle has a bell or hood lower section and an injection button, and is designed to facilitate the injection of sealants in multiple industrial applications.
3. The bell-shaped tip or lower section of the nozzle is designed to encapsulate rivets or nuts, and the injection button has a special design with channels and orifices for carrying out sealing operations with greater accuracy.
4. The button section allows the user to apply sealant operations both manually and by automated sealant injection machines.
5. The nozzle may be used in the aviation industry and the automotive, naval, railway and robotics industries.
6. The nozzle is preferably made of plastic, such as polypropylene.
7. The invention also includes a second embodiment with an injection button having lateral grooves or openings.
8. The nozzle provides a more economical sealing process, reduces sealant application time, and increases the quality of the resulting sealant application.

1. The position sensor system described includes a waveform generator that receives an unconditioned sensing signal from a transducer and modifies it based on an error correction signal to provide a conditioned sensing signal. An error correction generator, which includes a comparator, controller, and signal processor, determines and eliminates strong static signals and error signals that do not deliver information about the position of an object being sensed. A window reference circuit constantly compares a desired conditioned sensor signal output to an existing conditioned sensor signal output and adjusts the conditioned sensor signal output if it is above a preset high reference signal or below a preset low reference signal.
2. The sensor monitoring system is remotely located and provides power to the sensor and receives the conditioned sensing signal via two wires, making the sensor desirable for multiplexing with other sensors. The sensor system includes a window comparator, controller, counter, and digital to analog converter (DAC) that control the count rate and direction of the signal processor. The output of the DAC is subtracted from the output of the transducer in the waveform generator.
3. The sensor system determines and eliminates strong static signals or other error signals that do not deliver information about the position of the object being sensed whose inclusion in the sensor output signal would waste energy. A digitally stored offset and error correction closed-loop compensation constantly compares the sensor output to a desired minimum value and generates a correction that may be subtracted from the offset and error signal to deliver a sensor output that is as close to the desired, an ideal minimum, as is practical without requiring unnecessary circuitry that is typically used for signal conditioning. The sensor system generates a relatively small reference signal that is large enough to eliminate small values of drift in a negative going direction yet is small enough not to generate a significant amount of signal due to the discrete nature of the calibration voltages from the DAC and counter combination. A relatively large reference signal that substantially exceeds the largest voltage encountered as the object moves its maximum amount is accommodated by allowing rapid recalibration due to sudden changes in offset voltage caused by rapid temperature or other changes.

1. The text describes a desmodromic valve actuation system for intake and exhaust function of a four-stroke piston in internal combustion engines, which eliminates the use of springs and provides precise control over valve opening and closing.
2. The system comprises a rotary cam with a grooved track, a translating means (ball constrained in a slide), a rotable link with a slot, and pins attached to the valve that ride in the slot to control the up and down movement of the valve. The amount of port opening can be controlled by adjusting the angle of the slot.
3. The system can be computer-controlled to operate any set of pistons and adjust the valve displacement for efficient fuel consumption and engine performance. The system can also be adapted for engines with multiple valves per cylinder.

1. The text describes an aquarium lighting system that uses LED lights to emit different colors of light, specifically white and blue, which can be adjusted to create a desired color temperature output. The system includes a housing with a lighting control region that has two control channels for the white and blue lights, and a neutral channel. Light-emitting modules that emit white or blue light can be coupled to the lighting control region and to one of the channels to provide electrical power. The system also includes switches that control the channels, allowing the user to adjust the intensity and color temperature of the light.
2. The text also describes a module that includes radio frequency (RF) or other communication/control hardware, allowing it to be controlled remotely by a remote control. This module includes six RGB LEDs that can emit varying levels of red, green, or blue light to create a wide range of colors within the aquarium. The module receives power from the control channel and is controlled remotely by an RF signal from the remote control. The remote control functions include on/off, increase/decrease intensity, color selection, reset (to white light), and auto mode where the module continuously cycles through the different colors. The module also includes inputs for insertion of one or more optics to snap onto the module and change the angle of emitted light or otherwise alter the optics and emission of light from the LEDs.

1. The present invention relates to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for a fluid-flow machine operating at high temperatures, specifically a cooled stator or rotor blade for a gas turbine.
2. Current flow deflection apparatuses have cooling channels cast into the interior of the blade airfoil section to reduce metal temperature and improve durability.
3. The invention proposes using separate inserts for the separating walls instead of casting them together with the apparatus, which simplifies production, allows for flexible matching to the respective application, and improves cooling efficiency.
4. The inserts can be made of metal or non-metal materials and are secured in place after being inserted into the apparatus, either through the blade root or blade tip.
5. This design offers several advantages, including reduced material in the transitional region from the hot-gas wall to the insert, elimination of thermal stresses between the insert and the hot-gas wall, reduced blade weight and centrifugal-force stresses, simpler cast core and blade production, and easier adjustment of the cooling system by replacing inserts.
6. A preferred embodiment features a hollow casting with holders (rails) integrally formed in the interior for inserting and securing the separating walls, ensuring a good seal at the edges.
7. The separating walls can be flat strips composed of metallic or heat-resistant non-metallic materials and can be connected to the flow deflection apparatus by soldering or welding for added security.
8. In the case of rotor blades rotating at high speed, the cooling channels and separating walls should extend essentially in the radial direction with respect to the rotation axis, and the integral material joint should be arranged at the end of the separating walls close to the axis.
9. The invention can be applied to various types of flow deflection apparatuses, such as blades in a gas turbine, and can lead to considerable simplifications in design and production.

1. The text describes an invention for controlling a fuel delivery system, such as a throttle valve, in a vehicle. The system can be switched between automatic and manual control. In automatic control, a control unit processes signals from an accelerator pedal and the throttle valve to provide an optimum throttle position for the vehicle. In manual control, the throttle valve is controlled directly by the accelerator pedal. The system includes a clutch that connects the accelerator pedal to the throttle valve when manual control is desired. The system prevents the vehicle from lurching forward or stalling when control is shifted from automatic to manual.

2. The control system can also be used in conjunction with a continuously variable transmission. At high transmission ratios, it is desirable to manually control the throttle valve position while at low transmission ratios, automatic control is preferred. The control unit can be programmed to detect the transmission ratio and switch to the optimum control mode for the throttle. The system uses stepper or DC motors to control the throttle valve. The text includes flow charts and diagrams that illustrate the operation of the system and the subroutines used to generate pulses for controlling the stepper motor.

1. The invention is a method and apparatus for generating heat from particulate-laden gas or waste fuels such as wood waste, aiming to provide a clean burning waste fuel burner which can deliver exhaust gases as clean as those produced by oil and gas burners.
2. The method forms a conical pile of waste fuel, fed from below, with preheated underfire air percolating up through the pile in controlled amounts, drying and gasifying the waste fuel in the pile.
3. The volatile gases driven off the pile are partially oxidized by additional combustion air in a first or primary combustion chamber, with the total amount of combustion air admitted being maintained at less than stoichiometric proportions to keep the temperature lower than the necessary to melt the natural ash.
4. A steady temperature at the exit of the primary chamber is maintained by adjusting the amount of swirl air, which also forces particulate out of the gas stream leaving the primary chamber.
5. The volatile gases move into a second combustion chamber where secondary combustion air is introduced to complete combustion, with the secondary air introduced in the secondary combustion chamber being directed tangentially.
6. The combustion air introduced to the primary and secondary chambers is introduced on the outside of a refractory lining to cool the lining and increase its life.
7. The secondary combustion air introduced in the secondary combustion chamber can be introduced at various axial locations in that chamber to regulate the position of the flame within the chamber.
8. Additional blend air can be added to the discharge of the secondary chamber to cool the air for industrial purposes other than boiler heat.
9. The swirl air and secondary combustion air combine or interact dependent upon moisture content of the fuel to maintain good separation of the particulate from the gas stream leaving the primary chamber.
10. The primary and secondary chambers can be added to any source of dirty particulate-laden combustible gas and effectively burn the gas to provide a source of useful heat and remove the particulate for meeting environmental emission standards.

1. The invention is a highly efficient evaporative air cooler that operates by separating the dry and wet sides of a heat exchanger, keeping evaporating water separate from the useful air to achieve sensible cooling.
2. The system draws at least a major portion of the working air from the load (the enclosure to be cooled) to take advantage of its lower wet bulb temperature and increase the temperature differential.
3. The system uses an array of spaced vertically directed hollow elongated tubular members for the wet and dry sides of the heat exchanger. The wet side is accomplished by gravity flow of water downwardly along the inner surfaces of the tubes in conjunction with countercurrent flow of returned air from the load. The dry side is accomplished by fresh air flowing in thermal conductive contact with the outer surfaces of the tubular members for cooling.
4. The system can include variations such as recirculation of return air to mix with fresh air for quicker cooling at a higher energy cost, or bypassing cooled air to mix with working return air for lower temperature but higher energy cost.
5. The heat exchanger comprises an array of tubular members stacked between top and bottom headers, with a side wall accommodating blowers that draw fresh air through the dry side of the heat exchanger and distribute the cooled air to the enclosure.
6. Water is fed to the top header and flows downwardly along the inner surfaces of the tubular members, evaporating as the return air is pushed upwardly through the tubes, abstracting heat and cooling the walls.
7. The moisture-laden air is discharged as an exhaust stream, which can be conducted through a heat exchange assembly to pre-cool the fresh air.

1. The text describes a fluid pump for pumping liquids, particularly liquid manure from animal husbandry operations. The pump is designed to handle high volumetric flow rates and high pressures.
2. The pump comprises two or more pump heads, each containing an impeller driven by a drive structure. The drive structure is commonly connected to all impellers to ensure they rotate in unison.
3. The pump heads are connected in series, with fluid flowing from one pump head to the next. Each pump head comprises a housing with an inlet and at least two fluid conduits, which combine the fluid flow before exiting the pump head.
4. The drive structure may comprise one or more drive shafts, which may be connected through connectors to transmit rotational motion from one drive shaft to another.
5. The connectors may be mounted on the drive shafts, impellers, or housings, and may extend out from the pump heads to bridge two pump heads and be partially disposed in one or both of the pump heads.
6. The pump heads may be removably connected or formed in a unitary structure. Removable connection permits modularity, facilitating repair and the inclusion of more pump heads in the series to increase the operating pressure.
7. The pump may be mounted on a support structure, such as a wheeled boom, hitching assembly, or trailer, to facilitate operation at a fluid reservoir.
8. The pump is designed to handle solid material in the reservoir without plugging, and to provide high volumetric flow rates and high pressures.

1. The invention relates to engine compression release brakes that have fewer components than traditional systems, which typically include an engine brake for each engine cylinder.
2. The braking horsepower in these systems is varied by operating less than all of the engine brakes. However, if the maximum braking horsepower required does not need engine braking using all engine cylinders, the engine includes excess components.
3. A reduction in engine components can improve the overall robustness of an engine. Therefore, an engine compression release brake system including a sufficient, but reduced, number of components would be desirable.
4. The present invention provides an engine with an engine housing that defines a plurality of engine cylinders and an engine compression release brake for a portion of the engine cylinders, wherein the portion is less than all of the plurality of engine cylinders.
5. Each engine compression release brake is operably coupled to a cam actuated exhaust valve.
6. The engine compression release brake has a brake body, an electrical actuator such as a solenoid, a valve member, a spool valve member, a biasing spring, and a piston.
7. The spool valve member is movable between an upward, retracted position and a downward, advanced position. It defines a high pressure annulus and a low pressure annulus that can connect to a high pressure passage or a low pressure passage, respectively.
8. The piston is movably positioned in the brake body and provides a hydraulic surface that is exposed to fluid pressure in the actuation fluid passage. When actuation fluid passage is open to high pressure passage, high pressure acts on the hydraulic surface to move the piston toward its downward, advanced position, causing the exhaust valve actuator to move to an open position against the pressure in the cylinder.

1. The text describes a link assembly between an engine and a gearbox, which includes a male link coupled to either the engine or the gearbox, a female link also coupled to either the engine or the gearbox, and a pin that selectively retains the male and female links together. The female link receives the male link to allow translation and form a radial interface that dampens the translation of the male link relative to the female link. This design allows for increased mobility of the gearbox relative to the engine, which can absorb extreme shocks without transmitting potentially destructive loads from the engine to the gearbox.
2. The mounting link can be utilized as a medium to long link to connect the engine to an associated structure, such as the gearbox. In the illustrated embodiment, extreme loads may break the rigid constraint of the mounting link by shearing the pin to allow a permitted range of motion. The interface between the female link and the male link can dampen the relative motion within the permitted range of motion.
3. The female link includes a link mounting end and a link interface end, which includes a cavity to receive the male link. The male link is attached to the corresponding component that the female link is not attached to, and the link interface end is received by the female link in the link interface end of the female link. The pin selectively prevents the relative translation of the female link and the male link by passing through a through hole of the female link and a through hole of the male link to engage and retain the female link and the male link.
4. The pin can serve as a fusible link and is designed to shear at a known load magnitude corresponding to the maximum structural capability of the gearbox assembly, the unfused mount components, and the engine mounting structure. After an event that can cause the pin to shear, fuse, or otherwise release, the female link and the male link are allowed to translate relative to each other, which can limit or prevent damage that could otherwise be done to the gearbox and its attached peripherals by transmitting such extreme loads, while simultaneously helping to prevent the gearbox from detaching from the engine.

1. The text describes an archery equipment innovation that includes a point cap system with a point cap and a balance pin, which can be adjusted in weight for easy balance customization. The point cap system is designed to be small, lightweight, and suitable for unidirectional fiber reinforced shafts, reducing cross-fiber stress and allowing for easy replacement if threads are damaged. The invention also includes a nock cap adaptor for attaching nocks to arrow shafts.
