1. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, stated that the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 will be superceded by the new Post-compulsory Education and Training Bill (PCETR Bill). She mentioned that there are experiences from the implementation of the 2015 Act that they want to reflect on as they take forward the new Bill.
2. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the legislation being framed around institutional autonomy and whether it's possible for institutions to fulfill any national outcomes. Kirsty Williams AM responded that they will carry those protections into the forthcoming Bill, but they have to ensure appropriate regulation and accountability of institutions for their public funding and the privileges that they enjoy.
3. Kirsty Williams AM mentioned that they are considering how the part of the sector that includes private providers will be regulated in the forthcoming legislation. She also mentioned that there are a very small number of private providers in Wales and that they have a process in place to manage this.

1. The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended the meeting.
2. The Minister stated that the 2015 Act will be superceded by the new Post-compulsory Education and Training Bill (PCETR Bill). She acknowledged that there are areas in the 2015 Act that have worked well, but there are also areas that require improvement. She emphasized the importance of the four strategic aims of the Act: regulation of institutions in Wales, safeguarding the contribution made to public good, maintaining a focus on fair access, and preserving and protecting the principle of institutional autonomy.
3. The discussion covered various topics including the regulation of private providers, the role of HEFCW, and the need for national outcomes in legislation. The Minister stated that the new Bill will look to move to a system of outcome agreements, where those outputs will reflect national priorities. She also mentioned that the current legislation has provisions that protect universities' privileges and autonomy, and those protections will be carried into the forthcoming Bill.
4. The committee also discussed the need for a more streamlined and effective policy lever to align the sector to the social, economic and civic needs of Wales in the new PCET funding body. The Minister agreed that tertiary education providers should contribute to national goals and outcomes as part of a civic mission and that any legislation brought forward will empower the commission to enable that to happen.

1. The group discussed the final design of a remote control, with changes made to the original plan due to cost constraints. The final design includes an LCD screen, a jog-dial, and a number pad. The slogan will be placed along the side or bottom of the remote. The dimensions of the remote will be approximately 9-10 cm in height.
2. The group discussed the colors of the remote, deciding on a special color for the case and normal colored buttons. They also discussed the possibility of embossing the logo on the buttons.
3. The group evaluated the design using a set criteria, rating it a 2.5 out of 7 for stylish look and feel, a 3 for high tech innovation, a 2 for style reflecting a fruit inspired color design, and a 1 for design being simple to use.
4. The group discussed the room for creativity in the project, expressing that the guidelines were contrived and the creativity was more of a formality than an actual process. They also discussed leadership and teamwork, expressing that the leadership was strong and controlling, and teamwork was difficult due to the lack of communication outside of meetings.

1. The team discussed the new project requirements for a remote control for TVs. The remote will only be for TVs and not for other devices, and teletext is considered outdated. The team will have three presentations to discuss the various options, each presented by a team member.
2. The team discussed the design of the remote control. The remote will have a battery supply, buttons for various functions such as channel up/down and volume control, a chip to interpret button presses, and an infra-red sender to send signals to the TV. The team also discussed the possibility of including a clap-activated buzzer system to help locate the remote when it is lost.

1. The project manager called a meeting to discuss new project requirements related to a TV remote control. The meeting was to last forty minutes and include presentations from three team members.
2. The team discussed the remote being only for TV use and not being too complex, as time to market was important. They also discussed the possibility of including a "whistle back" function to address the frustration of losing the remote.
3. The industrial designer presented their research on the components required for a remote control, including a power source, user interface, a chip, a sender, and a receiver.
4. The user interface designer presented their ideas for the technical functions design, including a simple design with buttons for volume, channel up and down, and power. They also discussed the possibility of incorporating the company's logo and color scheme.
5. The team discussed the possibility of reducing the number of buttons and including a "favorites" option for channels. They also discussed the possibility of including speech recognition, but decided it would be too expensive and not preferred by older generations.
6. The marketing team presented their research on functional requirements, including the desire for a sleek and high-tech design, fewer buttons, and the possibility of including speech recognition for younger generations.
7. The team discussed the possibility of including a "whistle back" function to address the frustration of losing the remote and decided it would be a good selling point. They also decided to exclude teletext due to the popularity of the internet.
8. The team discussed the buttons that would be included on the front and back of the remote, including numbers, volume, mute, power, channel up and down, and a hidden panel for detailed functions.
9. The team agreed to meet again to finalize the design and assign tasks. The project manager will do the minutes of the meeting.

1. The meeting discussed the functional requirements of a remote control, including the user requirements and technical functions. The remote control should include basic functions such as turning the TV on and off, changing the channel, adjusting the volume, and muting the sound. Additional functions such as play, rewind, fast-forward, stop, pause, and enter for menus were also considered.
2. The user interface presentation focused on the function of a remote control as a device that sends messages to the TV. The presenter discussed the considerations for the remote control's buttons, including the numbers 0-9, power on/off, channel up/down, volume up/down, mute, and functions for VHS and DVD players such as play, rewind, fast-forward, stop, pause, and enter.
3. The marketing presentation discussed the findings of a study of 100 subjects and their use of remote controls. The study found that users are not typically happy with current remote controls, with 75% thinking they're ugly and 80% willing to spend more for a fancier remote. Participants also expressed a desire for a simple yet high-tech looking remote.
4. The industrial design presentation discussed the working design of the remote control. The presenter suggested using a smart chip for multi-functionality and extra functions, as well as a large on-off button for an aging demographic. The remote would be powered by batteries and include a switch, extra bulb, subcomponent, chip, and infra-red bulb for communication with other devices.
5. The group discussed the new product requirements, which included making the remote only for TVs, not including DVD or TiVo functions, promoting the company's color and slogan on the remote, and considering the use of teletext.
6. The group decided on the target group for the remote control, which would be all age ranges and not just for kids. They also discussed the technical literacy of the users, deciding to aim for the lowest denominator.
7. The group determined the specific functions of the remote control, including on-off, volume, mute, channel up and down, and numbers 0-9. They also discussed the possibility of including speech recognition and a finding device for the remote.

1. The meeting discussed the functional design of a remote control, aiming to determine user requirements, technical functions, and working design.
2. User research highlighted the need for a remote control that is simple, yet high-tech looking, with a snazzy design and easy-to-use interface.
3. The remote control should include basic functions such as power, channel, and volume control, with a simple and user-friendly design.
4. Additional features such as speech recognition and a homing device were suggested to make the remote control more advanced and user-friendly.
5. The target group for the remote control includes all age ranges, from kids to adults, with a focus on simplicity and ease of use.
6. The remote control should have a limited number of buttons, as users typically only use 10% of the buttons on current remotes.
7. The remote control should have a yellow logo and potentially yellow keys to promote the company's brand.
8. The team will discuss project financing and specific components of the remote control in future meetings.
9. The team will be sent a questionnaire and summary after the meeting, and will have individual work time and a lunch break before continuing with the project.

1. The meeting is a kick-off meeting for a project to design a new remote control. The aim is to make it original, trendy, user-friendly, and high-quality.
2. The project is broken down into three stages: functional design, conceptual design, and detailed design. Each stage is broken down into individual work and a meeting.
3. The meeting starts with an ice-breaker activity where each person draws their favorite animal and explains why they chose it.
4. The tool training covers the use of two smart boards, one for presentations and one for drawing. The drawing board has basic tools like save, print, undo, select, and pen.
5. The group discusses the project aim and the importance of user-friendliness. They also discuss the need for the remote to work with multiple systems.
6. The group agrees to create mock-ups and general ideas before deciding on the specifics of the design. They also agree to have a plan for what they are going to do before working on the user requirements and technical functions.
7. The group discusses the need for a clear and concise plan to ensure that the user requirements and technical functions align.
8. The group agrees to think about what they believe is the most important aspect of the design and to bring their ideas to the next meeting.
9. The group will receive specific instructions from their personal coaches and will meet again in thirty minutes.
10. The meeting is conducted in a setting where they are being watched by "Big Brother" which means they are being recorded for training purposes.

1. The group discussed the ease of bleeping out content and decided that it should be relatively easy but not too easy to accidentally bleep out important parts.
2. The group also discussed the database format for linking word transcripts, annotations, time-marks, and phone boundaries. They considered using the channelized output of Dave Gelbart's program as a starting point.
3. Grad C mentioned that they already have an XML format for this type of data, and PhD F requested to see it to determine if it would be suitable for their needs.
4. The group also discussed the challenges of handling phone-level alignments, which can be very dense and require a binary representation. They also discussed the possibility of using an existing way of representing phone-level information and linking it to the main representation using an ID.
5. The group considered using the P-file format for frame-level information, which is a binary format that is more compact than ASCII. They also discussed the possibility of using an existing feature format used by H T K.
6. The group also discussed the possibility of using the ATLAS database format, which is a more complex and complete system but has the advantage of being used by a larger community. Grad C agreed to take a closer look at it to determine if it would be a good fit for their needs.

1. The project manager introduces the new remote control project, emphasizing the need for it to be original, trendy, and user-friendly. The group discusses the design process, which will be divided into three main points: functional design, conceptual design, and desired design.
2. The group participates in an ice-breaker activity where they draw their favorite animal on the whiteboard. The project manager asks for a red pen to add details to the orangutan drawing, and the marketing expert draws a cat named Caramel.
3. The group discusses the financial objective of the project, which is to have a production cost lower than twelve point five Euros and have a selling price of twice that price to target a profit of fifty million Euros. They also discuss the possibility of the remote control being a single device or multi-device remote control.
4. The group shares design ideas and requirements, such as having few buttons, being lighted for use in the dark, fitting comfortably in the hand, and being resistant to shocks and waterproof. The idea of a whistle tracking feature is introduced, which is considered original and can improve the user experience.

1. The Welsh Government is working on simplifying the early childhood education and care system, which has grown complex over time with inputs from various sources. They are currently running pilot projects in eight local authorities to find ways of joining up the whole system.
2. The Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan AM, stated that the Welsh Government's approach is to support both children and parents, with a high-quality early childhood education and care system that can provide opportunities for parents to work while ensuring that children have the best possible start in life.
3. The Welsh Government is considering extending the Childcare Offer for Wales to parents who are in education and training, in addition to those who are already eligible. They are also looking at ways to make the system simpler and easier to understand.
4. The Flying Start programme, which is geographically targeted, uses data from income benefit to decide which areas it is delivered in. It provides support for children aged nought to three living in income-dependent households.
5. The foundation phase, which is part of the education improvement grant, has seen a 10 per cent reduction. While there is no evidence of lower standards in the foundation phase, the committee is concerned about the impact of fewer teaching assistants on the quality of teaching.
6. The Welsh Government is developing a more integrated approach towards the early years, encouraging the foundation phase to operate in more non-maintained settings and supporting co-location and partnership working between education and childcare providers through the capital investment programme.

1. Janet Finch-Saunders asked about the differences in early childhood education and care provision in different parts of Wales. Julie Morgan AM, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, acknowledged the variation and attributed it to historical reasons and the responsibility of local authorities in providing early education. She mentioned the pilot in Flintshire testing the impact of consistent funding rates for education and childcare and the importance of local authorities in the system.
2. Hefin David AM asked about the Welsh Government's approach to early childhood education and care, questioning whether it is more focused on child development or getting parents into work. Julie Morgan AM clarified that the goal is to support both children and parents, emphasizing the importance of high-quality early childhood education and care for both development and job opportunities.
3. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the pathfinders in eight local authority areas and their focus. Jo-Anne Daniels described the pathfinders as looking at ways of joining up the whole system of services provided by health boards and local authorities, with a focus on both children and parents.
4. Hefin David AM asked about the alignment of the Childcare Offer for Wales to the Foundation Phase and the possibility of merging policy and delivery teams. Julie Morgan AM mentioned guidance issued to support widening the number of non-maintained settings able to deliver early education and capital investment in co-located childcare facilities.
5. Janet Finch-Saunders asked about the Welsh Government's plans to address the big differences in early childhood education and care provision. Julie Morgan AM discussed the variation in provision, the role of local authorities and Flying Start, and the importance of developing facilities in each local authority throughout Wales.
6. Dawn Bowden AM asked about the impact of the childcare offer and the inclusion of parents in training and education. Julie Morgan AM mentioned the review of the programme and the intention to expand the offer to parents who are in education and training, with the review reporting early next year.

1. Julie Morgan, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, discussed the Welsh Government's approach to early childhood education and care during a scrutiny session. She emphasized the importance of supporting both children's development and parents' ability to work.
2. The Welsh Government is working on simplifying the complex early childhood education and care system, with pathfinder projects in eight local authorities examining ways to join up the system. An announcement about the direction of these changes is expected soon.
3. The pilot in Flintshire is testing the impact of consistent funding rates for education and childcare, with an independent evaluation due in November 2019.
4. In response to a question about the Childcare Offer for Wales, Julie Morgan mentioned the possibility of extending the offer to parents who are in education and training.
5. When asked about addressing differences in early childhood education and care provision across Wales, Julie Morgan highlighted historical reasons for the variation and the importance of local authorities in determining patterns of provision.
6. The Welsh Government is developing a more integrated approach to the early years, with the foundation phase being offered in more non-maintained settings and CIW and Estyn working together to inspect and regulate the early years sector.

1. The Welsh Government is working on simplifying the early childhood education and care system, which has grown complex over time with inputs from various sources. They are currently running pilot projects in eight local authorities to find ways of joining up the whole system and are looking to work with local authorities and health boards to simplify things.
2. The Welsh Government's approach to early childhood education and care aims to support both children and parents. They want to provide high-quality early childhood education and care that can support children's development and provide parents with the opportunity to work. They believe that this approach can also help reduce poverty by providing stable jobs for parents.
3. The Welsh Government is planning to extend the childcare offer to parents who are in education and training. They are also considering how to make the childcare offer more universally available and how to ensure quality in all settings. They are working on building a better understanding of the workforce's Welsh language skills to enable support for the sector to be targeted and to identify where capacity needs to be built for the future to meet the needs of the early years sector in a bilingual Wales.
4. The evaluation of the first year of the childcare offer showed limited impact, but the evaluation for year 2 is also expected to show a limited impact. The evaluation will be more meaningful in November 2020, and the Welsh Government expects to spend PS50 million to PS55 million in this financial year on the childcare offer. They are committed to making available the total funding that is needed to deliver on the offer and are managing it within the normal budgetary process. Local authorities will get the full funding that is needed, and there are no plans for them to find the extra money out of their own pots.

1. The group discussed the functional design of a new product, specifically focusing on the remote control. The remote control should turn the television on and off with one press, have a reliable and appropriate design, and be easy to find. The group also discussed the possibility of a remote control that changes size based on user preference.
2. The project manager mentioned that the company wants to establish a marketing or corporate image with this new product, and the management has proposed that the remote control should only be used for the TV. The project manager also introduced a new proposal for the project management and asked Christine to discuss the functional design.
3. Christine presented her ideas for the remote control, including user requirements such as turning the TV on and off with one press, and being able to find the remote control easily. She also mentioned the possibility of using materials that are popular and reliable for the outside of the product.
4. The marketing representative mentioned that the management is looking for a sales price of twenty-five Euros and a production price of twelve and a half Euros. The marketing representative also mentioned that there is a demand for speech recognition in remote controls, especially among the fifteen to thirty-five age group.
5. The group discussed the possibility of implementing speech recognition in the remote control, but there were concerns about the impact on battery life and the ability to filter out ambient sound and speech from the TV. The group agreed that if speech recognition is implemented, it should be able to recognize single words and have a specific word that it responds to. The group also discussed the possibility of using technology from companies like Intel or IBM for the speech recognition feature.

1. The meeting is about discussing the functional design of a product, specifically a remote control for a TV.
2. The project manager presents the new project requirements, which include not considering teletext in the design because of outdated technology, using the remote control only for the TV, and establishing a marketing or corporate image with the new product.
3. The industrial designer presents their ideas for the functional design, including identifying user requirements such as turning the TV on and off with one press of the button, making the device easy to find, and considering the corporate image and reliability in the construction materials.
4. The industrial designer suggests a remote control that changes size depending on user preference, with options for a very flexible and inflatable design in various colors or a clear design that blends in with the user's home decor.
5. The project manager suggests adding the feature of making the remote control unbreakable to increase its durability and appeal to families with kids.
6. The user interface brings up the issue of preconceived ideas about materials, specifically the difficulty of making something plastic unbreakable and the high cost of using materials like steel or titanium.
7. The marketing representative presents the management's desired sales price of twenty-five Euros and production price of twelve and a half Euros, and suggests taking a risk by adding features like speech recognition to appeal to the fifteen to thirty-five year-old age group.
8. The industrial designer raises concerns about training and battery life with speech recognition technology, and suggests adding wireless charging or solar power to address these issues.
9. The user interface raises concerns about ambient sound and speech on the TV interfering with speech recognition technology, and suggests finding a speech recognizer that can filter out these sounds.
10. The marketing representative suggests that a one-word recognition system could work for speech recognition technology, and the project manager offers to coordinate with technical companies for technical backup and information.

1. The meeting is about the functional design of a new project, specifically discussing the requirements for the remote control.
2. The remote control should only be used for TVs, not for teletext, as teletext is becoming outdated.
3. The remote control should be able to turn the TV on and off with one press of the button, and should be easy to find.
4. The remote control should establish the company's marketing or corporate image.
5. The remote control should have a big button for turning the TV on and off, and should be reliable and easy to find.
6. The remote control should have a flash when turned on and off, similar to the first remote control ever made, the Flashmatic.
7. The remote control should be flexible and inflatable, changing size depending on the user's preference. It should also be waterproof and give an oral cue when the TV has turned on or off.
8. The remote control should be unbreakable, especially for use in families with kids.
9. The remote control should have a sales price of 25 Euros and a production price of 12.50 Euros. It should also have speech recognition for simple commands like louder, softer, on, off, and change channel.
10. The remote control should be easy to use, with a long battery life and the ability to filter out ambient sound when using speech recognition.

1. The discussion focused on the components concept of industrial design for a remote control. The components in question include the energy source, case material, interface, and chips. For the energy source, the team considered solar energy, hand dynamo, kinetic technique, and regular battery. The case material options were wood, rubber, titanium, and latex. The interface could have simple buttons or more complex ones, and the chips would depend on the complexity of the interface.
2. The team discussed the possibility of using kinetic energy to recharge the remote control. However, there were concerns about whether the user would move enough to provide sufficient energy. They also discussed the user interface and how it could be made easy to use by representing buttons as figures, diagrams, or symbols on a graphical user interface.
3. The team received an email about a coffee machine that uses voice recognition technology. They considered the possibility of using voice recognition in the remote control, as well as a spinning wheel with an LCD display instead of buttons. They also discussed the possibility of a scroll button and customizable features for children, handicapped people, and old people. The team agreed to check with the R&D department to see if the kinetic metal is sufficient to provide enough energy and whether the voice recognition technology is ready for the market.

1. The meeting is about discussing the conceptual design of a remote control, specifically focusing on the components and interface design.
2. The industrial designer has reviewed the available components for building the remote control, including energy sources such as solar energy, hand dynamo, kinetic technique, or regular battery.
3. The case material for the remote control can be wood, rubber, titanium, or latex, but the choice depends mainly on aesthetics rather than technical considerations.
4. The interface can have simple buttons or scrolls, but the complexity of the chip to process the button commands will increase with more complicated interfaces.
5. The industrial designer suggests using a basic battery or kinetic energy collection as the energy source, as solar energy may not work well in a cluttered environment.
6. The user interface should be easy to use, with buttons that are comfortable to hold and a regular chip that is cheaper than a more complicated one.
7. The remote control's shape will be curved to fit comfortably in the user's hand, and the battery can be recharged using kinetic energy collected by moving the arm.
8. The marketing department suggests considering voice recognition technology, which is ready to be used, as an option for the remote control.
9. The group agrees to check with the R&D department to see if the kinetic energy collection is sufficient to provide enough energy for the remote control and to keep in touch with them regarding the design.

1. The meeting is about discussing the technical functions of a remote control for a television.
2. The remote control will use infrared signals to control the television and will use electrical energy to activate a chip in the remote.
3. The circuit board is the most important part of the remote control and can be made using fiberglass with copper wires.
4. The remote control will use standard and widely available components such as diodes, batteries, and LED lights.
5. The remote control should have basic functions such as channel selection, volume control, and a mute function.
6. The remote control should be easy to use and not too complicated, with at least 50% of users only using 10% of the buttons.
7. The remote control should have a trendy design, but it is important to consider that 75% of the market consists of elderly people who may not care as much about the design.
8. The remote control should not have too many features, as this may confuse elderly users.
9. The remote control should have a simple design with only basic TV functions, and there should be a distinction between the remote control for experts and novice users.

1. The meeting is a functional design meeting for a remote control project, presented by Maarten. The agenda includes three presentations, discussion of new project requirements, and a decision on the remote control functions.
2. The industrial designer presents the technical functions of the remote control, which uses electrical energy to activate a chip in the remote and sends infrared signals to control the television. The technology is known and widely available, with components like diodes, batteries, and LED lights.
3. The marketing expert shares research findings, including that three out of four people find remote controls ugly, three out of four users zap a lot, and fifty percent of users only use ten percent of the buttons on a remote control. The most important customers are in the age range of 36 to 65 years old.
4. The group discusses the remote control functions and decides to focus on basic functions like channels, on/off switch, volume, mute, and next/previous channel. They also consider implementing V_C_R_ and D_V_D_ functions but decide to group them in one button for less visual presence.
5. The group discusses the design and agrees on a trendy look, with the understanding that seventy percent of the market consists of elderly people who may not care for trendy looks. They also consider the corporate color and slogan in the design.
6. The group reviews new project requirements and decides to include a teletext button with on/off function and basic D_V_D_ functions like rewind and wind. They also discuss the target market and agree to aim at a younger market while still considering the needs of the older age group.
7. The group decides on the remote control functions, including zap buttons, numbers, teletext button, volume, and programme buttons. They also consider adding lights to the design.
8. The meeting is adjourned for a lunch break and individual work.

1. The team discussed the upcoming presentations on their work regarding a remote control project.
2. Catherine, the industrial designer, presented the working design of the remote control, including the energy source, the sender for the signal, and the user interface.
3. The team discussed the possibility of using an alternate energy source and the range of the infra-red signal.
4. Gabriel, the user interface designer, presented the user interface design and discussed the importance of maintaining basic functionality while improving existing designs.
5. Reissa, the marketing representative, presented the marketing report, which included user feedback on current remote controls and preferences for the new remote control.
6. The team discussed the possibility of incorporating a lock function, voice activation, and RSI-friendly design.
7. The team decided to go with infra-red technology and batteries for the remote control, keeping it simple and cost-effective.
8. The team discussed the importance of maintaining the company image and the possibility of offering different colors for the remote control.
9. The meeting concluded with the team discussing a few final details and deciding to take a break for lunch.

1. The group discussed the user interface (UI) presentation for their project, which is a television remote control. They talked about the function of the remote control, which includes an energy source (probably two batteries), a sender for the signal (an infra-red signal controlled by an electronic chip), and a user interface. They also discussed the possibility of using an alternate energy source, such as wind power or bicycle power, instead of batteries.
2. Catherine, the industrial designer, presented the working design of the remote control. She mentioned that the signal from the remote control can go through walls, and they can make it strong enough if they want. Marketing suggested using Bluetooth instead of infra-red, but the group decided not to overcomplicate things and stick with infra-red.
3. Gabriel, the UI designer, presented the user interface design. He mentioned that they want to improve what's out there and maintain the basic functionality that people want. He also mentioned that they need to find out what people want before making firm decisions on the design. The group also discussed the possibility of adding a lock function to the remote control.
4. Reissa, the marketing person, presented the marketing report. She observed remote control users in a usability lab and gave participants questionnaires to fill out. She found that 75% of users find the remote control ugly, 80% of them would spend more money if the remote control looked really cool and fancy, and 75% of users say that they only use ten percent of the buttons on a remote. She also suggested adding voice activation to the remote control, but the group decided not to pursue it due to manufacturing costs and the preferences of their target market.

1. The group discussed the marketing presentation and the names of the team members. The project manager wants to know everyone's names to avoid calling them "Miss Marketing" and similar titles.
2. The team discussed the design of the remote control, including the use of infra-red signal, battery power, and the user interface. They also talked about the possibility of using Bluetooth and solar power.
3. The team discussed the user interface design and the importance of maintaining basic functionality while improving the design. They also discussed the possibility of adding a lock function to the remote.
4. The marketing team presented their research on remote control users, including their preferences and pain points. They found that users want a remote control that looks cool and matches their operating behavior.
5. The team discussed the importance of making the remote control easy to use, especially for older people. They also discussed the possibility of adding voice activation to the remote.
6. The team decided to go with the simplest option for the remote control design, including the use of infra-red signal and battery power. They also discussed the importance of keeping the company image in mind when designing the remote.
7. The team discussed the possibility of adding different colors to the remote control and incorporating the company's colors and logo into the design. They also discussed the importance of making the remote control recognizable as a Real Reaction product.

1. Huw Morris, group director at SHELL, stated that the higher education Brexit working group has been meeting since September 2016 to discuss the potential impact of Brexit on higher education and further education. He also mentioned that officials have been visiting individual institutions to discuss their preparedness for a "no deal" scenario.
2. Marie Knox, deputy director overseeing European transition, mentioned the existence of a European transition team that meets fortnightly to discuss Brexit preparedness within the Welsh Government. She stated that the team provides a governance structure for the Welsh Government and leads discussions with the Department for Exiting the European Union, No. 10, and the Joint Ministerial Committee.

1. The Welsh Children, Young People and Education Committee held an evidence session on the impact of Brexit on higher and further education, with Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning.
2. The session included discussions on preparedness for Brexit, risk assessments, and the impact of Brexit on higher education and further education.
3. Higher education institutions have been conducting their own risk assessments, while the Welsh Government has been working with the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales to assess the sector's preparedness.
4. The Welsh Government has been engaging with further education colleges and has identified specific sectors of concern, including farming, health and social care, construction, manufacturing, and hospitality and tourism.
5. The European transition team has been established to coordinate the Welsh Government's response to Brexit and to provide governance for the Welsh Government's preparations.
6. The student voice is being taken into account through the Welsh Government's close working relationship with the National Union of Students.
7. The Welsh Government is working to maintain learning opportunities currently provided by European Union funding and to ensure that there is no negative impact on the quality of faculty.
8. The committee resolved to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting and the whole of the following week.

1. Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, discussed the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales during a committee meeting. They were joined by Huw Morris, group director at SHELL, and Marie Knox, deputy director overseeing European transition.
2. The committee discussed the preparedness of higher education institutions for Brexit, with Suzy Davies AM asking about sector analyses and risk assessments. Kirsty Williams AM mentioned that each institution has its own exposure and potential impact, and that officers have been visiting each institution to ensure they have their own plans in place. She also mentioned that they are working with officials in Westminster around Erasmus+ provision and Horizon 2020 impacts in a no deal scenario. Eluned Morgan AM added that the number of EU students in further education colleges is significantly lower, and that they are keeping in touch with them and letting them know what they can do to protect those 71. She also mentioned that about PS15 million a year goes into the FE sector just in relation to apprenticeships.

1. The meeting is a session of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education.
2. Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, are present to answer questions.
3. The committee welcomes Suzy Davies as a new member and thanks Mark Reckless and Darren Millar for their service.
4. There are no declarations of interest.
5. The committee discusses the preparedness of higher education institutions for Brexit, with a focus on the potential impact of a "no deal" scenario.
6. The Welsh Government has been working with higher education and further education institutions to understand the potential impact of Brexit and to form its views, which were articulated in the Government's White Paper, "Securing Wales' Future."
7. Each institution has been looking at their own institution's exposure to European Union students and projects, as the potential impact of leaving the EU is different for each institution.
8. The Welsh Government has been working with officials in Westminster around Erasmus+ provision in a "no deal" scenario and the impacts of a "no deal" on Horizon 2020.
9. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales has been doing specific work on Brexit and its impact on higher education, but it is unclear how wide they would want that to be shared.
10. The Welsh Government has been engaging with further education colleges and ColegauCymru to understand the potential impact of Brexit on the sector, particularly in relation to European social fund funding and apprenticeships.

1. The team has completed the prototype of the project and evaluated its design and functionality. They discussed the look and feel of the product, technical innovation, ease of use, fashion element, and recognizability of the Real Reaction product. The prototype received an average score of 1.8 out of 7, with 1 being true and 7 being false.
2. The team also discussed the budget requirements and the need to reduce the cost of the prototype from thirteen point seven to twelve point five. They considered various options to achieve this, such as using a plastic case instead of rubber, simplifying the product, and reducing the number of special colors and forms. They also discussed the possibility of using battery power instead of kinetic energy and the impact of these changes on the product's technical innovation and fashion element.

1. The group is discussing the design of a remote control for a television. They are considering a single-function remote control, which is simpler to use and more internationally sellable. They are also considering including illuminated buttons, an alarm to find the remote if it is lost, and a way to make the remote control environmentally friendly.
2. The group is also discussing the functional requirements of the remote control. They have found that seventy-five percent of users of remote controls find them ugly, and eighty percent of users would spend more money on a remote control that looked fancy. They are also considering making the remote control compatible with different brands of television devices, rather than other entertainment devices.

1. The group discussed the components design of the remote control during a conceptual design meeting. The main components considered were the case, power supply, and means of communication with the television set.
2. The team decided to use a curved design for the case and explored different materials. They initially considered rubber, but it was eliminated due to heat issues. Plastic was also eliminated due to its tendency to melt and become brittle over time. Titanium was also ruled out as it was deemed impossible to make curved cases out of it. The only remaining option was wood, which was considered environmentally friendly.
3. The group also discussed the chips to be used in the remote control. They considered simple chips, regular chips, and an advanced chip on print. The advanced chip on print was chosen due to its infrared sender, which was deemed important for finding the right chip. Manufacturing had also recently developed a sensor and speaker to be integrated into this advanced chip on print.
4. The team discussed the possibility of using exotic woods and allowing users to customize their cases. They also considered incorporating solar cells, microphones, and speakers into the advanced chip on print.
5. Another team member presented a design with an on-off switch, volume and channel control, menu access button, ergonomic shape, and a number pad. They also suggested a flip screen to prevent accidental button presses and a battery life-light to indicate when the battery is running low.
6. The marketing team presented their findings based on consumer surveys. They found that consumers are looking for fancy, feel-good, and easy-to-use remotes with the next generation of innovation. Consumers are also willing to pay a premium for exciting technology.
7. The team discussed the possibility of incorporating a display into the remote control. However, they were unsure about its usefulness, given that a big display is already present in front of the user. They decided to wait for more information on the cost of adding a display before making a decision.
8. The team decided to create a prototype of the remote control with a wooden case and the advanced chip on print. They also agreed to come up with a marketing strategy and determine the cost of adding a display. The next meeting would be used to discuss these findings and make further decisions.

1. The meeting was about discussing the conceptual design of a remote control and deciding on the remote control concept and functional design. The main presentations were given by Christine, Agnes, and Ed, focusing on the components concept.

1. The meeting is a continuation of a previous meeting where the team decided to create a simple remote control interface with a wheel to change channels, protected button for channel digits, buttons for volume, and power on/off. The remote control will not have LCD or voice features to keep costs low and development fast.
2. The Industrial Designer presents their conceptual specification and discusses the use of a wheel sensor, which is much more expensive than push buttons. The team discusses the possibility of combining the wheel sensor with push buttons or finding a cheaper wheel sensor.
3. The User Interface Designer presents their specification and shows examples of current remote control designs. The team agrees to simplify the design by removing unnecessary buttons and making the volume and channel controls bigger. They also discuss the possibility of placing the channel numbers on the side of the remote control.
4. The Marketing team presents their recent investigation on remote control trends and shares that the most important aspect for remote controls is to be fancy look and feel, followed by technological innovation, and ease of use. They suggest that the remote control could have a fruit or vegetable form, and the material should be spongy.
5. The team agrees to keep the wheel feature as it is innovative and easy to use. They discuss the possibility of making the remote control in the shape of a banana or pear, as these fruits are ergonomic and fit well in hand. They also agree to use a spongy material for the remote control.
6. The team makes a decision to use a standard battery, a specific chip imprint, and an odd shape with a spongy cover for the remote control. They also decide to place the wheel on the top and buttons on both sides of the remote control to make it comfortable for both right and left-hand users. The Industrial Designer and User Interface Designer are tasked to work together to create a prototype of the remote control.

1. The group is discussing the data collection routine for a project involving a computer system that provides information to tourists.
2. They plan to have subjects perform tasks and record dialogues with the system, which will help them study how people phrase different intentions and the types of decisions made during tourist activities.
3. The system will have a limited set of places and activities to focus on, making it easier to handle the data and build a prototype.
4. The group is considering whether to include more complex sets of tasks and activities or keep it simple with fewer variations.
5. They discuss the importance of deciding what components of the system will care about the level of detail in the ontology or types of places.
6. The speech people will benefit from having more pronunciations of the same thing rather than fewer pronunciations of many things.
7. The group plans to review the data collected from ten subjects after a couple of weeks and make adjustments as needed.
8. They will use the audio from the web page for the review and consider purchasing another disk if needed.
9. The group agrees on the importance of starting with a relatively straightforward response system before moving on to more complex, multi-step planning scenarios.

1. The focus of the meeting was to work on the semantics of the belief-net, which will be the main inference engine for the system's decision-making process. Decisions will turn out to be parameter choices for calls on other modules.
2. The group needs to figure out what all the choices are, what influences these choices, and do technical work on the actual belief relations and probabilities.
3. The group is also working on what should be in the dialogues, as they plan to have subjects record dialogues in the near future.
4. Robert has laid out a table of the kinds of things that might come up and the kinds of decisions, with decision nodes and discrete values on the left.
5. The group is planning to start data collection with thirty subjects and is looking for a room on the sixth floor to conduct the study.
6. The group discussed the possibility of limiting the detail of their ontology or types of places that someone could go, as it may simplify the data collection process.
7. The group also discussed the possibility of having a prototype system that only handles a few things, as it may be easier to handle.
8. The group plans to review the data collection after ten subjects have been tested and make adjustments as needed.
9. The group also discussed the importance of deciding what things are actually going to matter to them in terms of linguistics and what constructions people use.

1. The team meets to discuss a new project for designing a trendy and user-friendly remote control for a television set. The project will be divided into three phases, with the first phase focusing on functional design.
2. The team uses an electronic whiteboard to draw their favorite animals and discuss what they like about them. The user interface designer draws a dolphin, marketing draws an elephant, and the industrial designer draws a tiger. They discuss the importance of high-responsiveness, efficiency, and teamwork in their designs.
3. The team shares their initial ideas for the new product. They discuss the importance of an intuitive design, considering other design aspects and usability for people with disabilities, using lightweight materials, and setting a selling price of 25 Euros with a production price of approximately 12.5 Euros.
4. The team shares their expertise, with the marketing expert mentioning some ideas they have and the project manager reminding them that their personal coach will provide them with personalized assignments. The meeting is adjourned, and they plan to reconvene in thirty minutes.

1. The marketing team suggests incorporating voice recognition software in the new remote control, but they have concerns about the training period required for the remote to get better over time and the potential for regional accent recognition issues.
2. The user interface designer proposes a user-focused design approach that pares down functions to what is most likely to be used, with a programmable remote that allows users to specify what they want to access easily.
3. The industrial designer presents the internal workings of the remote control, including the energy source, user interface, sender, chip, and digital signal. They discuss the possibility of using buttons or light bulbs on the user interface and the potential challenges of adding a joystick.
4. The project manager expresses concerns about the power, cost, and feasibility of implementing voice-activated control for an embedded system. They propose the idea of a joystick and LCD for additional functionality.
5. The team discusses the potential target audience for the remote control, with the marketing expert suggesting that it could be aimed at most people who have used a mobile phone. They consider the possibility of selling the remote to TV manufacturers.
6. The team discusses the idea of incorporating a feature to locate the remote control if it is lost, such as a beeping noise or a flashing light. They consider the use of a small transmitter attached to the TV and a microphone or speaker on the remote control.
7. The user interface designer emphasizes the importance of making the remote control easy to use one-handedly, with the joystick controlled by the thumb. They also mention the need to define the software side of the interface based on the most frequently used options.
8. The team discusses the feasibility of the minimalist approach, with a joystick to control basic functions and the ability to manipulate it like a mobile phone. They agree to look into the idea and consider the time frame for implementation.

1. The meeting is a discussion about the conceptual design phase of a project, including the conceptual specification of components and design, as well as trend-watching. The group has 40 minutes and will go through an agenda including presentations, a decision on remote control concepts, and a closing.
2. The marketing team has done trend-watching and found that the most important factor for the target group (people aged 60-80) is a fancy design, followed by innovativeness and ease of use. The older people prefer dark colors, recognizable shapes, and familiar materials, especially wood. The trend-watchers advise that the remote control and docking station should be telephone-shaped.
3. The user interface team presents their research on designing the interface of the remote control. They suggest using a few buttons, speech recognition, and a small display. They propose focusing on primary functions, using large buttons, and adding new attractive functions such as speech recognition and a special button for selecting subtitles.
4. The industrial designer presents options for the components design, including a basic battery or kinetic energy as an optional source, a flat or curved casing, plastic or rubber buttons, and an advanced chip-set for the LCD screen. The group discusses the possibility of using kinetic energy, but decides against it due to the impracticality for the target group and the potential increase in production price. They also discuss the possibility of a docking station, which could help elderly people keep track of their remote control and serve as a marketing tool.

1. The project manager created separate folders for the shared project documents to keep them organized.
2. The team discussed the prototype presentation and evaluation criteria for the remote control design.
3. The team evaluated the design based on factors such as being fancy, innovative, and easy to use for both younger and older people. They rated each factor on a scale of 1 to 7.

1. The meeting is a functional design meeting for a project with the objective of putting fashion in electronics. The agenda includes discussing general objectives, new project requirements, and making a decision on remote control functions.
2. Marketing presented the functional requirements of the project based on market research. The research showed that people think remotes are ugly and are willing to pay more for a fancier looking remote. Younger people are more inclined to want voice recognition while older people are not. The biggest frustration for people is losing their remotes and difficulty in learning how to use them.
3. User Interface presented the technical functions design of the remote control. The user interface should be designed with design specifications in mind, taking into account technological and economic practicalities. Remote controls are a standard piece of equipment and should be fairly conventional in design, but there is room for novel ideas.
4. Industrial Designer emphasized the need for simplicity, ease of use, big buttons for frequently used functions, and a device that looks cool and feels good.
5. The team discussed the possibility of a rechargeable battery and a charging station for the remote control.
6. The team decided to focus on the fifteen to thirty-five age group, but will consider an income group as the target market instead of a specific age group.
7. The team agreed on the following functions for the remote control: keeping it from getting lost, large buttons for essential functions, a possibility to get extra functions, fashionable design, and a rechargeable battery.

1. The team is discussing the redesign of a conceptual remote control with a limited budget. They are considering various features such as buttons, LCD screen, chip-on-print, sensor, kinetic energy, and special color of buttons. They are also discussing the possibility of dropping certain features to save costs.
2. They are comparing the costs and benefits of using a hand dynamo, regular battery, and kinetic energy as power sources. They are also discussing the possibility of using an integrated scroll-wheel push-button instead of individual buttons.
3. They are discussing the user interface and the importance of ease of use, functionality, and aesthetics. They are also discussing the possibility of using a special color for the remote control to make it more appealing to the target market.
4. They are discussing the marketing strategy and the importance of meeting user requirements, trends, and the company's marketing strategy. They are also discussing the possibility of using a seven-point scale to evaluate the design based on criteria such as matching the operating behavior of the young user, relevant and most used functions, ease of use, technology innovation, and fancy look and feel.

1. The project manager starts the meeting by discussing the functional design phase and reviewing the minutes of the last meeting.
2. The marketing team presents their findings from user research, which includes the importance of having a beep function to find the remote control and the desire for speech recognition technology.
3. The user interface team presents their ideas for the design of the remote control, including the use of changeable covers and a more durable design.
4. The industrial designer discusses the technical aspects of the remote control, including the use of a circuit board and the potential challenges of implementing a universal remote control.

1. The meeting discussed the functional design phase of a project and presented the minutes of the last meeting. Three presentations were given, one each by the marketing director, user interface designer, and industrial designer.
2. The marketing director presented the findings of a user survey, which revealed that 75% of users find most remote controls ugly, and

1. The team discussed the prototype presentation of a new product design, which is based on a mango shape and has buttons accessible from the thumb for easy use.
2. They evaluated the design, discussed the placement of the L\_E\_D\_ and power buttons, and considered the use of a plus button for numbers larger than ten.
3. The team also discussed the ergonomics of the design and how it may help reduce repetitive stress injury.
4. They reviewed the use of a spongy rubber material for the remote, which is often used in stress balls, and passed it around for everyone to feel.
5. The team discussed the color options for the product, considering a limited range of colors for the prototype but planning to offer interchangeable casing in different fruit-themed color combinations.
6. They evaluated the prototype based on predetermined criteria, giving it a score of around two out of seven, indicating general satisfaction with the design.
7. The team also discussed the budget, confirming that the product is under budget and that the operating cost is 1220 Euros.
8. They evaluated their project leadership, teamwork, and means, giving positive feedback and identifying areas for improvement.
