1. The team discussed the prototype presentation of a product resembling a mango shape with buttons accessible from the thumb, and a kinetic energy feature. They also discussed the use of a special color and material, and the possibility of interchangeable plates.
2. The team evaluated the product based on various criteria, such as whether it is technologically innovative, easy to use, good-looking, and minimizes the effects of repeated strain injury. They also discussed the company color and logo, and staying true to their motto of putting fashion into electronics.
3. The team calculated the production costs of the product, including the use of kinetic energy, a regular chip, plastic and rubber, a special color for the case and buttons, push button interface, and a special form and material. They found that they were just barely under budget.
4. The team discussed leadership, teamwork, and the project means. They felt that there was room for creativity, but were limited by resources. They also discussed the need for more time and materials, and the satisfactory means, including computer programs and new ideas found through discussion.
5. The team concluded that the costs are within budget, the product has been evaluated generally positively, and they need to complete the final questionnaire and meeting summary. They plan to celebrate in an unspecified way.

1. The meeting began with a prototype presentation of a new remote control design, shaped like a mango and featuring a circular design for the numbers to improve ergonomics and reduce repetitive stress injury. The team discussed the use of a plus button to access channels above ten, and debated whether to press the plus first or the channel number first.
2. The team then evaluated the prototype based on pre-determined criteria, giving it a score of 1.9 out of 2. They discussed the challenges of incorporating the company color and logo, and debated whether to use interchangeable plates for different fruit themes. The team also discussed the budget, confirming that they were able to stay within budget despite the use of kinetic energy and a special color for the buttons. The meeting concluded with a discussion of leadership, teamwork, and the resources used in the project.

1. The meeting is being held to design a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly. The project will be divided into three phases: functional, architectural, and detailed design.
2. Ebenezer Ademesoye, the Marketing Expert, drew an elephant as his favorite animal, emphasizing its good memory and size. Tarik Rahman, the Industrial Designer, drew a tiger because he likes its appearance and the fear it evokes. Dave Cochrane, the User Interface Defin Designer, drew a monkey as an oblique reference to his three-year-old daughter, who is affectionately known as Miss Monkey.
3. The project finance is set at twelve point five Euros per unit, with a goal of selling them for twenty-five Euros each. The team aims to make fifty million Euros, which requires selling a significant number of units.
4. The team discussed ideas for the new remote control, including touch screen LCD remotes with sophisticated programming options and a lower-priced remote with similar functionality using a conventional push-button design. The idea of a remote that can operate multiple units in an integrated fashion with limited macro programming facilities was also proposed.
5. The team also discussed the potential for a remote control designed specifically for gaming and interactive television, with larger buttons and easy navigation. The importance of ergonomics and a biomorphic design was emphasized. The meeting concluded with the agreement to write up the ideas and distribute them to the team members.

1. The group discussed the eligibility for free school meals as a measure for identifying pupils to target for support in schools.
2. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, stated that while the eligibility for free school meals may not be a perfect measure, it is the best available proxy for identifying a child in need.
3. The group discussed the possibility of changing the once-a-year eligibility determination to a more flexible system, similar to the "Ever 6" concept used in England.
4. The Cabinet Secretary stated that while an "Ever 2" concept is being considered, the cost of implementing an "Ever 6" system in Wales would be around £40 million, which is not currently available.
5. The group discussed the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) and whether the guidance for its use is sufficient.
6. The Cabinet Secretary stated that new PDG regional advisers have been appointed to spread good practice and ensure more consistent usage of the grant.
7. The group discussed the use of PDG for more able and talented children and the importance of identifying and supporting these students.
8. The Cabinet Secretary emphasized the need for PDG to be used strategically and consistently across all schools, and for schools to demonstrate evidence of impact.

1. The group discussed the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) in schools and its impact on educational outcomes. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, along with Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Ruth Conway, deputy director, support for learners division, were present to answer questions.
2. The group discussed the targeting of the PDG and whether it is being used appropriately. The Cabinet Secretary stated that individual interventions should only be targeted at children who are eligible for free school meals, but schools may use PDG funding for universal interventions if they can demonstrate that they have a disproportionate effect on the outcomes for children on free school meals.
3. The group also discussed the use of PDG for more able and talented children. The Cabinet Secretary stated that PDG should be used to support the potential of all children, including those who are more able and talented.
4. The group discussed the eligibility for free school meals as a measure for identifying which pupils to target and the flexibility of the once-a-year eligibility. The Cabinet Secretary stated that they are giving thought to greater flexibility and maybe longer term projections for schools to know their allocation for a number of years ahead.
5. The group also discussed the impact of PDG on attendance and exclusion rates for children who have free school meals. The Cabinet Secretary stated that there is still a gap between the attendance of free-school-meal pupils and non-free-school-meal pupils, and that PDG can be used to support this particular agenda.

1. The paper discusses the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) in Wales, which is targeted at children eligible for free school meals and those who are looked-after or adopted. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, and other officials are questioned about the effectiveness and targeting of the PDG.
2. The PDG can be used for both individual interventions for eligible children and universal interventions that have a disproportionate effect on the outcomes of eligible children.

1. The text is about a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in the National Assembly for Wales, discussing targeted funding to improve educational outcomes.
2. Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Ruth Conway, deputy director, support for learners division, are present to answer questions.
3. The committee is discussing the targeting of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) and its impact on educational outcomes, particularly for vulnerable learners.
4. The Cabinet Secretary emphasizes that individual interventions should only be targeted at children who are eligible for free school meals, but schools can use PDG funding for universal interventions if they can demonstrate a disproportionate effect on the outcomes for children on free school meals.
5. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledges concerns about the identification and support of more able and talented children, and encourages the use of PDG for this purpose.
6. The committee raises concerns about the guidance and awareness of how the PDG should be used at the coalface, and the Cabinet Secretary mentions the role of new PDG regional advisers in spreading good practice.
7. The committee also discusses the use of free school meals as a proxy for identifying children in need of additional support, and the challenges of the current system, such as the once-a-year eligibility check and the potential impact of universal credit.
8. The Cabinet Secretary mentions the need for greater flexibility in the system and the ongoing discussions about decisions for the next two years.
9. The committee discusses the practical uses of the PDG and the importance of leadership in schools for effective deployment of the grant.
10. The Cabinet Secretary emphasizes the importance of attendance and engagement with education for children who have free school meals, and mentions some examples of good practice in using PDG to support attendance.

1. The Schools Challenge Cymru program was a time-limited initiative aimed at improving the performance of 39 schools in Wales. The program has ended, but the Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, believes that the investment in regional school improvement capacity will continue to have a positive impact.
2. The Cabinet Secretary has visited many Schools Challenge Cymru schools and has spoken with teachers about their experiences in the program. She is confident that the schools are receiving appropriate levels of support and that the lessons learned from the program are being applied across the education system. However, some critics have suggested that the program was not given enough time to have a significant impact and that the transition out of the program was not well-managed.

1. The group discussed the progress of the EDU project, including the continuation of data collection and the involvement of a new cognitive science student. The SmartKom project was also discussed, with a mention of issues with the synthesis that should be resolved soon.
2. Eva presented an update on her work with PRMs, including the construction of classes and dependency models, and the potential for using PRMs to make inferencing more efficient. The output of the model makes two decisions: how desirable a site is and the mode of visit.
3. The group discussed the possibility of using an interpreter for PRMs and the potential benefits of using PRMs, such as the ability to instantiate objects and express information in a way that is not possible with traditional belief nets.
4. The group discussed the potential for using PRMs in a travel planning context, with the ability to take in data about multiple sites and make decisions based on that data.
5. A visitor from the International University, Andreas, introduced himself and discussed his work on content management systems and the need for a standardized way of representing information in these systems.
6. The group discussed the potential for using PRMs in the Heidelberg project and the similarities between the issues faced in the two projects. The group also discussed the potential for using FrameNet to improve the understanding of the content in these systems.

1. The group discussed adding support for DVD players to the remote controls, with the marketing representative suggesting a clear layout with grouped buttons for different functions.
2. The remote control is intended to be used for international markets and support different equipment, with a selling price of twenty-five Euros and a production cost limit of twelve Euros fifty.
3. The group emphasized the importance of user-friendliness and agreed that it should be a priority in the design process.

1. The Industrial Designer presented their ideas for the technical design of a remote control, including the user interface and the functions it should have. The user interface would consist of two parts: voice command and buttons. The buttons would be divided into four sets: for choosing devices, for special navigation in space, for linear access of medium, and for random access. The voice command feature would allow users to assign any command to any button, as long as there is enough processing power.
2. The Marketing team presented the results of a usability lab study, which showed that 75% of users find most remote controls ugly, 80% would spend more money for a fancy-looking remote control, 50% of users zap a lot, and 50% of users only use 10% of the buttons on their remote controls. Based on these findings, the Marketing team suggested that the remote control should be easy to use, have a simple design, have a way to find it easily in the room, and have buttons that are resistant to shock and easy to press. The Industrial Designer added that the remote control should be ergonomic to prevent tendonitis.

1. During a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee, Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, discussed the draft strategy 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales'. He stated that the strategy is an all-age approach and expressed confidence that it will deliver for children and young people.
2. Dr Atherton mentioned that the strategy has engaged with children and young people through various forums, including schools and a session with youth ambassadors. He also mentioned a toolkit produced for schools to encourage their involvement in the consultation process.
3. When asked about targets for reducing obesity among children, Dr Atherton clarified that while he did not advise against having a target, the target should be deliverable and challenging. He also mentioned the importance of performance management and evaluation in achieving the strategy's goals.
4. Dr Atherton and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the level of investment needed to implement the plan. They mentioned that existing programmes would be evaluated for effectiveness and value, and there may be a case for new investment.
5. The conversation also covered the use of revenue from the levy on soft drinks for efforts to reduce childhood obesity. Dr Atherton expressed a preference for not hypothecating the revenue but rather considering the totality of resource that goes into public health programmes.

1. The Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales draft strategy is an all-age strategy aimed at addressing the high prevalence of overweight and obesity among adults and children. The strategy focuses on the next generation and engaging with children and young people.
2. The Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, is confident that the strategy will deliver for children and young people. During the consultation process, they have discussed with young people in various forums and visited schools to talk with teachers and students.
3. Dr Frank Atherton advised the Minister for health not to adopt the target of halving the prevalence of obesity in children, as it is more aspirational than deliverable. Instead, he suggested choosing a target that balances deliverability with challenge.
4. The level of investment needed to implement the plan has not been quantified yet, but it is estimated to be around PS8 million to PS10 million a year. The revenue from the levy on sugary soft drinks could potentially be used to support the plan, but Dr Frank Atherton is not in favor of hypothecation.
5. The strategy emphasizes a whole-system approach and partnership working to create a system that coordinates action and drives change across relevant partners. Dr Frank Atherton mentioned the importance of leadership and governance in driving the strategy forward.
6. The delivery of the plan will be led by a national implementation board that will be accountable to Ministers. Dr Frank Atherton believes that health should lead the strategy, but it needs broad ownership across government.
7. The main source of information on childhood obesity is the child measurement programme, which collects information on children entering school aged four or five. Dr Frank Atherton mentioned the need to consider a second measurement taking place in Wales to better understand the point at which children start to become overweight.

1. The Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales draft strategy aims to create a healthier environment for children and young people by reducing obesity and promoting healthy lifestyles. The strategy is an all-age approach, but there is a focus on children and young people as the next generation.
2. The strategy includes engagement with children and young people to inform its development. The Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the engagement efforts during the consultation process, including visits to schools and a session with youth ambassadors.
3. The strategy emphasizes leadership and a whole-system approach to implement the plan. A national implementation board will be established to oversee the plan and will be accountable to Ministers. The board will focus on creating a system that coordinates action and drives change across relevant partners, avoiding a situation where it's everyone's role, but nobody's responsibility.

1. Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the draft strategy 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' with the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
2. Dr Atherton expressed confidence that the strategy will deliver for children and young people, and discussed the engagement they have had with children and young people to inform the draft strategy, including visiting schools and discussing with youth ambassadors.
3. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about leadership and targets in the strategy, and Dr Atherton explained that they may consider a target but it needs to be balanced with deliverability, and that performance management and evaluation are important.
4. Sian Gwenllian AM also asked about investment, and Dr Atherton stated that resourcing will be important and that they will need to consider existing programmes and the potential for new investment.
5. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the use of revenue from the levy on soft drinks, and Dr Atherton expressed a preference for not hypothecating the revenue but rather considering the totality of resource that goes into public health programmes.
6. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about data and metrics, and Dr Atherton discussed the child measurement programme and the potential for a second measurement.

1. Dawn Bowden AM asked about the implementation of the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' plan and the use of legislative measures such as restricting price promotions and banning energy drinks. The Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton, stated that legislation may be one of the outcomes of the consultation, but the timing would depend on other pressures and the availability of resources.
2. Dr Frank Atherton also discussed the potential use of the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways around schools and improve community sport infrastructure in new schools. He expressed support for the idea, but noted that the effectiveness of such measures needs to be studied and that health impact assessments should be used more extensively to inform policy decisions.

1. The last meeting discussed the presentation by the Industrial Designer regarding the new remote control for TVs. The remote will have nine channel buttons, next button, volume buttons, subtitle buttons, switch to control features, color contrast, sharpness, a memory switch, and a mute button. The designer also suggested incorporating speech recognition as a favorite feature.
2. The designer proposed a child-friendly design with few buttons, colorful appearance, and star-shaped or other shaped buttons. She also presented an oversized remote that she guarantees will never be lost.
3. The marketing expert suggested that the remote should be small, easy to use, and eye-catching. The special feature of the remote should be a speech recognizer, and the energy should be battery-operated. The campaign should focus on one or two features, and the remote should have a fruit and vegetable design with a soft feel.
4. The team discussed the prototype of the remote, which has a snail shape, blue color, yellow buttons, and compact shape. The material for the case is plastic, and the buttons are made of soft rubber. The light-emitting diode is a fluorescent green bulb like an ordinary infrared.
5. The remote includes a switch-on and off button, mute button, one to nine buttons for controlling programs, two buttons for increasing or decreasing volume, two buttons for scrolling up and down channels, a menu button, and a swapping button. The remote also has an inbuilt voice recognizer that recognizes the user's voice and acts accordingly.
6. The team agreed that the remote is easily accessible with one thumb, and the on-off button is in a prominent place. The color and design of the remote are attractive, and the mute button is on both sides, making it accessible for both left and right-handed users.
7. The team also discussed the budget and financing of the project. They agreed that the cost of the voice recognizer was not included in the budget, and they need to be careful about the quality of the voice recognizer that they can buy within their budget.

1. The group discussed the effects of room noise on the PDA microphones and the potential impact on dynamic range. It was concluded that quantization error is not a significant factor. A simple digital filter was suggested to remove room noise before processing the data.
2. The group talked about the use of high-pass filters in their software and the cut-off frequency used. It was mentioned that the STRUT implementation of the software has a pre-emphasis filter.
3. The group discussed the issue of latency in the PDA microphones and the potential impact on online normalization. It was noted that the new system has better latency but there is no real improvement in performance.
4. The group discussed the use of voice activity detection (VAD) and the differences in performance between different VADs. It was suggested that the French VAD performs significantly better than the baseline set of features.
5. The group discussed the upcoming meeting in June and the progress made on various projects, including the use of a second stream and the integration of spectral subtraction. It was noted that the French VAD performs significantly better than the baseline set of features.

1. The team discussed the merits and demerits of existing remote controls, focusing on user preferences and market trends.
2. The team found that users prefer fancy and visually appealing remote controls over functional ones, with the design and outlook being the most important factor.
3. The second and third most important factors were technological innovation and ease of use, respectively.
4. The team also discussed incorporating elements from recent fashion trends, such as fruits and vegetables, into the design of the remote control.
5. The team considered various materials for the remote control, including rubber and latex, to achieve a spongy and durable feel.
6. The team also discussed the possibility of incorporating speech recognition technology and a scroll wheel for ease of use.
7. The team agreed to create a prototype using clay and to explore different shapes, such as an hourglass or a banana, for the remote control.
8. The team decided to use a rechargeable battery and to keep the design simple to minimize costs.
9. The team will have their next meeting in half an hour to discuss further developments and to assign tasks.

1. The group is discussing a visit from Hans Guenter, who will be staying for three weeks to look at their work and possibly collaborate.
2. Grad E has been testing a spectral subtraction method for the SmartKom system and found that using a twelve-second window in the past to calculate the mean worked well, but using a shorter window resulted in a slight drop in performance.
3. Grad E also experimented with training models using different lengths of time and found that using a longer time for training did not significantly improve performance when using shorter windows for testing.
4. Professor C suggests that Grad E should think of the spectral subtraction as a filter and design it as such, which would allow for more flexibility in terms of start-up behavior and temporal and spectral characteristics.
5. The group discusses the possibility of using a second pass in the system to improve performance, where more complex processing is done after an initial pass to distinguish between top N possible utterances.
6. PhD B has been working on Wiener filtering and found that it improved the system by around 30% over the baseline, but did not meet a target of 50%.
7. PhD B also found that using the old VAD resulted in a baseline of 95.68, 89, and 40% for different mismatch conditions, and that the new VAD improved performance.
8. The group discusses the rules for an upcoming test and the use of files to ensure consistent boundaries for all systems.
9. The group also discusses the use of VAD and Wiener filtering in other systems and the potential for further improvement in their own system.

1. The group discussed the results of a recent wizard test, where a participant was asked to complete tasks using a system that was pretending to be both a human and a machine. They noted that the participant had difficulty with the tasks and suggested that the reading material should be shortened and the introduction for the wizard should be improved.
2. They also discussed the possibility of hiring Fey and adding her to the payroll. Professor B suggested that Lila could provide more information on how to do this.
3. The group talked about the possibility of having Johno tell them about his work and also discussed the interface, M-3-L enhancement.
4. Robert presented a pedagogical belief-net that he created to help conceptually organize the tasks and grouped things according to image schemas such as Trajector-landmark and Source-path-goal.
5. The group discussed the possibility of adding a summary node to the belief-net to avoid a combinatorial input problem. They also discussed the idea of making each node narrow enough to avoid this problem.
6. The group discussed the possibility of adding extra properties and deterministic rules to the existing SmartKom system as a minimal extension. They also discussed the idea of integrating the belief-net into the existing SmartKom system to create a module that can take input and output a decision.

1. The meeting discussed the conceptual design of a product, including the materials to be used, such as plastic and soft rubber, and the possibility of using titanium. The design should be sturdy, simple, and have a spongy feel. The color options were also discussed, with a preference for a two-tone look and a limit of two colors.

1. The meeting is introduced and the team members present their roles and functions. The team consists of a project manager, a marketing person, an industrial designer, and a user interface designer. The team will work individually on each type of design and then discuss their ideas in subsequent meetings. The industrial designer agrees and suggests that the design should be different, with the possibility of using different shapes and colors. The marketing person suggests that the remote should have a feature that allows it to be easily found when lost, such as a light sensor that activates a signal when the remote is in a dark spot. The project manager agrees and suggests that the sensor could be activated by a certain level of darkness. The team agrees to think about these ideas and come up with a working design in the next meeting.

1. The team discussed the design of a new remote control. The team consists of a project manager, marketing expert, user interface designer, and industrial designer. Each team member will have a different role in each phase of the design process.

1. The team discussed the functional requirements of a remote control for a television. They considered factors such as the size of the remote, the buttons, and the use of an LCD screen.
2. The team decided that the remote should have a low power usage and should be easy to use, with volume and channel buttons that are easy to find. They also discussed the possibility of using an LCD screen, but noted that it might be more expensive and could be difficult for some users to use.
3. The team also considered the target market for the remote. They noted that younger people are more interested in features like LCD screens and speech recognition, while older people are less interested in these features. They also discussed the fact that many users lose their remotes and find them ugly.
4. The team decided that the remote should have a mute button and should be able to switch between one-digit and two-digit numbers. They also discussed the possibility of including a button for teletext, but decided that it was not necessary.
5. The team also considered the possibility of using a rechargeable battery for the remote, but noted that it would be important to ensure that the batteries lasted long enough between charges. They also discussed the possibility of implementing speech recognition, but decided that it would be difficult to do and might not be necessary.

1. The meeting is a functional design meeting for a remote control project. The project manager, industrial designer, user interface expert, and marketing representative are present.

They suggest making the remote control easy to find and use, with a low power usage and large, clear buttons. They also suggest considering the needs of both younger and older users.
5. The group discusses the functional requirements of the remote control, including the need for a low power usage, easily findable volume and channel buttons, and a way to find buttons when the label is gone. They also discuss the possibility of using an LCD screen and the importance of making the remote control easy to use for both younger and older users. The group decides to use an LCD screen and to make the remote control easy to use for younger users while still being functional for older users. They also discuss the importance of affordability and the need to keep production costs low.

1. The group discussed the design of a remote control, focusing on its marketing, interface, and technical components.
2. The remote should be easy to use, attractive, and have a short learning curve. It could also have a child lock and a timer.
3. The interface designer suggested incorporating a voice recognition feature, which would allow users to switch channels by speaking.
4. The industrial designer discussed the technical components of the remote, including the case, integrated circuit, resistor, capacitor, diode, transistor, resonator, and battery.
5. The industrial designer explained how the remote works: when a button is pressed, it completes a circuit, which sends a signal to the chip. The chip then produces a morse code line signal specific to that button, which is amplified by the transistor and sent to the LED, which translates the signal into infrared light.
6. The marketing expert emphasized the importance of making the remote different from the competition, with a focus on small, simple, and eye-catching design. She suggested developing one or two standout features for the ad campaign.
7. The group decided on battery-powered energy, a chip on print, and a bright, colourful, trendy, and strong case.
8. They agreed on push-buttons for the user interface, with supplementary features such as a mute button and a swapping button. The voice recognition feature was added as a pending item for further research.
9. The industrial designer and user interface designer were tasked with creating a prototype using modelling clay, with specific instructions to be sent by their coaches. The group agreed to reconvene in thirty minutes.

1. The team discussed the cost control of their project and realized they had budget problems.

5. They used a seven-point scale to rate their product based on these criteria, with one being the highest ranking.
6. The team agreed that the product met most user requirements, but they were limited in design choices.

8. The team was satisfied with the product's conformity to the company's strategy and gave it a high ranking.
9. Overall, the team decided to launch the product, as they were within budget and the evaluation was positive.

1. The team came up with a new design for a remote control that meets user requirements and is fashionable, but they had to make changes to reduce costs. They flattened the design to make it more like a traditional remote control and removed some of the double curves to save two Euros, bringing the cost down to eleven Euros sixty.
2. The team evaluated the project and gave it a rating of two out of seven based on user requirements, trends, and company strategy. They felt that the product met all user requirements and was fashionable, but they were concerned about limiting customers by only offering a few design options.
3. Despite some reservations, the team decided to launch the product because it met all the evaluation criteria and was within budget. They celebrated with a champagne lunch.

5. The team had to make changes to the design due to budget problems, considering flattening the shape to save costs.
6. The team was happy with the design and felt they had a winning product, giving high ratings in project evaluation criteria.
7. The team was proud of their creativity, leadership, teamwork, and technical skills in the project process.
8. The team agreed to give everyone a raise and a couple of days' holiday pay as a bonus.
9. The team decided to round up the overall evaluation of the product to two, considering it a good evaluation.
10. The team was excited to launch the product and celebrate with a champagne lunch.

1. The team discussed the different components that could be used to make the remote control, including the circuit board, integrated circuit (or chip), diodes, transistors, resonators, resistors, capacitors, and LED. They also discussed the possibility of using different energy sources, such as a basic battery, a hand-powered dynamo, kinetic energy, or solar power.
2. The team considered different materials for the case of the remote control, such as metal, rubber, wood, and titanium. They also discussed the possibility of using interchangeable plates and the need for an LCD display if they used scroll buttons.
3. The team discussed the user interface and the different types of interfaces, such as graphical user interfaces and command interfaces. They decided to go with a command interface and discussed the need for symbols on the buttons to indicate their functions.
4. The team discussed the trend-watching report, which mentioned the importance of a fancy look-and-feel, technological innovation, and ease of use. The report also mentioned that fruits and vegetables would be a popular theme for clothes, shoes, and furniture in the coming year.
5. The team made several decisions, including using kinetic energy as the energy source, a regular chip, a plastic case with a rubber coating, and interchangeable plates. They also decided to use a command interface with symbols on the buttons and to consider the fruit and vegetable theme when designing the look-and-feel of the remote control.

1. The speakers are discussing a meeting about speech recognition technology, where different companies and researchers gather to share their findings and progress.
2. One of the main topics of discussion is the use of a voice activity detector and its impact on the performance of speech recognition systems. There seems to be some controversy over the use of this technology, with some parties claiming it gives an unfair advantage.
3. The speakers also mention the use of Gaussian classifiers and the importance of understanding the properties of the vectors used in these classifiers. They discuss the correlation and distribution of the elements in these vectors and how it affects the performance of the classifiers.
4. The speakers mention the use of critical band spectrum and the possibility of using two critical bands at the same time to improve the performance of speech recognition systems.

1. The text is a transcript of a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in Wales discussing the impact of Brexit on higher and further education.
2. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) is present to give evidence, including Dr David Blaney, Chief Executive, and Bethan Owen, Director of Institutional Engagement.
3. The committee asks about the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education so far, and Dr Blaney mentions uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe as a significant issue.
4. HEFCW has identified the exposure of the Welsh higher education sector to EU-sourced income, including EU students, structural funds, and EU research funding. There are signs of decreased applications from EU students and increased difficulties in collaborative research activities with EU partners.
5. The financial impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education is uncertain, but HEFCW is monitoring the situation and working with the Welsh Government to address potential challenges.
6. The committee also discusses other pressures on the Welsh higher education sector, including funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, infrastructure, and the potential consequences of the review of fees and funding in England.
7. The committee notes several papers, including a letter from the Cabinet Secretary for Education on the school organization code and a letter from the Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care on the Childcare Funding (Wales) Bill. The committee then moves into private session.

1. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) appears before the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales.
2. HEFCW expresses concern about the uncertainty surrounding Brexit and its potential impact on university finances, particularly in relation to EU students and research funding.
3. The committee discusses the potential impact of Brexit on EU student recruitment and the challenges facing the Welsh higher education sector, including funding pressures and the need for capital investment.
4. HEFCW outlines the steps they are taking to plan for various Brexit scenarios and to support Welsh universities in their planning, including working with the Welsh Government and the UK Government to ensure continued access to EU research funding.

1. The text is a transcript of a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in Wales discussing the impact of Brexit on higher and further education.
2. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales is present to give evidence, represented by Dr David Blaney and Bethan Owen.
3. The committee is interested in the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education, specifically in terms of the sector's exposure to EU-sourced income and the potential financial impact.
4. There has been a decrease in applications from EU and international students to Welsh institutions, while there has been an increase in applications to English institutions.
5. The main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector include the funding position, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, infrastructure and capital expenditure, and uncertainty around potential consequences of the review of fees and funding in England.
6. The committee is concerned about the potential for Wales to do less well than England in terms of EU student enrolment, but Bethan Owen notes that it is difficult to forecast until enrolments are made.
7. Llyr Gruffydd AM asks about the factors leading to the decrease in EU student applications, and Dr David Blaney suggests that it is due to a combination of changes in student support arrangements and the relative levels of investment in facilities between Wales and England.
8. The committee also discusses the potential impact of Brexit on research funding and collaborations, with Dr David Blaney noting that the Brexit deal may impact the capacity of Welsh and UK research infrastructure to play into broader collaborative activity across Europe.
9. The committee notes several papers, including a letter from the Cabinet Secretary for Education on the school organization code and a letter from the Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care on the Childcare Funding (Wales) Bill.

1. The text is a transcript of a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in Wales discussing the impact of Brexit on higher and further education.
2. The Chair, Hefin David, is absent and John Griffiths is appointed as the temporary Chair.
3. The committee welcomes the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, Dr David Blaney (chief executive), and Bethan Owen (director of institutional engagement).
4. The committee asks about the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education, and Dr Blaney mentions uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe as a significant issue.
5. Bethan Owen mentions a decrease in EU and international student applications to Welsh institutions, and Dr Blaney mentions the Anglocentric nature of the media and relatively better invested English institutions as possible reasons.
6. The main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector include the funding position, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, increased student expectations for modern facilities, and uncertainty about potential consequences from the review of fees and funding in England.
7. Darren Millar asks about the decrease in EU and non-EU student applications and Bethan Owen mentions a mix effect and perception of how welcome overseas and international students are.
8. The committee discusses financial forecasts and Bethan Owen mentions that the sector is expecting to receive a full forecast at the end of the month.
9. The committee discusses the Diamond report and its recommendations for re-establishing funding at Welsh institutions, and Dr Blaney mentions that the challenges introduced by Brexit are in addition to those addressed by the Diamond report.
10. The committee also discusses the potential impact of Brexit on researcher collaborations and networks, and Dr Blaney mentions the importance of maintaining the quality and impact of Welsh research.

1. The team discussed the design of a new remote control using Bluetooth technology. The remote control should only be used for the television and not be a multi-purpose remote control.
2. The Marketing Expert presented findings from a questionnaire, which showed that the age group of 16-45 years is the biggest audience and that they prefer simple remote controls with the most used functions, such as switching channels, teletext, and volume controls, being very clear.
3. The Industrial Designer discussed the current remote controls, which are all infrared and have a simple structure, and proposed the idea of incorporating Bluetooth or a radio receiver in the placeholder next to the TV, connected to the TV.
4. The User Interface Designer emphasized the importance of keeping the design simple and not including too many gadgets and functions. The most used buttons should be bigger and the minor functions should be combined to reduce the number of buttons.
5. The team discussed the use of teletext and the possibility of incorporating Bluetooth or a radio receiver in the placeholder next to the TV. The Industrial Designer proposed the idea of introducing a speech function in the remote control.
6. The team discussed the technical functions and usability of the remote control. The User Interface Designer emphasized the importance of combining the design, technical possibilities, and user-friendliness in one.
7. The team discussed the possibility of using a touch screen and the importance of keeping the remote control simple and easy to use. The Marketing Expert suggested using big pictures on the touch screen for elderly users.

1. The Welsh Baccalaureate is a qualification that aims to provide a broad and balanced curriculum for young people in Wales.
2. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams AM, values the qualification and believes it helps prepare students for further study and the world of work.
3. The qualification has been generally well-received by learners and teachers, but there have been concerns raised about workload and the impact on students' well-being.
4. The Cabinet Secretary believes that the qualification should be the norm for students, but recognizes that there may be cases where flexibility is needed to ensure the well-being of the student.
5. The value of the qualification is not consistently understood by employers, and the Government is working with Qualifications Wales to develop a joint communication plan to better engage employers.
6. There is variability in the way the Welsh Baccalaureate is delivered in schools, and the Cabinet Secretary is working with Qualifications Wales to ensure greater consistency.
7. The Cabinet Secretary is also working to ensure that teachers have the necessary skills and confidence to deliver the qualification effectively.
8. The Welsh Baccalaureate is regarded as an equivalent to an A-level by universities, and is used as part of the offer for competitive courses such as dentistry, medicine, and veterinary science.
9. The Cabinet Secretary is confident that the university sector regards the Welsh Baccalaureate as a valuable endeavor for Welsh students, and that it does not disadvantage them in any way.
10. The Cabinet Secretary expects all institutions to be in a position to deliver the Welsh Baccalaureate by 2020, and believes it should be an entitlement for Welsh students to be able to undertake this qualification.

1. The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to prohibit all forms of physical punishment of children to protect their rights and ensure equal protection from physical punishment as adults.
2. The Bill has received opposition from individuals and parents who understand the difference between child abuse and a light smack from a loving parent. However, the Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan, believes that the Bill is necessary to clarify the law and send a clear message that physical punishment of children is not acceptable.
3. The Bill does not create a new offence but removes the defence of reasonable punishment for the offence of common assault. The implementation group, which includes representatives from various organizations, has been set up to address issues related to the Bill's implementation.
4. The Bill's impact on public services, particularly social services, is unknown, but the implementation group is working to ensure a smooth transition.

1. The group discussed the presentation of an industrial designer on the energy source and case material design of a remote control. The industrial designer presented three options for the energy source: basic battery, hand dynamo, and kinetic provision of energy. The group decided to go with the basic battery as it is the least expensive option.
2. For the case material, the industrial designer presented five options: plastic, latex rubber, wood, and titanium. The group decided to go with rubber, as it is more ergonomic and can withstand being thrown. The group also decided to make the remote control double curved to fit the shape of a user's hand.
3. The group discussed the push-buttons for the remote control and decided to go with simple push-buttons instead of a scroll-wheel or LCD. The group also decided to use rubber push-buttons to match the case material.
4. The group discussed the possibility of using a sample sensor sample speaker thing, but decided against it as it would be the most expensive option and not very useful for a remote control.
5. The group also discussed the key layout and design, and decided to have a limited number of buttons including power, channel up, channel down, volume up, volume down, and a numerical keypad.
6. The group discussed the marketing aspect of the remote control and decided to make it look and feel fancier than current remote controls and make it technologically innovative.
7. The group also discussed the possibility of making the remote control in different colors to appeal to different demographics.

1. The project aims to create a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly. The team will be divided into three parts: functional design, conceptual design, and detailed design. Each team member will work on their own ideas and then collaborate with the rest of the team.

They disliked having to press multiple buttons to turn on the TV and the clutter of having multiple remotes. They also mentioned the need for a way to find lost remotes and the importance of easy-to-use buttons that are not too small. They also discussed the possibility of using a lithium battery to increase the lifespan of the remote.

They agreed on having one remote for the main functions, such as on, off, channel changing, and volume control, and another remote for special functions. They also discussed the importance of large buttons for older people or those with poor hand-eye coordination. They will continue to discuss and explore these ideas in their next meeting.

They plan to invest any extra profits in R&D for future products. The group suggested conducting focus groups with their target market and considering ways to simplify the remote's interface in future versions.

The remote has two scroll wheels for volume and channel control, and a turbo button for quickly scrolling through channels. The turbo button also serves as the on/off switch for the TV.

1. The project manager summarizes the decisions made in the last meeting, which include no LCD, no speech recognition technology, a banana look and feel for the remote control, use of wheels and buttons, and a base station for battery charging and remote calling.

4. The base station has a button for calling the remote control when it is lost. The leaves of the banana base station act as antennas to improve the signal range.

1. The meeting discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales, with Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning.
2. The Minister expressed gratitude to school staff, key workers, and parents for their efforts during the pandemic, and emphasized the importance of protecting public health.
3. Hefin David AM asked about the reopening of schools, and the Minister stated that it will depend on the advice of medical and scientific advisers, and cannot be done until it is safe.
4. The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on reopening schools, including the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, clear communication, and consideration of which groups of children should return first.
5. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the importance of testing in reopening schools, and the Minister agreed that it will be crucial in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic.
6. Dawn Bowden AM asked about the support available for vulnerable children, and the Minister stated that they are working across Government departments to ensure that vulnerable children are supported, whether they attend school or not.
7. The Minister also mentioned that they are working with further education and higher education institutions to share thinking on how to respond to the pandemic.
8. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the number of children and staff attending school hubs, and the Minister provided data on the number of children and staff attending, with the majority being children of key workers.
9. The Minister also mentioned that they are working to ensure the safety of staff and children in school hubs, and that they have seen a doubling in the number of vulnerable children attending since the start of the traditional summer term.

1. The meeting is being conducted remotely due to the coronavirus epidemic, with all participants joining via video conference.
2. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, are present to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
3. The Minister expresses gratitude to those who have kept schools open for vulnerable children and children of key workers, allowing them to continue their critical roles in responding to COVID-19.
4. The Minister outlines five principles that will guide her decision on when and how to reopen schools, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, clear communication, and operationalizing new approaches to education.
5. Hefin David AM asks when schools might reopen, to which the Minister responds that it will not be imminent and will depend on advice from the chief medical officer and chief scientific officer.
6. The Minister states that the principles for reopening schools also apply to further education colleges, and that they are working closely with the higher education sector to address challenges.
7. Sian Gwenllian AM raises concerns about reopening schools before adequate testing is in place, to which the Minister responds that they are not relaxing any restrictions and will only reopen schools when it is safe to do so.
8. The Minister provides data on the number of schools open and the number of children and staff attending, with the majority being children of key workers.
9. Dawn Bowden AM asks about support for vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs, to which the Minister responds that they are working across government departments to provide support and that schools are in regular contact with vulnerable children and their families.
10. The Minister discusses the importance of mental health support for children and young people during this time and that additional funding has been provided for school counselling, which can be used for telephone and video support as well as in-person counselling when possible.

1. The meeting is being held virtually to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
2. The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams AM, outlines her gratitude to those keeping schools open for vulnerable children and children of key workers, and expresses her pride in the school community's response to the crisis.
3. Hefin David AM asks about the five principles regarding the reopening of schools, to which Kirsty Williams AM responds that schools will move to a new phase when it is safe to do so, based on advice from the chief medical officer and chief scientific officer.
4. Kirsty Williams AM states that a return to normal is not imminent and that there are practical issues to consider before schools can reopen, such as social distancing and school transport.
5. Sian Gwenllian AM raises concerns about the mixed message conveyed by relaxing restrictions when testing has not been sufficiently developed, to which Kirsty Williams AM responds that they are not relaxing any issues around schools at present.
6. Dawn Bowden AM asks about the phased return of children to school, to which Kirsty Williams AM responds that the most vulnerable children, such as those with additional learning needs, may return first.

8. Sian Gwenllian AM asks about the number of children and staff attending school hubs, to which Kirsty Williams AM responds that, on average, 1% of children in Wales attend these locations, with 85% being vulnerable children.

1. Kirsty Williams AM, the Minister for Education, discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee. She expressed gratitude to school staff, key workers, and parents for their efforts in keeping children safe and supporting remote learning.
2. The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when and how to reopen schools, including considering the safety and well-being of children, staff, and parents, ensuring clear communication, and addressing practical challenges such as social distancing and transportation. She emphasized that a return to normal is not imminent and that any decision will be based on medical and scientific advice.
3. The number of schools open and the number of children and staff attending them has been increasing since the start of the traditional summer term. Currently, 5.6% of the teaching population is working in school hubs, with 85% of the children attending being vulnerable or the children of key workers.
4. The Minister discussed the importance of supporting children with additional learning needs during this time, including providing specialist support where appropriate and ensuring that families are supported in their homes. She also mentioned that school counselling services are being expanded to provide remote support for children experiencing emotional and mental health difficulties.
5. The Minister acknowledged the risk of an increasing attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their more affluent peers due to varying access to digital resources. She stated that the Welsh Government is working to ensure equal access to learning for all children by providing hardware, connectivity, and digital learning resources where needed.

1. The text is a transcript of a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in Wales discussing the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
2. The meeting is being held remotely due to the pandemic, with all participants joining via video conference, and is being broadcast live on Senedd.tv.
3. The Welsh Government officials present include Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning.
4. The Minister expressed gratitude to all those working in the education sector for their efforts in keeping schools open for vulnerable children and children of key workers, and for supporting remote learning for other students.
5. The Minister outlined five principles that will guide the decision-making process for reopening schools, including considering the safety and well-being of students and staff, clear communication, and addressing the needs of specific groups of children.
6. The Minister also discussed the current situation of school hubs that are open, with an average of 1% of children in Wales attending, and 5.6% of the teaching population working in those hubs. Of the children attending, 85% are children of key workers and the remainder are vulnerable children.
7. The Minister answered questions from committee members on a range of topics, including the number of school staff tested for COVID-19, the challenges of supporting vulnerable children, and the impact of the pandemic on higher education and post-16 education.

1. The text is a transcript of a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in Wales discussing the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.

1. The Welsh Government has announced the closure of all schools in Wales due to the COVID-19 pandemic. From next week, schools will have a new purpose to support those most in need, including people involved in the immediate response to the coronavirus outbreak. The key areas that the Welsh Government is looking at are supporting and safeguarding the vulnerable and ensuring continuity of learning.
2. The Welsh Government has also announced that the summer exam series for GCSE, AS, and A-levels will not proceed. Learners due to sit these exams will be awarded a fair grade to recognize their work, drawing on a range of information that is available. The decision to cancel the exams was not taken lightly, but was necessary given the advice and recommendations received from a public health perspective and the situation that was developing on the ground.

1. The Welsh Government has decided to close all schools from a certain date due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision was made to protect the health and safety of staff and pupils, and to ensure continuity of education. From the following week, schools will have a new purpose, which includes supporting and safeguarding vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning for all children, including those who benefit from free school meals and children with additional learning needs.
2. The Welsh Government has also announced that the summer exam series for GCSE, AS, and A-levels will not proceed as planned. Instead, learners due to sit these exams will be awarded a fair grade to recognize their work, drawing on a range of information that is available. The decision was made to provide early certainty to students and staff. The Government is also working to ensure that students receive support for their mental health and well-being during this challenging time.

1. The Welsh Government held a meeting regarding the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales. The meeting was attended by Kirsty Williams, the Minister for Education; Steve Davies, director of the education directorate; Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning; and Rob Orford, chief scientific adviser for health.
2. The Minister for Education made an opening statement outlining the measures taken by the Welsh Government to address the challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic in the education sector. The decision to close all schools from March 23 was made to ensure public safety and protect all staff and pupils in educational settings. The Minister also announced that the summer exam series for learners due to sit exams will not proceed, and learners will be awarded a fair grade to recognize their work.
3. Members of the committee asked questions regarding the new purpose of schools, staffing, communication with parents, and the provision of free school meals during the school closures. The Minister and officials provided updates on the measures being taken to support vulnerable children, free school meals, and additional learning needs.
4. Members also asked questions regarding exams, the potential closures of colleges and universities, and the mental health and well-being of staff and learners. The Minister and officials provided assurances that student maintenance payments will continue as normal and that student well-being will be supported during the prolonged period of closure.
5. The Minister also discussed the emergency legislation and the powers it will provide Welsh Ministers, including the power to temporarily close schools or other educational institutions, childcare premises, and to give temporary continuity directions. The legislation will also provide flexibility to relax requirements around ratios in childcare settings and to direct resources.

1. The project manager, Sebastian, introduces the team and explains that the project is to develop a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly.
2. The team will follow the company's three-step project method: functional design, conceptual design, and detailed design.
3. The team will use the tools available in the meeting room, including the whiteboard, to take notes and make drawings.
4. Michael, the user interface designer, draws a spider on the whiteboard and talks about its characteristics.
5. Guillermo, the marketing expert, shares that when he was a child, he wanted to be a panther, and he likes it because it's fast, black, and powerful.
6. Hemant, the industrial designer, draws an elephant and talks about its peculiar way of walking and its usefulness to human beings.
7. The team discusses the target selling price of twenty-five Euros for the remote control, which should generate a profit of fifty million Euros.
8. The team needs to decide whether the remote control should be specific to a device or universal, and what people are willing to pay for it.
9. The team will have another meeting to discuss the product and the market.
10. The team members have tasks to do, such as working on the working design, technical functions, and user requirements specifications.

1. The team discussed a newsflash they received about the design of a new remote control. They talked about the features that should be included, such as an LCD screen and speech recognition, and decided to target users below the age of forty. They also discussed the corporate identity that should be incorporated in the design.
2. The team also discussed the layout of the remote control. They decided to put the power button on the top right corner, with the screen on top and the buttons in the middle for easy reach. They also discussed the possibility of adding LED lights under the buttons to indicate which functions are active. The team agreed to take a lunch break before continuing their work.

1. The team discussed the design of a remote control device, including the power supply, buttons, and circuit board. Options for the power supply include standard batteries, a dynamo, kinetic energy, and solar cells. The team considered the cost and functionality of each option.
2. The team decided on a simple push button design for the buttons, which would be supplied by Real Reaction. They also discussed the possibility of incorporating a scroll wheel, but decided against it due to cost and potential impact on the design.
3. The team considered the use of speech recognition technology, but decided that it would not affect the circuit board and could be added as an extra feature. They also discussed the possibility of using a kinetic power supply and the potential benefits and challenges of this option.
4. The team discussed the design of the remote control, including the possibility of using curves and the importance of considering the storage and packaging of the product. They also discussed the use of a rubber case and buttons, and the potential impact of this on the overall design and cost of the product.
5. The team made a number of decisions, including the use of a simple circuit board, simple push buttons, and a kinetic power supply. They also decided to incorporate a red apple-shaped standby button and to keep the design of the other buttons simple and self-explanatory. The team will now move forward with these decisions and continue to refine the design of the remote control.

1. The meeting is a follow-up to discuss the functional design of a remote control for a television. The project manager welcomes everyone and confirms the agenda, which includes discussing the minutes from the previous meeting, individual presentations, and making decisions about the functions of the remote control.
2. The minutes from the previous meeting are accepted by the group. The main points from the previous meeting include the product development and review, financial implications, a sales target of four million units, and the influence of Japanese design on the product.
3. The marketing representative presents research on user preferences for remote controls. The research shows that users dislike the current look and feel of remote controls and that fifty percent of users only use ten percent of the buttons. Eighty percent of users would spend more money on a remote control that looks fancy.
4. The user interface representative presents their ideas for the design of the remote control. They suggest a more streamlined volume with no extraneous functions and a focus on power, channel, and volume buttons. They also suggest an "enter" function for accessing additional features.
5. The industrial designer discusses the practicalities of how the remote control needs to work. They suggest using a battery as the energy source and incorporating a chip that translates button presses into a message that can be sent to the television. They also mention the importance of the user interface and the need for the remote control to be easy to repair or replace if something goes wrong.
6. The group discusses the possibility of including a rechargeable internal battery and a docking station for the remote control. This would make the remote control more convenient and economical for users, but it would also add to the cost of development.
7. The group agrees on the target group for the remote control, which is the younger end of the market. They also discuss the importance of making the remote control easy to use and decide on the functions, which include power, channel, volume, an "enter" key, and number keys. They also agree that additional features, such as screen and audio settings, should be controlled using the television's own control panel.

1. The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill was discussed in a scrutiny session of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
2. The witnesses included Sally Jenkins, chair of All Wales Heads of Children's Services, Alastair Birch, senior system leader for equalities and safeguarding at Pembrokeshire County Council, and Councillor Huw David, Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care.
3. The witnesses expressed their general support for the Bill, stating that the current law is ineffective and unclear in protecting the rights of the child. They emphasized the importance of upholding the rights of the child under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
4. The witnesses also discussed the potential unintended consequences of the Bill, including the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment and the importance of simplicity in the Bill. They also mentioned the need for adequate resources and support for parents and carers.
5. The witnesses were asked about the impact of the Bill on other services, such as housing and education. They mentioned the need for awareness raising and training for professionals in education settings.
6. The witnesses were also asked about the potential impact of the Bill on social services, including the capacity to deal with it and the potential unintended consequences. They mentioned the importance of involving families and carers in the implementation of the Bill.
7. The witnesses emphasized the need for a cultural change in how children are treated and cared for in Wales, and the importance of protecting children from harm.

1. The text is a summary of a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in the National Assembly for Wales, discussing the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.
2. The witnesses in the meeting were Sally Jenkins, chair of All Wales Heads of Children's Services, Alastair Birch, senior system leader for equalities and safeguarding at Pembrokeshire County Council, and Councillor Huw David, Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care and leader of Bridgend County Borough Council.
3. The witnesses were asked about their general support for the Bill, and they expressed their agreement that the current law is ineffective and unclear in protecting children's rights.
4. The witnesses also discussed the evidence that physical punishment is harmful to children, and how the Bill would bring clarity and improve children's positions within their families.
5. The witnesses emphasized the need for greater clarity around the definition of what constitutes corporal punishment, but agreed that it is not essential to be on the face of the Bill.
6. The witnesses also discussed the implementation of the Bill, and how local authorities have been involved in the process.
7. The witnesses were asked about the potential impact of the Bill on other services, such as housing and education, and they emphasized the need for awareness raising and training.
8. The witnesses were also asked about the potential unintended consequences of the Bill, and they agreed that if implemented carefully and with the right resources, there should not be any significant issues.
9. Finally, the witnesses discussed the potential impact of the Bill on existing local authority responsibilities, and they emphasized that the state's paramount role is to protect children from harm.

1. Alastair Birch, representing the Association of Directors of Education Wales, expressed support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill, stating that the rights of the child should be upheld and that the current legislation allowing for reasonable punishment is ineffective and unclear.
2. Sally Jenkins, representing the Association of Directors of Social Services, emphasized the need for greater clarity around the definition of what constitutes corporal punishment, but stated that it is not essential for it to be on the face of the Bill. She also mentioned the importance of simplicity in the Bill and the need for discussion during the implementation phase for nuancing.

1. The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to remove the defense of reasonable punishment from Welsh law and raise awareness about the impact of physical punishment on children.
2. The witnesses, including Sally Jenkins from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Alastair Birch from the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Huw David from the Welsh Local Government Association, support the Bill and believe that the current law is ineffective and unclear.
3. The witnesses emphasize the importance of upholding the rights of the child and following the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
4. The witnesses also highlight the negative impact of physical punishment on children, including emotional harm and the potential for it to lead to more serious abuse.
5. The witnesses support the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment, but it is not essential to be on the face of the Bill.
6. The witnesses emphasize the importance of awareness raising and involving families, carers, and parents in the implementation of the Bill.
7. The witnesses are confident that the Bill can be implemented without major impact on their capacity to deal with it, but further work is needed to determine the cost implications.
8. The witnesses also highlight the importance of addressing unintended consequences and ensuring that the Bill does not undermine existing local authority responsibilities.

1. The witnesses, including Sally Jenkins from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Alastair Birch from the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Huw David from the Welsh Local Government Association, expressed their support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill. They believe that the current law is ineffective and unclear, and that the rights of the child should be upheld.
2. The witnesses discussed the importance of awareness raising and training for educational professionals, as well as the need for clarity in the definition of corporal punishment. They also mentioned the potential impact on social services, including the need for resources and a major awareness-raising campaign. The witnesses emphasized that the focus should be on supporting parents and families, and that the implementation phase of the Bill is crucial.

1. The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to remove the defense of reasonable punishment from Welsh law and make it clear that physical punishment is not acceptable.
2. The witnesses, representing the Association of Directors of Social Services, the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and the Welsh Local Government Association, expressed their support for the Bill and emphasized the importance of upholding the rights of the child.
3. The witnesses highlighted evidence that physical punishment can be emotionally damaging for children and that removing the defense of reasonable punishment would improve children's positions within their families.
4. The witnesses also mentioned that the current law can be ambiguous and that clarifying it would help shift the culture towards recognizing the importance of physically safe environments for children.
5. The witnesses emphasized the need for awareness raising and training for professionals, particularly in the education sector, to ensure that they are clear about how to support the implementation of the Bill.
6. The witnesses also discussed the importance of resources for implementing the Bill and ensuring that families are supported, rather than criminalized.
7. The witnesses noted that the costs of implementing the Bill are not yet fully identified, but that they will work with Welsh Government to quantify those costs.
8. The witnesses welcomed the opportunity to engage with the committee and answer questions about the Bill.

1. The meeting is a discussion of a product prototype for a new remote control. The prototype is a handheld device, with a curved design and big, easy-to-use buttons. It is powered by kinetic energy and uses chip on print technology. The design is simple, with a yellow and black color scheme, and there is also a banana-shaped version of the prototype.
2. The group evaluates the prototype using a set of criteria, including whether it is fancy, technologically innovative, easy to use, trendy, has excess buttons, has good buttons, is ugly, is sellable, and other. The group determines that the prototype is elegant/fancy, technologically not innovative, easy to use, trendy, has no excess buttons, has good buttons, is not ugly, is sellable, and is cost saving/environmentally friendly.
3. The group also discusses the finance aspect of the project, including the number of components to be used in the device, such as a hand dynamo, battery, kinetic, solar cells, electronic simple chip on print, and case material supplements. The total cost of the project is calculated to be nine Pounds twenty out of the twelve and a half they were allowed.
4. The group is satisfied with the project process and finds new ideas, such as the use of fruit shape and spongy material. The group also determines that the costs are within the budget and the project is evaluated to be excellent, with a score of 1.88 out of 2. The group will do the final questionnaire, meeting summary, and a final report will be presented.

1. The group is discussing the transcription of audio data for the Meeting Recorder project. They are considering ways to improve the efficiency of the transcription process, including the possibility of using single channel parts instead of mixed signals.
